Roy Mustang is badass, Hawkeye is also really cool. The main villians all have entertaining personalities, and you can even sympathise with some of them. The character development was also amazing.
ANIMATION: 10/10
This show was made by Studio Bones, so this rating shouldn't come as a surprise to anybody. This show has some of the best fights I've ever seen. Character designs were all memorable and the world looked awesome.
SOUND: 9/10
The opening were all bangers (especially the first one), and even some of the endings were bops. This show has ONE OF THE BEST DUBS EVER, and it's hard the top the voice acting in the sub, so that's saying something. The music used in the show was good, but I didn't remember a lot of it.
ENJOYMENT: 10/10
This show had me HOOKED. I loved each and every episode (except the recap, that episode was okay), and I watched the last 9 episodes of the show in one day (that's a 
lot for me). I couldn't shut up about this anime when I was talking to other people either, much to their dismay.
OVERALL: 9.6/10 (Rounded out to a 10/10)
This show is amazing, and if you haven't seen it yet, DROP ANYTHING YOU'RE DOING RIGHT NOW AND WATCH IT. The flaws are so minor, you might as well call them nitpicks. So, I can't feasibly give this show anything lower than a 10.

Fullmetal Alchemist: Brotherhood is an anime masterpiece and it dethroned Avatar: The last Airbender to become the best anime series to date! An absolute "Must-Watch" for anyone who appreciates great animation, outstanding character design and a solid plot. There are plenty of heart-warming moments as well as some soul-crushing ones, a massive array of badass fight scenes, solid dialogue, great comedy, a bit of romance, this series really does have it all!
Watching this anime is like watching the first season of 24. You think you can watch just an episode or two and then go about your life but suddenly, nine hours have gone by
                  and you should have been in bed six hours ago and now you are gonna have to call in sick because you are in no condition to go to work in the morning. Brotherhood grabs you by the balls and doesn't let go until it is done.

FMAB might be the perfect anime.
Story: 10
The writing in this anime is beyond phenomenal. It keeps you engaged, and it leaves you wanting more. It manages to communicate its philosophies and its themes in a way that feels so impactful and meaningful.
Art: 9
I'm very tempted to give it a 10. The animation is crisp yet fluid, and I enjoy the art style a lot. The fight scenes are amazing. Sound: 9
The first opening might be the greatest opening in anime of all time. And it's not even the only opening in this show I can say that about. Enough said.
Character: 10
This might be the show's greatest strength. The characters are all complex and layered with personality, ideals, and motivations. Edward and Alphonse are the driving force behind this show, but they aren't the only great characters. Winry, Roy Mustang, and especially Hohenheim are all some of my favorite characters, period. What's more, the antagonists are also absolutely outstanding.
Enjoyment: 10
I love this show so much. It is so well-written, so well-produced, and just off of the merits of its quality alone, managed to earn a 10 in enjoyment.
Overall: 10
What can I say? I can't find a single fault. Not one crack, in 64 episodes. It's phenomenal. It's way too good. It might be one of the best TV shows, not just one of the best anime.

The Perfect Anime?
Yes yes it is. Hell i wish all animes where like this but then i feel i wouldn't be able to have some fun reviewing animes that are hidden gems
Listen this anime is Myanimelist top anime if that isn't enough to convice you why are you reading reviews but if it was that simple then i wouldn't be doing this.
Funny enough this was one of those animes that i'd be fine not watching but i watched it with a friend who loves this show and over the couple days of watching it i never got bored, this show has enough going on that
                  you are constantly entertained but not enough that you're super confused with the amount of stuff going on. The one thing this anime does better than anything else is the characters and their relationships each character feels real i didn't find a character i overly hated it was just i like those better than others.
The story is well crafted with a nice couple of twist and turns with a great mystery to boot but the one thing i find most impressive is that has several moments to slow down and let the characters catch their breaths which allows the audience to take a breath as well and not have plot and exposition thrown in their face constantly 
FMA Brotherhood is a worth while anime and is one that i would recommend to anyone either if they hadn't watched it or they are just getting into anime because it truly deserves to be number 1

[Non-Spoiler Review]
I cried 4 times. And this isn't even a slice of life or romance anime. That's how I knew I couldn't rate it anything less than a 9. 
I had high hopes for this anime. It's highly regarded in the anime community and I thought, surely it couldn't be THAT good. And I was sorely mistaken. The first couple of episodes were somewhat slow for me. After the first one, I thought that this could get really good but lazily watched it at my own pace. And after episode 10, I was hooked through and through. I binged it so quickly. 
The characters are
                  the absolute highlight for me. I adored every single character. I have attachments with virtually ALL the characters, even ones that started off as villians. I couldn't believe how often I managed to cry. The art style of the characters made it that much easier, it actually hurt. And also, I really liked how at no point were the main protagonists (and even the side ones) unbeatable. They bled, they got hurt, they suffered the consequences of their actions. They stood right back up afterwards. As much as I love seeing fights where the MC's dominate, FMAB was a breath of fresh air in that aspect. I had no idea who was going to win, and what they had to lose as a result of winning. They weren't invincible. They were genuinely human... to an extent (iykyk).   
And the pacing is just right, not too slow or fast. I could get through an easy 15+ episodes without even thinking to pause. I never thought I'd rate something a 10/10 (though the ones I have, have been purely out of enjoyment, not taking everything into account). I 100% recommend watching this. 64 episodes never felt shorter, I was really skirting around my house avoiding finishing the last couple of episodes. 
Fullmetal Alchemist: Brotherhood is well worth the hype. The comedic relief, the emotional moments, the action, plot, everything. It was everything tied up in a really nice bow. I'm sad it's over but the ending didn't beg for more. I probably could've watched 50 more episodes of the aftermath.

******Fullmetal Alchemist:Brotherhood Review********
First of all let me start off by telling, "WOAH! What a kick-ass series this is!!". This was my second time watching the series and let me tell you, the series just gets better and better as you keep repeating it and another thing to be noted is that this is far more better than the original FMA (you will eventually find out once you watch both the series).  
The story of FMA:Brotherhood is what other anime writers crave to develop but fail miserably, this being said I don't want to underestimate other worthy anime series out there.Law of Equivalent exchange was one of the major bases in the show and I must say that it was pretty much well executed by the series.The story progresses in a subtle way and has it's twist and turns, twists and turns which will probably blow your mind off.Overall, The story of two brothers who performed the ultimate taboo in alchemy; Human Transmutation go on a rugged and dangerous journey to get their bodies back and in the course of getting their bodies back they meet different people and face many obstacles is pretty well handled.Pretty Surprisingly, this series was able to include almost everything in it i.e action, comedy( the comic timing between the characters and the comedy was just awesome), emotion, drama, fantasy, etc 
The characters in this series are one of the best part of this series, The main characters of this series around whom the series is based are pretty well protrayed and the development of the characters is absolutely flawless. My favourite characters in the series were Winry rockbell and Edward Elric, their portrayal in the series was awesome. The worst character in the series must be Envy (OH god! Seriously Envy gave me creeps). Many other characters are introduced in the series here and there and their portrayal in the series was also fine.
The music and the soundtrack in this series was just freaking awesome. I can express in words how much I liked the OP and ED of this series, as each and every one of them tends to go with the flow of the series and all of them were able to grip my interest.The sound effects in the series is also good and enhances the viewing experience of the viewer during the series.
Overall, FMA:Brotherhood entertains viewer in each and every episode and leaves them at the edge of their seats with the sudden twists and turns in the episodes. Also, FMA:Brotherhood is far better than the original FMA as the story is better faced and the characters are portrayed better in this series. The series is also successful in portraying comedy, violence, fantasy, drama, emotions, etc in a managed manner. So, I recommend this anime to every person, and especially who are against anime as this anime will definitely change the view of such people. 
What are you waiting for? Just give it a try for heaven's sake.  I doubt you'll regret watching it.

Its The King of all anime's. If someone is looking for a start in anime, he should start this one.
The story is unique and provides a thrill after every episode, something that not a lot of anime's can do.
It is also polished as compared to 2003 version. Some characters have been removed or added in order to make the story memorable.
The art style can still compare to modern day anime's.
Even though its 64 eps long, it still has the entertainment and thriller. You will never get bored. 
Summary: Edward and Alphonse Elric live in Resembool with their mother Trisha and father Van Hohenheim, the latter
                  having left without a reason. Trisha soon dies from an illness. After finishing their alchemy training under Izumi Curtis, the Elrics attempt to bring their mother back with alchemy. The transmutation backfires, and Edward loses his left leg while Alphonse loses his body. Edward sacrifices his right arm to retrieve Alphonse's soul, binding it to a suit of armor. Edward is invited by Roy Mustang to become a State Alchemist (to research a way to restore their bodies) and undergoes a painful medical procedure which grants him prosthetic automail limbs. Edward becomes a State Alchemist, with the title of Fullmetal Alchemist. The Elrics spend the next three years searching for the mythical Philosopher's Stone to achieve their goals.

A concise and touching story that makes you feel fulfilled upon finishing it. With memorable characters, meaningful relationships, and powerful moments.  
Pros:
- Every line, every visual, and every character has a purpose to the overarching plot and that's what I enjoyed the most about it. It truly feels as if we're only seeing the tip of the iceberg as we watch, but the trust we put in the author is never betrayed as she constantly delivers and rewards us for our attention.
- The theme of family and friendship is not just 'portrayed', it feels genuine. The dynamics between the characters and their interactions have
                  a unique touch of realness to them and the banter between them is always a pleasure. 
- The comedy, even when it's out of place, is gold.
- Mustang and Hawkeye, both as individual characters and together, are absolutely amazing. Everything about them was well-written and they were my favorite part about this anime.
- The politics in this anime actually surprised me with its depth. Human atrocities is a subject lots of stories touch upon, but to start the story on the side of the people who committed these atrocities was a fresh perspective and it was told well. 
- The antagonists were a force to be reckoned with, and though some of them had an overwhelming and scary presence, lots of them felt like genuine human beings. The motivations of the villains were as powerful as the heroes'. Also, their plan for world domination ACTUALLY MADE SENSE. 
- Amazingly written female characters. The author of FMA proves that female characters don't need to be insanely powerful (though there certainly are insanely powerful women in FMA) to be taken seriously. 
Cons:
- The fight sequences just weren't good. I look back and think I've only enjoyed the fights where King Bradley was involved, which weren't many. The number of times Ed broke his automail and rendered useless during fights is ridiculous.
- The pacing was very slow in the beginning half of the story. I almost dropped it because, even though things were HAPPENING, they weren't happening at a pace which I enjoyed.
- Tons of build-up that often didn't pay off. The constant hyping up of characters and moments just to later be interrupted or ruined actually pissed me off. If I had a drinking game every time Edward made an empty threat, I would've been hospitalized. The number of times Alphonse or Greed were hyped up to be strong just to be easily defeated, was infuriating. 
- The character of Alphonse, while provided good emotional support and was the gentle counterpart to Ed, was useless in almost every fight he was in. As a 'fighter' he just... wouldn't DO MUCH. 
- A disappointing conclusion to the romantic relationships that the author put so much emphasis on. I felt cheated with the Winry 'hug', and more so when we didn't even get a conclusion to the Mustang and Hawkeye romantic subplot. 
Quotes:
"Life that has been lost cannot be brought back again. That very truth is what shows us the meaning and value of living." - Roy Mustang 
"War does not determine who is right, only who is left." -Riza Hawkeye
"Look straight at the people you kill; don't take your eyes off them for a second. And don't ever forget them because they won't forget you." - Solf J. Kimblee

I just have to say that the final is everything, the anime goes thru with some good phrases and scenes, but man the final got me crying. 
In some point I was not that in love with the characters but as they develop, you start to create some link with them, and I am going to say it again, when you see the last episode your heart cracks of joyness (I do not know how to explain it more precisely). 
All the phrases and things that are said in the last episode are meant to be written in our hearts, and al the scenes and
                  animations, everything is made the right way.
For me the last episode repair all the things that I thought were missing in this anime. 
JUST WATCH IT PLEASE.
FMA is a must watch for sure.

A brilliant and well constructed story that follows the manga much more closely apart from the first few episodes.
There is an extremely good balance of humour and fantasy, as well as its spinechilling and downright sickening moments. But with also enough lulls in the storyline such that it's not incredibly action packed every episode.
The range of characters and their personalities are also very well balanced and contrasted against each other in the appropriate situations. Should it be military personnel providing a more serious atmosphere, to more rowdy/different characters such as Edward himself to provide a bit of humour.
Certainly, this is a must watch, and it's
                  hard not to be disappointed by this series.

*REVIEW FOR FULLMETAL ALCHEMIST: BROTHERHOOD*
Story (10/10):
In my opinion, FMA:B has one of the greatest stories of anime. Based in a fictional country within a law with its own physics rules (alchemy), the series successfully manages to keep the viewer wanting more and more episodes. This aspect is also completed by the main characters' goals (return to the original bodies and .... (here's a spoiler so nah)) 
Animation & Art (8/10):
The animation deserves a 7/10 but thanks to the beautiful art of the series, I think it deserves overall an 8/10 on this criterion. They knew how to add symbolism to the story, a very important
                  detail in my opinion. Also although the animation isn't great, the shots are amazing.
Sound, Voice Acting & Music (10/10):
Everything in this criterion is a 10/10. The soundtracks? Excellent. The voice acting? Great. The openings/endings? Legendary.
Character (10/10):
The characters are not well-built. They are "legendary-built". The character development is one of the things that will impress you regarding the character as you advance further in the story. There are also a lot of characters that from villains turn to heroes, and from heroes turn to villains, an interesting detail that you don't want to miss.
Overall, Fullmetal Alchemist: Brotherhood is an ABSOLUTELY must-watch for all anime enthusiasts. Although the first 10 episodes are weak, give it a try and I assure you the final quarter is LEGENDARY.
Recommendable only to anime enthuasists? : No.
Genre: Action, Drama, Adventure.

This show is amazing, i love it from the bottom of my heart i do, it would receive a 9 on a scale out of 10 from me, the only limiting factors being i missed some of what would have been considered "filler" episodes that truly added to the story, and on rewatchability level. this could be considered my first rewatch and i dont have the same desire to go through it all again as i do for shows ive given a 10 to in the past. 
The story itself is one i find keeps me drawn into wanting to see more and find out
                  more about it, and its why i wish that they didnt remove the filler in a way. 
As for rewatching, it just seems that with where it was left it is like a good book that ends right where it should to keep you wanting more, and i dont think it does that in a bad way.

A Christian's Anime Review
Full Metal Alchemist: Brotherhood
Discernment Topics
Violence: \/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/
Superpowered science (which might as well be magic) is used to burn, cut, crush, impale, drain, and otherwise harm people.
Many weapons such as guns, tanks, swords, and explosives are used frequently in fights and warfare.
Throngs of dead people are shown in the aftermath of war. Ethnic cleansing is a part of this.Blood, occasionally detailed wounds, dismemberment, and extreme pain are depicted often.
Language:\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/
Frequent mild language.
Spiritual Content:\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/
[Spoilers]
Immortality gained through the use of the souls of the dead is a reoccurring theme throughout.
A villain desires to destroy/talk to/become "God" or some such nonsense.
A seemingly omnipotent and omniscient being know as "Truth" exists near a door with many names for God inscribed on it. It demands a sacrifice of one's body in exchange for knowledge.
A group of people known as Ishvalans follow a certain religion revering a god named Ishvala.
A charlatan cons a bunch of people into believing he is a messenger of a god named Leto.
The main character of the series expresses atheism in the name of science. However, he later prays to God for help.
Fanservice:\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/
Several instances of minor fanservice.
One case of unfeatured nudity not in the vain of fanservice of a group of souls given form.
Misc. Suggestive Content:\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/
Ethnic cleansing and mass murder is a featured action taken by the villains.
Detached Assessment
Story:\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/
10/10
Shonen, sci-fi, fantasy-ish, adventure that delivers on many emotional and exciting scenes.
It's ending is also very good.
Characters:\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/
10/10
Likable characters who receive ample developement along with a great cast of supporting characters.
Art:\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/
10/10
Bones studio does a spectacular job of making everything look great. Especially the fight scenes.
Occasional lapses into comedic, chibi-style artwork may be jarring to some people. I found it fitting for the jokes though.
Sound:\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/
10/10
OST was serviceable.
All OPs and EDs were fantastic and are worth listening to again and again.
Enjoyment:\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/
10/10
Nothing disappoints here.
Everything was outstanding.
Conclusion
Fans of epic stories with great endings will appreciate this show.
Compared to the older series, "Fullmetal Alchemist", this one has the better ending hands down.

This my first time writing a review but I felt the need to, so please go easy on me.
What I really wanted to say is the character so maybe you can skip to that for major criticism mainly on Roy Mustang.
Story 9/10
The story is great. First, it had a solid plot throughout the series. Ed and Al were trying to get their bodies back from the beginning and stayed true to their goal which is good. Some anime had a goal from the beginning but strays along the way or stopped mentioning about it until the end. FMAB does it every now and then. It
                  may sound repetitive but it reminds us what their objective is and what they are trying to do. 
The subplot I would consider to be the scheme of the empire and how it revolves around the alchemy and the fight for the philosopher's stone. It's like some pirates trying to get some treasure at the end of the journey but had issues along the way, which I would consider those issues as subplots. It was developed well throughout the series and well-concluded at the end. Since no spoilers are allowed I could not elaborate further but the subplot does intertwine well with Ed and Al's objectives.
The definition of alchemy in FMAB had a solid foundation. Alchemy could only be performed with equal values and the only interruption that could occur would be the use of philosopher's stone. There was no major power inflation which makes the characters insanely powerful. It thought this was a rare touch on a shounen anime. The elaboration between the 2 difference races, their vengeance, hatred and discrimination felt real to me. The terror of war as such was also well-mentioned in series. Learning to endure and forgive was a subplot too and served as an important message.  
The anime has just the right amount of story-telling, nothing too draggy nor lacking. However, some episodes I felt doesn't link well with the next episode. I felt some were rushed through at certain points. For example, one of them was the time-skip. Most shounen animes have time-skips FMAB had it too. However the previous episode showed Al in a certain place then the next it jumped right into the time-skip which I felt awkward. And the separation of a certain character who was together felt like it jumped out of nowhere. It was never explained why they decided to move to those certain places after the time-skip. So it is a 9.
Art 10/10
I thought the art was great for the year. Art style is a matter of personal preference. I thought the art style was good and since there were no major distortion in the art I thought I would give it a pretty high score. There were some good use of chibi characters and good battle effects and movement. It is rather promising if you look at the year of release. Overall, I enjoyed the art, the flashiness and the character art design and had some characters design which I find cool and adorable so I gave it 10/10 out of my level of satisfaction.
Sound 10/10
Good use of sound. All the OPs and EDs were fantastic. I love them all. Some episodes had the EDs cut into the ending scene which I believe was a good use. It gave me goosebumps. I am loose on battle sound effects, as long as it doesn't feel awkward it is fine. So overall 10.
Character 5/10
Characters. This portion is where I had the biggest problem with. I wish I could elaborate on each character but I think I will just focus on Winry and Roy Mustang(along with Kimblee, Hawkeye, Armstrong, Hughes for comparison)
Before I start on those 2 I mentioned, I need to mention that some characters that later joined the crew felt rather unnecessary. Because IMO I think they could be replaced by basically anyone. No background stories no particular connections, it was like they were just there to help out with the last boss because they desperately needed people. I didn't mind but they felt random to me. For example, Dr. Marcoh was there for a reason, Scar was, Winry was the mech, The Xings had a reason etc but those were not the same. So I was perplexed.  
Winry. I felt like she was just a plot device rather than a character. Her change of perspective and resolve were too sudden. Winry was there because the brothers needed her support, she was Edward's weakness, she needed the interaction with Scar for the plot etc. I needed to see more of her struggle, how she overcome the barrier after knowing the truth. I believe Scar was influenced by Winry and maybe the accompany of the little girl and mustache, but Scar's objective was to wipe out all state alchemists regardless whether they are children or adults. What happened to that? Scar was even threatening to kill Winry early in the series. I needed to see the struggle and more interaction between the 2.
I am going to bash on Roy Mustang so proceed with caution.
Roy Mustang. How and where should I start without spoiling. As a general knowledge, the military took part in genocide of Ishval before the start of the show. I am totally fine with that as a story. Most of the people that were important had their personal thoughts and views with regard to their participation in the war. But Roy had close to none, which makes me feel that he is lacking in his character development. 
If you look at Kimblee, he was someone who enjoyed massacre and enjoyed his moments in his war. I think it was justified because he was portrayed as someone who enjoys annihilation of Ishvalan and I am totally fine with his characterization. I don't hate him just because he's a villain. He was alright as a character.
Armstrong, he was a coward during the war. Armstrong did both the right and wrong things in the war. He escaped after seeing children/civilians getting killed. This might look biased because I think Armstrong was a morally righteous person who chose to escape. However it was also a wrong thing to do as a soldier. But because of that I got to know his character better at that point so I was fine.
The problems with Roy Mustang I believed would be his view on Ishval, how he reacted after the war. How he felt towards the people he killed. How he felt with using his alchemy despite being told not to get the flame alchemy. I know Roy had a resolve, he wanted to stand at the top so that he can change the country. But that decision does not link well with his action in the genocide of Ishval. The best comparison I could use here would be Hawkeye. Hawkeye participated in the war. She wanted to make the country better so she joined the military but ended up killing people. She showed her resentment so she asked Roy to do something to her which I could not say here. She even spoke her mind out when chatting with Edward regarding the issue and was able to show her emotions to Scar. But Roy lacked that. Maybe I could say the resentment phase. Without that it makes me think that he would go on burning people again even if it was needed to make the Ishvalan better. This confirmed my belief because the last episode showed exactly how he can ruthlessly use something gotten during the massacre in order to achieve his goal. He knew that his flame alchemy had done atrocious deeds. They at least need to show him hesitating in using his flame etc. He was so unethical in his last choice in the last episode. Think of the people you sacrificed. Think of your families who were sacrificed and getting used. If Roy was written as a cunning villain or a brainless dude who just follows orders I think he has a justified characterization. But I try to believe Roy was meant to be a righteous person and decisive character at heart, but the anime failed to show that in my opinion. 
The people were saying he was forced I mean the Ishvalans were forced after tying them up. The lost souls were forced to be used. "I will use the souls I brutally killed" sounds nice to you? Besides he could do it even in that condition. If the anime showed reasons like say you cannot become the Fuhrer if you are in that condition then maybe he would have no choice but at least he should seek the permission of the Ishvalans first, asking them if he could use the souls of their families sisters brothers mothers fathers friends. After all he is still a war criminal.
The relationship between Roy and Hughes were rather good. Roy showed how he felt with Hughes' situation yet no elaboration on Ishval's case. 
BTW I have read the manga and I must say I liked Roy Mustang much more than the anime. I didn't know why they changed in the anime. I didn't like the anime version of Roy Mustang.
Enjoyment 8/10
I still loved the series. I was touched and teared up a little too. The journey was promising and the fights were alright. If you compare with the recent works done by the same studio, not too flashy but I still enjoyed the sword fights and the use of alchemy, gun shots and their brain power. Moreover, the plot was great and I enjoyed it a lot.

A re-styling of Fullmetal Alchemist with crisper animation, more plot, more logical storylines, and better backstory, Brotherhood follows the plot of the manga more closely, giving Ed and Al's father more of a role. And I think most of the voice actors returned, which is great, because Ed and Al are perfect. If you're going to watch just one, watch this one.

Just one word - Masterpiece !!!!!!!!!!!
This is my first review , please tell me if i lack anything -
FMAB deserves the praise it gets , most importantly people compare it with other animes and tend to say FMAB lacks this but in my opinion its just perfect . 
First time i felt attach to so many characters , it was awesome not a single episode bored me.
If you are confused to watch it or not , i mean cmon man there shouldn't be option for skipping this legendary anime.
The osts are amazing , badass characters like roy mustang. Our man Edward isn't the strongest but
                  one of the best MCs.
FMAB will forever be in my heart.

Fullmetal Alchemist: Brotherhood is really a testament to the original work of the manga. Although the details from the beginning of the series were omitted (these episodes are covered in Fullmetal Alchemist 2003) in all other respects, it is a faithful retelling of Hiromu Arakawa's work. 
The story has a rich cast of characters whose lives become increasing interwoven with the journey of Edward and Alphonse. The story is incredibly cohesive and many of the characters introduced throughout the series remain relevant and actively play a role in the final climax of the plot, which I find particularly impressive. 
There is a lot of depth
                  to each of the characters and the anime does a good job of accurately portraying their quirks and motivations throughout the series. The animators make it possible for you to deeply sympathize with the characters and makes the impacts of the themes of justice, determination, and perseverance even more stark and relatable. You can especially see Alphonse and Ed go through a lot of character development as you visibly see them grow up through the series.
The action scenes are very well choreographed, and the art style is very classic in my opinion and has aged well. The opening and ending themes were fitting and well animated as well. 
In Summary: The story and characters are really what make this anime shine and a favorite of many throughout the years. This is definitely worth a watch if you enjoyed the manga or even if you haven't read the manga, this anime is outstanding on its own.

This show, I dont even know where to begin with it. Wow. Just, wow. 
Very few shows would I rate a 10, in fact as of right now, this is the only one that qualifies in my mind. Whether it really is the perfect show doesn't really matter because it is to me.
I first watched Fullmetal two years ago and I was struck by a colourful cast of characters, an intriguing story and a crippling anime addiction. The pacing is incredible, the romance is believable, and doesn't get in the way of the storytelling. I don't cry much, especially not for background characters, but when
                  I tell you I cried watching this show I CRIED. (In a good way of course!) 
Another thing I love is the small details sprinked throughout the show, some that I hadn't even noticed until the second time through.
In conclusion: WATCH THIS SHOW. DO IT.

Did you know, i had to try 3 times to finish this anime. First 2 times, i dropped it cause it was too dark. But after half graduating from anime i became determined to finish this and i finally did.
This anime is a masterpiece and i knew that from the start cause of the ratings.
Firstly, the characters, the mc Elric brothers are perfect characters. Their traits, reactions, actions, emotions everything is enjoyable. Other characters have all unique traits and with enough depth except the main villain the father. He seemed somewhat under delivered. No! It's not cause of him severing his 7 emotions, he is
                  still plain boring but his 7 emotions are good though, just the combined person is meh.
The plot is about the villain, wanting to become god by serving all his emotions and his slave who was somewhat villain's creation wanting to stop him. Alchemy, equivalent exchange, Philosophers stone and you can already imagine the rest. Then comes the MC Elrick brothers who really seen hell on earth because of their immaturity and had to learn everything the hard way. Amidst long term planning, between two sides, the mc has their adventure to search for their beliefs. Various variable comes to play in between.
The art is old even though it's a remake. But, still no complains there cause it matches the anime setting. Sound is good throughout the anime except poor opening and ending themes, which i hardly  care about.
I watched 1500-2000 series in this oriental fiction industry so it's not easy to move me but watching Early Elric hell and that chimera girl left a bad taste in my mouth. Making a a 25 year old veteran have change of feeling means the anime is successful. The comedy was enjoyable throughout the journey. The early part was 10/10 the finishing became somewhat mild because of veteran experience. I had to skip and drag a lot which i really didn't want to but had to. The story overall was perfect. All dots are connected. Only flaw was Edward's last action of sacrificing his knowledge for his arm. It felt like Deus ex machina, they could've done it differently. I enjoyed it even though this experience would've multiplied if i watched it when i started my anime journey. Well, it can't be helped cause the anime is too dark at the start even though it becomes normal as the story progresses.
I give it a solid 9 overall and i recommend this to everyone of course

So the most popular, "Number One"-Anime on this site can't possibly be bad, right? Well fear not, this is not meant to be contrarian or going against the masses for the sake of being cool or simply different, no. I can wholeheartedly support the notion that Fullmetal Alchemist: Brotherhood is nothing short of a fantastic show. Really, the only goal this review has, for me personally, is to find out whether it's really great or even a masterpiece. You see, since i always make up these reviews as i go, i am not really sure myself ate the start. But let's take a look:
Story: The
                  story is outstanding, let me get this out of the way first. It's such a carefully crafted plot, with all the foreshadowing that a story of this kind carries around. However, it is always a little subtle, so that you can only really spot it on a rewatch. That said, the story is also rather straightforward, it's nothing to crazy or outlandish, all the concepts seem to be grounded in this world, that's not that different from ours, except that some people are capable of using a kind of magic called "Alchemy". It gets a little crazy towards the end, but even that is always established throughout the show, always in the back of the head of the Elric Brothers and the viewer. It deals with some heavy themes, the loss of loved ones, the desperate desire to bring them back, the punishment for ones naive sins and how to deal with it, how to bear it or maybe fight it and to protect the people that still remain. Also, to bring it down the basics: what it means to be human. While it has some truly tragic scenes, enough to make you shed some tears, certainly, there is also just a lot of fun. Really,the story is able to invoke the whole range of emotions, something that is always tough, or even nigh impossible, to do.
Art: Something the art in this show really manages to capture is facial expressions, especially for Edward. When his eyes go wide because he saw something horrible or if he is angry, simply by being called out on his height, the drawings always capture his emotions perfectly. But the same goes for other characters, Roy Mustang, Armstrong and Hohenheim and even Alphonse,fascinating enough. He doesn't even have a face, but just the way his eyes get smaller or just completely go dark, you always get a idea how he might feel in a moment. I gotta say though, not a huge fan of the art style. It looks nice, certainly, it's still pretty good, but it's just a little too basic to me. It' kinda hard to express what i mean, but i just really like stuff that goes a little off the rails. In contrast to that, FMA:B goes a more realistic route and that is okay, it's something a can like, but not completely love. Some of the character designs are a little silly, mostly in the Homunculus-department, but then some are absolutely brilliant, even if a huge chunk of the characters wear the same uniform. Not that this is a problem, the blue looks pretty sharp. So the art is overall very good, even if it seemed like i had a lot of qualms with it. I didn't, i blew it out of proportion, just a tad.
Sound: Something that really stands out here is the voice acting, that is some real quality. Romi Park does such an amazing job as the lead role and she is pretty much the whole reason i could never watch this show dubbed, even if always hear good things about the english voice work. I mention her specifically, but the whole cast is actually amazing, without fail really. Then again, i don't actually know japanese, so it's hard for me to spot a bad actor, i suppose. To my amateur-ears, it all sounded great. And then there is the habit of some great Ending-transitions. They are so memorable and always so brilliantly timed that they really make for the best scenes. Especially the door-scene, that might be my favorite in the whole show. The Soundtrack is nice as well, especially the main theme, always brings a tear to my eye. I just wouldn't listen to it separately. There are also a lot of openings and endings and they all range from pretty good to great. My personal favorite might still be the first opening, but over the rewatch i also grew fond of "Golden Time Lover". The sound receives a final verdict of great.
Characters: This section, in tandem with the story might be the best part of the show. The main characters are great, the side characters too, the villains as well, i guess you can see where this is going. They all have their struggles and motivations, even if for some the motivation is simply:"Father says so." Even that works, simply because the cast is so massive that you really get all kinds of characters. At the same time, however, the how manages to avoid all the common tropes. Yes, Edward is a bit of a hotheaded shonen-protagonist, but at the same time, he is a straight-up genius, levelheaded as soon as he actually enters the fight his short temper brought him into. They are many examples of that, but that's something everyone should discover for themselves, how much there actually is to the characters. Just want to say that you won't find your twintail-tsundere or your dandere with some shade of blue in her hair. Not to say that i don't enjoy these archetypes, but if your fed up with more of the same, Brotherhood delivers something different. That alone wouldn't be enough for outstanding Characters, but again, i won't say too much, only that there is a lot of depth and development.   
Enjoyment: In 64 Episodes, i was never bored or had the urge to check the time on an episode. That is truly amazing, some regular 12 episode anime don't manage that. So what else could i say to prove my enjoyment? That the adventures of the Fullmetal Alchemist Alphonse Elric and his little assistant threw me through all the emotions i already mentioned. The pacing is always perfect too and the payoff for some of the slower segments is outstanding. So this will be the score for my enjoyment, i loved it, not every episode, but i at least liked them all.
So in the end, it only barely misses the ten and i think that's okay. Fullmetal Alchemist is something anyone can enjoy and i wouldn't judge you if you said it's your favorite anime of all time. For me, however, it's a little too grounded. I mentioned this before, but i prefer something a teeny bit more complicated. Really, only a small margin, cause this show is pretty complex too. Does it help if i mention that my favorite anime is either Monogatari or Madoka? Yeah, i am one of those people... . But there you have it, a great anime with pretty much everything you cold ever want, stellar animation, a good story with a nice ending and a whole bunch of likeable and complex characters. This is why we watch anime, right? I certainly do.

--The review contains spoilers--
So my review is based on recent rewatch. Used to give this anime a 9-10 given how good the story is for its time. Animation as well. This review really stems from my recent discussion on how I used to feel attack on titan being similar to FMA. But it just made me grow less fond of FMA after further comparison.
Art 7/10
I know its not fair because this was done in 2009. But I felt the arts tone sometimes felt inconsistent. Biggest example is when Ed was showing anguish after confronting Shou Tucker. It was supposed to be a serious moment yet
                  the art made it look comical, but I'm not really bumping it down for that.
Story 8.5/10
Its still a good story with amazing revelations. However they removed so much from the manga causing some very odd pacing. I did not realize this before and simply enjoyed it. Dublith arc is an example of this with no build up to Bradley appearing in South. Like why? In the manga it was much better, with also a clear reason why Bradley knows where Greed was. Another complaint is the gags. The first time I watched it I had no issues, but now I feel it drags the pacing of the story a lot. It also makes it hard to appreciate the dark undertones of the story. I again did not realize this problem before. Only after watching AoT do I get to appreciate the lack of humor. Additionally, felt that the first season had lots of fillers that dragged the story a lot, second season was when the story improves. 
Also I realized a big problem. The beginning of the series, its hard to relate to the brothers other than to he sad for them. But I mean they really want to get their body back, but the urgency isn't there. It had a weaker start.
Characters 7/10
Used to appreciate Edward Elric and Roy Mustang more. But I feel FMA has a large cast with some of them not really essential to the plot. Thus reducing screen time for some of these characters. Hughes and Havoc to me was not developed as good as I expected.

Wow, what an anime. Before I get into my full review I have to admit that I've actually dropped this show before. I guess I could blame onto life getting in the way, so when everything was settled I decided to restart from the beginning and honestly I couldn't have made a better decision. Another confession, I haven't watched the 2003 FMA and I probably won't. I've already seen this version and would much rather spend my time watching a fresh new anime.
I was recommended FMA: Brotherhood by a random website. For those you that don't know, I've watched some anime's in the past but
                  never really got deep into the lifestyle. So I decided to do myself a favor and search some anime's a beginner should watch and from the endless lists I decided to start at FMA: Brotherhood. The only problem now is that the other anime's might not hold up.
Where do I even start? 
Story  8/10
I'm guessing everyone has read the synopsis and I'm not allowed to spoil much but story is really good. Unlike some other anime's I've seen, such as Bleach, there aren't filler episodes. The viewer just progresses forward without the plot stopping to catch up with the manga artist. There aren't any plot holes, well not any in my opinion. (I am just a beginner.) The plot twists are also very good, I learned my lesson not to trust everyone and to not judge someone too quickly.
Art & Sound 7/10
My rating might be a little biased because of my naivety but Brotherhood's artwork is good. What really draws you in are the fight scenes. Sound is good as well, I really liked the third opening. It's the only one I've saved to my playlist.
Character  8/10
The characters are very rich. Most of them are nicely fleshed out and each time a major death happens it tugs at your heart. The creators did a good job of having the viewers connect with the characters that when we lose them it's hard to see them go. 
Enjoyment  10/10
It's so obvious that I really, really enjoyed this show. Definitely in my top 5 now.

I will be plan and simple, this anime is perfect, it was the only series that fully attended what a want in the genre of shounen, it redefines the genre, refines existing elements and creates and many new ones, the story goes and ends with everything solved and the whole plot is connected, the author had the whole story on his mind so there he could finished it without having the trouble of "forgetting" or missing something out, i watched it last year, please make yourself a favor and what it NOW. 
And btw, Mustang X Riza will always be my OTP, and i am
                  not even a romance fan. And also, the comedy on this anime is on another leve, fun but not dumb whille being intelligent but no boring, fucking masterpiece.

Brilliant. Absolutely -BRILLIANT-.
Fullmetal Alchemist: Brotherhood is meant to be a more faithful re-telling of the Fullmetal Alchemist manga, where the original anime deviated greatly from the original material's story. I must say, they hit the mark spot on. The greater amount of humor that existed in the manga is here, but also the darker story elements are also there, creating a huge contrast from the original anime.
The art is amazing, using the colors and tones from the manga adds a nice visual difference that sets it apart from the original series.
All the same characters are back, and I am especially happy that they used the
                  exact same voice cast for the english dub as the original FMA anime series, this is a HUGE thumbs up to Funimation.
Overall, FMA: Brotherhood is a GREAT retelling of the series from the manga's storyline. You do not have to read the manga or watch the original FMA anime series to follow Brotherhood, but I recommend the original series as well as it was a nicely done anime, despite it's let-down ending.

Unlike the 2003 adaptation, Brotherhood is a faithful representation of Arakawa Hiromu's manga.
Fullmetal Alchemist: Brotherhood is starting at a breakneck pace. However, once you get used to it, the pacing feels very appropriate for the series and only seems to increase the suspense. Brotherhood always manages to switch between serious and comedy. Interestingly, one of the greatest advantages of Brotherhood is actually its wealth of interesting characters. The original FMA focused primarily on the two main characters and their efforts to regain their bodies, while Brotherhood also explores other characters in great detail at the same time.
One of the many good things about this series
                  is that there is no infill at all (yes, I'm thinking of Naruto etc), which keeps the story from losing momentum. All the episodes are concise and each scene is important as part of the huge main story.
The art is in a different style, a bit simpler, but that's not a bad thing. What is lacking in detail, it makes up for with some premier fight sequences. The animation is generally very neat and the movements of the characters are very fluid and natural.
The voice acting is excellent and consistent, and I think pretty much all of the characters have voice actors to suit their personalities. With such a cast of actors, you wouldn't expect less. Most opening / ending are fun to listen to.
You'd be hard pressed to find a shonen anime that will entertain you as much as Fullmetal Alchemist: Brotherhood. Really good anime, there is no other way to describe it. A must have for newcomers to anime and hardened otakus.

The story of FMA:B is just brilliant. It follows two storyline routes; the first one is the supernatural route, which include everything about alchemy and its magic!!! 
The second route is the military aspect of the show which is amazing too.
The main protagonists mostly deal with the problems in the alchemy section but a lot of good characters are in the military part of the story (Hint: King Bradly).
The artwork was great and the soundtrack is just beautiful!!
One thing I didn't like is Winry's part of the story, she is so annoying and adds nothing to the story in my opinion, even the little story
                  about her parents and Scar didn't seem to have any meaning or importance to the overall story.
At the end, till this day nothing I have watched beats FMA: Brotherhood, maybe Bioshock games if just they were an anime.

Everything about this anime is amazing. I watched the original FMA and absolutely loved it, I had no knowledge of the manga, and was just watching it for the pleasure of it, not the manga or something else.  FMA was hands down the best anime I had ever seen, up there with Cowboy Bebop and the like.  I didn't pirate it, I purchased the DVD sets because they were so good that they sure as hell deserved my money for the great work they did.  I started out watching Brotherhood with the preconception that the differences were "Brotherhood is more lighthearted" and
                  "Brotherhood splits off in story at episode 14".  Those were my only preconceptions.  I'll admit, the first 10 or so episodes had wayyyy more anime faces and sillyness than I'd ever seen in FMA before, but I got used to it, because I was persistent in the fact that it had a completely different take on the FMA universe and I really wanted to experience it again.  Once it hit around episode 20, it started getting darker and more brutal, like the old FMA, which was something I preferred.  The character development and background stories were SOOOOO detailed and fleshed out that I was blown away at how much of the characters I didn't understand or know before.  There were just so many incredible details and little tidbits that I NEVER knew and it just blew me away to hear it and wonder why I never heard it or was aware of it before.  The story was amazing, it was so twist-y, addicting, and cliffhanger-y.  This is the most addicting show I've ever watched, I sat down and watched 12 episodes one day.  That's 12 x 20 minutes = 240 minutes of Brotherhood straight in ONE sitting.  I've never been so enthralled and involved in any anime or visual entertainment of ANY kind.  I don't want to write a wall of text, because I could, but FMAB takes the awesome FMA series (which I didn't think could get any better), improves absolutely EVERYTHING, and blows the doors off of any anime I've ever seen in my entire life.  To quote what I said to one of my best friends about the anime after finishing it: "I can wholeheartedly say it is honestly the best thing I've ever seen in any art form or medium of entertainment in my entire life ever."  It's a bold f***ing statement, but I've never been so taken by anything like Brotherhood.

One is all and all is one. equivalent exchange. war and peace. the seven sins. God and truth. all of these alchemic and philosophical concepts are applicable to daily life and are depicted here. An anime without a single flaw imo. Incredible buildup to an epic conclusion where everything and everyone is connected. The character development of every character is truly phenomenal.
It’s a quintessential story about humanity.
I see now why it's heralded as the best anime in the last two decades. I'd recommend it to anyone who wants to check anime out. Don't miss it!! Watch it!! I can't highly recommend it enough.

NO SPOILER REVIEW
Here is a review coming from a young audience, not affected by nostalgia that typically prefers modern anime over old ones. 
To keep things short, my overall opinion after seeing this anime is that it's good, but, I do not appreciate the fact that the build-up was very long and that it wasn't that good. The pacing killed me halfway through, nearly falling asleep. The reason this anime is so appreciated is because it is long and complex. There were plenty of episodes to build a world from scratch. There were a lot of details and the anime payed attention to them. There
                  are a lot of characters meant to represent your average people, that slowly appear into the life of two people, thus making them grow. But these people I'm talking in fact were very boring to watch. The interesting parts came in sets, separated by 10ish episode gaps.
I do appreciate it not being your average shonen, the MC is not powerful at all and the struggle is very hard. The MC grows in power from experience and from nothing else. The anime successfully gives you the feeling of a loss but 
I absolutely disliked the music of this anime because it is old. Can't complain too much, it was made in 2009, however in this review I'm sharing my impression. The animation wasn't that good either, the transitions between frames was slow, fights lack the punch (being nothing to what Shippuden offered for example).
The anime starts low, gets really interesting for a few episodes (20-25 I believe), then falls into that slow pacing up until the last 10 episodes being the climax. 
I don't think this anime deserves this spot on this site. It's ratings are way too high, I'm not saying it's bad but it's overrated. People got too emotionally affected by the ending (which indeed is really good) but forgot how boring it was to get there. There are also a lot of people affected by nostalgia or just old school FMA fans that were proud to see a remake of the original series.
STORY: 10/10
The story is amazing. Complex, a lot of plot twists, a lot of things make sense and it feels realistic (in a way of reality mixing with fantasy, not just pure fantasy). There was a lot of room for chaos and it was a long and hard ride. A lot of amazing details were shown in this anime, something the new ones fail to deliver. I don't think there is anybody in this world that won't enjoy this story.
ART: 8/10
It is an older anime but I still didn't get their art style at all. The eyes are poorly placed, most are too big, and some character's hair are just...yikes. Now I'm reviewing the anime, not the art style chosen by the manga writer, however the anime was supposed to make them a bit more pleasant to watch. I think they did an OK job overall.
SOUND: 7/10
The music has to be the shittiest part of this anime. There is a cycle of sounds played depending on the arc, the problem is it's very very very very repetitive. And it doesn't move you at all. It's just that music you find in old movies overused in most scenarios that try to move your soul a bit but they make you cringe. That's how it is. You'll get to a point where you'll be able to predict what song will come according to the scene.
CHARACTER: 9/10
I liked most characters because they covered the typical types of people you find around you. They were made realistically. None of them spit shit out of their mouths. You'll relate to what most normal humans would say. About their behavior, the main 2 protagonists start from scratch and although they don't suddenly get stronger they do change their decision making and perspective as time passes, this is the process of growing up. The supporting characters overall are good but there are some that simply make you wanna punch them, being good and suddenly becoming bad just to "shake things" up. 
ENJOYMENT: 8/10
In the "interesting" parts I just couldn't stop watching but in the build up episodes they simply made me drowsy or made me wanna check my phone just to change the panorama a bit. I had mixed feelings overall.
OVERALL: 8/10
It is a good anime and I cannot deny it, but again, I do not and I will never really see it as the number #1 anime rated by this site. IMO there are better anime out there worth this spot.

I just finished the series and it was quite good but as you can probably tell from my rating this review isn't going to be all praises. 
I'll start with the comedy. Don't get me wrong, I also giggle at comedic relief when done right but they used dumb humour so repetitively during the first 10 episodes I almost quit watching. It's a shame because these earlier episodes usually had serious philosophical undertones but the show kept bailing out with jokes and those godawful animation switches. Given the story's dark and serious nature, the humor just felt out of place. It seemed like the show
                  doesn't take itself seriously and isn't worth my time but I endured for a few more episodes and I'm glad I did.
As the story progressed the brat MC became less bratty and the cute armor-clad brother didn't bring up his foodlist as often. But more importantly they got less screen time! Soon it was apparent that this isn't just a show about two brothers but something bigger. With the spotlight being shared more and more by various side characters, the show revealed its strength.
It took only 46 episodes to create a living, immersive world with a ridiculous amount of characters I'm heavily invested in. I enjoyed the pacing of the conspiracy reveal and I found myself breezing through the episodes. As I learned more about the rough FMA:B world, I also began to appreciate the brothers' childish behaviour and their struggle.
Other than that, the action scenes were well done throughout the show and only got better during the final act. I didn't love or hate the soundtrack, I thought it was mediocre (except Trisha's Lullaby <3). The animation was impressive for the most part but I wasn't a fan of the switches to "chibi". 
Overall, I think FMA:B is very good (8) but not the masterpiece it's made out to be. If you decide to watch it don't quit early, it gets better!

Story: Edward and Alphonse Elric's careless behavior towards the fundamental's of Alchemy law, have ripped away at Edward's limbs and Left Al's soul being sealed into a cold suit of armor.  To get back what was lost, the brother's look through a war-torn land for the philosopher's stone, A fabled relic which grants the ability to perform alchemy in impossible way's. 
Animation: The animation was perfect! Then again, what else would you expect from Aniplex? The same studio that animated title's such as Demonslayer, Fate/Stay Night, and Angel Beats! Aniplex is a powerhouse when it comes to the production of not only anime, but
                  Music and Anime merch as well. It's no wonder at times, their limited edition boxsets are priced at ridiculous prices, but That's to be expected. 
Intro/Outro: The Intro/Outro tracks are forever remember by anime fans around the world, as everything about the Intros and Outros were amazing! " Again " by Yui, " Rain " by Sid and Let's not forget the Outro's like " Uso " by Sid, " Tsunai Da Te " by Lil'B are all amazing! From Metal to Rock, and Rap, FMAB has it all and The animation done within the Intros and Outros, compliment the animation within the anime as well. 
Character Development: Character development is done correctly within this anime, as it followed on the manga path compared to the 2003 Iteration of FMA, as it did not. Everything about the character's felt correct and Nothing was changed, as it was all original to the manga.  
Personal Enjoyment: I enjoyed watching FMAB to the point I've seen it four or five times already and I can still watch it over and over again, which may sound crazy, but To understand this masterpiece, you would literally have to see the difference between FMA and FMAB, there are even fans still fighting about which is better to this very day and It just goes to show you how popular this anime series was. I once use to think DBZ was the best anime of all time, but As I grew away from the casual aspect of anime and Became more knowledgeable of anime and It's overall production I had decided by that time, that FMAB was better than DBZ.   
Overall Score: The overall score for Fullmetal Alchemist: Brotherhood? 10/10 - PERFECTION!!!!!
Final Verdict: Fullmetal Alchemist Brotherhood will always remain a staple in anime history and Will always be considered The GOAT of Anime aka Greatest Anime of All Time! The animation, The amazing Intro's/Outro's, The character development, and Overall enjoyment I got from this anime is just another reason why I can make this statement and I'm pretty sure all of MAL aka My Anime List would agree with me.
