Now I’m not a fanboy of the franchise by any means. I never read the manga or saw the first adaptation. All I did was watch this show. It’s no “masterpiece” but it is still VERY good.
Story [9/10]: The story was by far this show’s biggest high point (and the most important thing by far when rating an anime). The storytelling was properly paced, dynamic, and complex enough to satisfy everyone. There were many twists and surprising reveals along the way, but not too many where it becomes confusing and annoying.
Art [4/10]: The animation gets the job done... that’s it. The characters, settings, special effects,
                  and backdrops are bland in design, but are also crisp and well-animated. Visuals clearly weren’t on high priority.
Sound [6/10]: Voices and SFX were amongst the best of the best in terms of audio quality, but no cool sound effects to be found. Music leaves much to be desired, and in some instances causes the show to be dead silent.
Character [6/10]: The characters didn’t really feel too engaging. Most of them were just your by-the-numbers anime tropes. Nothing else to say here.
Enjoyment [10/10]: I really enjoyed watching this show. It’s storytelling kept me engaged and coming back for more. I’m sure you will enjoy this show as well.
Overall [7/10]: When the story is the show’s only high point, I struggle to give this show any more than a 7. I really like this show and I truly recommend it. I just don’t find any other aspect good enough to bump the score up any higher.

FMAB holds up to its reputation as one of the greatest animes of all time, but I do not regard it as a masterpiece. It is a well-balanced series that does almost everything right, from animation and story character writing, yet excels at none. It has a tight story with deep philosophies woven in, and features lovable characters, some of whom are incredibly complex. The animation is smooth, and the fights are well executed. However, FMAB does not necessarily break any new ground, although to be fair, most anime series doesn't. It is quite difficult for an anime series to be called "masterpiece," since most
                  of the more influential directors direct animated movies.  
Compare this to Neon Genesis Evangelion, a highly acclaimed series that is the touchstone of anime. Evangelion is highly flawed, especially when it comes to the controversial last two episodes, but it is a masterpiece for its original and daring visual artistry. Evangelion is a good example of Japan's avant-garde genre, and even though not as many people can appreciate it, once you have entered the world Anno built, you cannot escape. Your mind is reined in by the symbolism woven in, and you feel the need to rewatch it over and over to understand the message the director is trying to send. 
I am not trying to promote Evangelion. I am merely using it as a reference point, and to juxtapose FMAB with it to explain why I do not give this incredibly entertaining show a 10, as many MALs users do. I truly enjoyed it, however. 10/10 enjoyment. FMAB certainly is a classic that anime fans can enjoy even 10 years from now.

Superb superb and even more superb
I’ll begin with its flaws first....
Right, now that’s over with i can continue with everything that’s great.  Firstly the characters. Expertly delivered character development which goes way beyond the main characters.  Even the sub sub sub main characters develop throughout.  Furthermore, the subtlety in which they develop is excellent.  I also don’t think I have watched an anime with such a thoroughly engaging cast, pretty much everyone you enjoy watching which each of them drawing you into their small piece of this magnificent story.  
Secondly the animation. From the very beginning a smooth and colourful
                  style hits you. There no waiting around. It get down to business right  away. The colour palette is warm and vibrant, even within the first scene at night.  These brilliantly animated fight scenes don’t continue in the same vein however.....they get better. With every scene they seem to improve, that coupled with the excellent characters partaking in them make for wonderfully enjoyable fighting.
Finally, the magnificent story. With every passing episode the story builds a little more, all the way trough to the very final episode. The reveals come early and are very frequent. There will be times where a big reveal will hit you, you take a step back, look at the episode count, see you are still in the teens and wonder how the hell they will top it in the episodes that  remain. Well let me tell you they do. The reveals get bigger and more impactful all the way to the penultimate episode. This story has to be, quite possibly, one of, if not the best story ever told in anime. The pacing is second to none, the characters are brilliant, the engagement is unrivalled and more importantly, is even better than the hype!
All in all I believe this to be one of the beat anime’s you will see. I would be very interested to chat with someone who thought on the contrary.  I honestly could watch it again immediately. Top 5 maybe even top 3 anime. Watch it, you won’t regret it.

Spoilers Included
Story-The plot is about a pair of  boys,Edward Elric the FullMetal alchemist and his brother Al Elric, who venture out to the world in hoping of finding the key to restoring their bodies back to normal after losing them in a result of failed human transmutation.This is the best part about the anime,the crazy plot itself. It is very original and unique.Always being unpredictable,always catching you off guard with the plot twists and revealations,always making you think.Also the pacing is godly,not even the fights slow the plot down.Not to mention zero filler in existence and the ending is a god send.no complaints here.(10/10)
Art-The
                  art's pretty good and the animation is even better.It can just be really inconsistent at times like the character models,their faces for example.Animation never fails to impress.The  fights are also short,always interesting to watch,they,never feel dragged on characters like Mustang and Bradley often get the best animation strapped to their fights.The artwork usually changes when a gag scene is on screen.I recommend watching this in blu ray as well to see the art at it's highest quality,just can be inconsistent at times but in spite of that,i don't care,it's a 9.(9/10)
Sound- Sound is good between great.I'm a bit mixed with some of the new openings and endings and alot prefer the 2003's fma over them though I do favor openings 2,4, and 5 and endings 4 and 5.The ost is really good and really help convey the mood being on screen,though it can be unfitting at times,though at least they're played and stopped at the right times though alot of it is really fitting for the action scenes and gets better the farther you watched into the anime.Also,the voice acting for the dub is superb,all of funimation's voices really suit their characters persona and are well acted,no complains there. The dub Voices earn  itself a 10 while the ost,ops and endings get a 8.(8/10)
Characters-My favorite aspect about the show besides the story.The characters.lots of good ones here,even the minor ones.Your bound to find one to latch on to and we see a lot of them develope.
We get all sorts characters here like the military amestrians, the Ishvalans, and theXingese,The military amestrains are by far my favorite group of characters to watch on screen,many of whom wear the same uniform but have very distinctive personalities between them but that doesn't make the ishvalans and xingese characters any less interesting. The villains are based on the 7 deadly sins.speaking of protagonist,Edward Elric is a great one,I never get bored watching him on screenMy personal favorite crackers are Roy Mustang, he's the ambitious,arogant, snide, and manipulating Type ,the infatuation family obsessed loving realist Maes Hughes,cold,loyal and stoic Riza Hawkeye,and Greed.Really the best part about the show next to the story,not as single one feels bad or a waste of space,they all felt important to the story (10/10)
Overall-I enjoyed the anime all around from start to end except maybe the first select few(first 13 episodes,after that it was great),after that it comes the most enjoyable shounen to me,really strong unforgettable anime with lots of message. I recommend this show to new comers and veterans alike,there really is something for everyone here for all demographics,if not then most.even if you don't initially get attached to the show's character and plot,you should watched and experience this anime at least once.Totally worth all the praise and attention it gets. (10/10)

The premise of this anime and the hype surrounding it were all but a hullabaloo. It never managed to rub off its 'supposed invincibility' on me. Sure, Alchemy is such an interesting subject to tackle but this show never managed to flesh out everything that its promise held. Naruto's chakra system's even more creative when it comes to power scaling and overall execution. The characters also look cartoonish and most of them are just borderline caricatures. I remember struggling just to finish watching all 64 episodes as it felt like sitting out a meeting when it could have just been an email. It's too predictable
                  that you can never get excited for the next episode or for what's to happen later. Respect to the author though for making her work shine in a male-dominated industry. No matter how the anime adaptation turned out, her story's still one of those tales you can't miss for the world.

as per usual when i am extremely overworked and pulled so many all nighters in a row that i no longer wish to exist i want to roast something. today i will roast one of the most hyped mainstream shounen battles of all time, FMA in da hood straight outta compton.
my thoughts overall can be expressed shortly as: entertaining enough that i didn't start spacing out and daydreaming for 5 minutes before realizing that i have to rewind.
i kind of want to compare it to d.gray man. i'd like to think this is what d.gray man would have looked like if the author actually used
                  the ideas and setting in an interesting way instead of making it into a one pattern snorefest.
so it is about two brothers who do alchemy. their mom dies, they try to revive her and end up losing bodyparts/whole body. they then start working for the corrupt military, responsible for some genocidal war, and it turns out the ones pulling all the strings in these wars are artificial humans, called homosexomonculus or something, and of which the original homo-thing was created from, we don't get to know, only that van homoheim added his blood to it. the original homonculous has very vague, if any at all, motives for his creating of philosophers stones by destroying nations. as far as i know none of this is explained and it is thus hard to take seriously, he only blabbers on about "oh silly humans how pitiful they are blablabla insert generic grumpy old man muttering".
give him some warm milk and an alt-right newspaper subscription and send the bastard to the retirement home i say.
if your mind isn't boggled by above it is pretty great. well structured, the pacing is top notch. quality entertainment
TL;DR artificial human/homo-thing wants to destroy/consume god by gathering philosophers stones by destroying nations and killing all of its inhabitants, for reasons unknown.

Definitely THE anime of its decade. A must-see for every anime fans out there. FMAB certainly set the standard high for succeeding animes.
Everything about this series is beautiful, from the creative and emotional storyline, the smooth animation, the brilliant music and sound edit to the complex, badass and likeable characters. What stands out to me the most about FMAB is its line-up of amazing female characters that other shounens can only wish they could create. FMAB is proof that you don't need to make a female character a protagonist to make her memorable. I am happy that for once a shounen doesn't provide fanservice using
                  its female characters by making them wear scanty, revealing clothing or act cute. 
But of course that's not all distinctive about FMAB. The poignant story about the two brothers on a quest to retrieve their body after a botched alchemical experiment is already an interesting enough of a premise, but as the story progresses, viewers soon realize there is more than meets the eye. The two protagonists soon uncover a conspiracy involving high-ranking officials that threatens to engulf the whole country. The brothers' journey is not only a journey to retrieve their bodies but also to save the country while reflecting upon themselves, what alchemy means, what life entails, and what the truth is. The brilliant philosophy of self,  humanity, truth, and universe is smartly woven into the story, giving the viewers not only a roller coaster ride of action and plot twists but also time and emotional break to ponder about life and ourselves.
The only flaw that I have with FMAB is the pacing in the first few episodes, which is a little too fast. We do not have enough time to become attached to a character whose role becomes pretty important as she is serves as a wake-up call for the two protagonists about the evils of alchemy, and also the impetus for Edward's decision at the end of the series.
Anyway, this series is a masterpiece. 10/10. If there is any anime of this decade that I deem capable of toppling FMAB, it is Shingeki No Kyojin.

9/10 overall for me
I've watched this anime over 5 times already. It's easy to watch, or listen to. The story is very entertaining, and captivating at parts. I definitely developed a slight sense of attachment to the characters, and it was awesome to see how much they grow throughout the series. 
What I enjoyed the least, is how annoying Ed seemed at first. But they balanced it out with his brother being the calm one. However they made his personality match pretty well with how people around him treated him, and reacted to him. 
He also gets less annoying later on, as they show him
                  growing.

I really loved this anime. I loved the original version too. They're very different stories after the first few episodes so if you're planning on watching either, I'd recommend you see both. 
The original Fullmetal Alchemist is much darker and quite slowly paced at times, but the characters are developed superbly, and you have sympathy for the villains which is always a good thing in my opinion :) The ending fits well with the tone of the series although a lot of people were unhappy about it, but the movie sequel helps somewhat.
Brotherhood, on the other hand, has a much more fast moving plot and
                  tighter storyline. The characters aren't as well developed, but there are much more characters in this series (some, like General Armstrong, are totally badass, others, like the chimeras whose names I can't remember, kinda blend into the scenery but are still kinda cool). The ending is also much happier and more satisfying in this series :)
So if you like something dark with lots of character development, watch the original. If you like a more shonen feel and a slightly tighter, more fast-paced plot, watch Brotherhood. Both are excellent animes and both are worth watching :D

Comparing this to the manga, I was very dissapointed. 
Everything moved too quickly... I understand that they skipped a few parts of the manga that were already shown in the first anime, but other parts that were never showed in the first anime, completely disappeared. :(. I was frustrated that they didn't stick to the manga 100%, which was what I thoght they would do.
But the animation, music, and everything else was great,xD. And although it's kinda dissapointing, FMA Brotherhood is still awesome. Same with every other version they would make of it.xD

While searching on what to watch next, I saw in numerous forums many people agree that FMA:B was one of the best anime without fighting too much about it. So what anime could have such an impact? That's how I started my journey into this masterpiece.
Story:
It really follows closely the manga. Some initial details are left out in the first episodes, mainly cause FMA had already an anime adaptation that went through that stuff. The pacing is great and whatever question you have about the plot is answered. The transition between the brothers' journey to getting back their bodies, discovering a dangerous secret and then
                  fighting not only for their lives but for a whole country was really smooth to me. It deals with many things like "Is it ethical to search for eternal life and how to resurrect people?", "A war is justified just from having a single person die from an enemy?", "What is the truth behind everything?". The sure thing is that the story will get stuck to your mind.
Art:
I'm no animator or artist but the art is so nice and easy to the eye. The fight scenes were great from the coloring to the pace. Also I was very happy that the comedy parts were as cute as in the manga. Studio Bones did an amazing job with keeping Arakawa's art intact.
Sound:
FMA:B has a suberb OST from Akira Senju, wholly orchestrated and also some of the greatest OP's in all of anime. You'll be singing "Again" like crazy. Guaranteed.
Character:
In all the anime I've watched I still haven't seen a number of so many characters so fleshed out. All the people we watch have a beginning, a middle point that influences them and an ending that fits every single one perfectly. Male and female characters don't fall under stereotypes. Men aren't all powerful and we feel that they are aware of their weaknesses and women aren't crying little girls, they are more dynamic and know when to take action. You won't find a character that dosen't deserve your love (or hate).
Enjoyment:
I'll just say that I've rewatched the series 4 times. I absolutely love it. I have bought all the manga volumes too. For me there's no other anime like FMA:B. It has that special something that lures me back to its' world.
Overall:
It is, and will always be, a masterpiece to me. I can't recommend it enough to the people who ask about it. Of course for some people it might not be that amazing as they thought, but I believe that everyone who will watch it will agree in one thing: 
Fullmetal Alchemist Brotherhood is a story that you must experience even once in your life, even if you are not fond of anime.

I really enjoyed the anime and think it's good. I was impressed with how it tricked me many times and always made sense. It was enjoyable but not enjoyable enough to be in my top 10 or something like that, and I see I don't enjoy it as much as most people. Still, really good anime.
The story was all connected and well built. It's impossible to say anything that happens, even the most minor detail, without spoiling so much, which might be why I barely ever see people talking about this anime. 
Some of the best opening songs were used, Rain being one of my
                  favourites of all time. USO, the first ending, was also really nice. The soundtracks also complimented the events very well.
My favourite characters are Ling and Hohenheim, and overall I really loved the characters. I was sad that Scar wasn't as good in my opinion as he is in FullMetal Alchemist though.
Final Score: 8/10

I actually never had a thought of watching this anime but when i got to know that this is the most high rated anime on imdb i had a curosity to check, is it actually good has people rated it, did it deserve the spot and omg when i finished i thought wish it had some more episodes u can barely hate any charcters had well written villans a mc with no demon inside him shit the mc didnt even got any power up but still his charcters was good asf it also shows that not everytime u need a overpowered mc to make an

[POSSIBLE SPOILERS]
Fullmetal Alchemist Brotherhood is undoubtedly one of the best shonen anime.
Story
The story starts off when the main character Edward Elric and Alphonse Elric wanted to resurrect their deceased mother but since the human transmutation backfired, it costed Edward's leg and Alphonse's body. Edward realised that he made a huge mistake so he made a deal with The Truth (God of transmutation) to big
                  back his brother Alphonse and that costed his arm. The story then continues when Edward burns down the house that him and his brother lived in so that they cannot turn back and are forced on the journey to get their original bodies back. They joined the military to accomplish their goals but not to participate in brutal, genocidal campaigns to generate a Philosophers Stone from the people they killed. Of course, the military get complicated throughout the series as it gets corrupted by evil immortal devils using Philosophers Stone to create an immortal army of alien-like creatures. The story overall is interesting and written well throughout the series. 
10/10
Art
The general art and animation for an anime adaptation from 2009 is impressive, it has high definition and high framed action scenes with simple colours palette used to light up the world. The simplistic colour palette gives the look of the early 1900s matching the general theme of the show.
9/10
Characters
Fullmetal Alchemist Brotherhood introduced many side and minor characters are in the show in a steady pace. All the characters have depth and a reason why they exist in the show especially the main characters. The main characters changed a lot from the start like how childish Edward was eagerly trying to bring back his brother till the end when he realised the truth about the military and prioritised others lives over their own body.
10/10
Enjoyment + Overall
I surprisingly enjoyed it despite the fact that I almost dropped the show. The show started off really slow paced because it developed the general background information of how alchemy worked prior the development of the main characters. It was a smart way to engage me more into the characters with a little background knowledge of what is alchemy. The show used its slow paced story to foreshadow future events and introduce new characters and give them depth. Overall, the anime is both extremely enjoyable and well written in every aspect of the show.
8/10
                                 [HIGHLY RECOMMENDED SHOW]

Fullmetal Alchemist; Brotherhood was a series I picked up because of its raving reviews. Of course, I had to watch the show rated no. 1 on MAL, and boy am I glad that I did. In this review, I'll sum up how I fell in love with the show and its characters, and how FMAB sauntered its way into my no.2 spot of favorite animes of all time.
disclaimer : slightttttt spoilers, nothing major at all
Skip to the end for a shorter review summary :)
---
To start off with the art and sound, I thought the animation was very well done and the Japanese VA was done
                  perfectly. Both the animations and the VA captured each character so well and because of it the show ran so so SO smoothly. I definitely appreciated the effort that went into the animation and both of these factors made the show run at its full capacity.
---
The characters are AMAZING. Like I'm not joking, AMAZING. The character development was so well thought out and executed that as a viewer I was able to see all sides of EVERY character, including the damn mini-panda-cat that May had. Like the mini-panda-cat had a backstory, like WHAT?
Ed and Al are the dynamic duo we all know and love, yet we don't deserve them at all. As the plot progressed you could see their personalities and relationship grow and change, and their dedication to each other as brothers was so fulfilling to watch.
As for my other favorite characters, Ling/Greed, Scar, Mustang, and Olivier, they all had great character developments of their own and the show made it clear that Ed and Al weren't the only characters we should be focusing on because all the others had their own qualities that drew us to them.
I will say that some characters were a bit lacking, or at least I wanted to see a bit more of them, including Lan Fan, Fu, May, and the three guys that could turn into the lion, frog, and alligator ( i think, I forgot their names ). I didn't see as much of them as I wanted, and I honestly forgot about them in the last couple of episodes.
---
And for the plot, nothing short of amazing as well. Definitely original, definitely had me thinking, and definitely offered up existential questions for the viewer to answer for themselves. The situations each character was put in spoke to us as viewers, as their opposing views in the show reflected our own struggle to pick what's "right and wrong" in a given situation. 
The ending of FMAB was 10/10 to me, and I saw everything that I wanted to, and yes I was brought to tears when Winry, Al. and Ed finally reunited at the end. And let's not talk about the battle that came before that, because that's something you're going to have to experience for yourself.
---
You see I don't think anyone will understand how good this series is until you give it a watch. It had me laughing, crying, stressed out, melting from ed's cuteness, and so much more. I'd say the plot is what made the show amazing, but in reality, its the loveable characters that resonate with us. 
I said it before, but there's a reason why FMAB is rated no. 1 on MAL, and whatever high expectations you have for this series, it goes above and beyond it.

It's one of the last animes I watched with my little brother. It holds a special place in my heart.

The story is just insanely good. It shows you how much does it take to bring back the dead, and it fails. Nobody can bring the dead back to life. Not even the best alchemist in the world! It's seriously good. I was wanting more after the series was over, it's that good!

The overall 
Watch this anime if you haven't already. It's so good. Try it if you don't even like anime. It's that good!

The best anime I've ever watched. My #1 favourite anime when I was a teenager, and now, almost 10 years later, it still is.
Story: A perfect mix of action, tragedy, thriller, fantasy, and a dash of romance. The main story started off so simple - two brothers looking for a magic stone in order to restore their bodies - but over time grew complex without ever becoming confusing. The plot progression was just right, with the perfect pacing and perfect amount of details that went into each significant part of the plot.
Art: Great animation, great art work from Hiromu Arakawa. This anime has a lot
                  of action scenes, and everything went as smoothly as could be.
Sound: All of the opening and ending themes are amazing (for some reasons they fit the current plot perfectly). The soundtrack, bless Senju Akira, is stunning and clearly deserves its own praise. So many different BGMs for so many different scenes. It was never a dull moment.
Character: A myriad of characters, either good or evil or something in between. They were all excellently written and described, and each of them serves an unforgettable part in the story of Fullmetal Alchemist: Brotherhood as a whole.
Overall, this is possibly the one title I would recommend to someone who has never watched or liked anime. For me, it's perfect all over. Most of the anime I enjoyed during my teenage years I have grown to dislike (or found cringeworthy) when I rewatch it nowadays. Today, December 20th me attested that Fullmetal Alchemist: Brotherhood is still the masterpiece I watched and loved. If you haven't watched it already, by all means, give it a try. You will not regret it.

I just finished FMAB and I have to say it was so well made. Most of the character was flushed out and had their backstories and goals. The world building was so vast and expansive you can do a whole analysis on that such as the cultures, people, beliefs, and nations. The themes Fullmetal explored was also fantastic such as war, man's inhumanity to man , personal struggle the characters faced, and understanding morality. The author of Fullmetal really put a lot of effort into making Fullmetal. The art, animation, and music was a big plus for this anime also. The comedy in this anime
                  was well done and funny as hell, the funniest anime I have ever watched. The tone and the vibe was very nice also, at times it would get dark but I would be lifted by the comedy. But at times they mixed the comedy with the fights which was suppose to be serious and dark. The story was well done and nothing seemed out of place or didn't make sense.
The fights were confusing at times, half the time in the fights the good guys and bad guys were talking too each other way too much and other times they wont even talk and just start fighting. Another things is the pacing, I felt like the creators should have done a better job on shedding Ed's and Al's younger years and their troubles when they first joined the military and also the other characters also. My last problem was the consistency such as keeping the same music people enjoy alot to become a nostalgia for example keeping the same opening instead of it changing every time. And also doing a better job of making the audience care for the characters by doing a better job on the emotional scenes, their origins, and their dialogue.
So overall I enjoyed the show, it wasn't a masterpiece to say oh I will remember this show for the rest of my life, or bad to say that I'm never going to watch this show again . FMAB put a lot of passion into the visuals, story, and music which was a big plus because I enjoyed those aspects alot. But I think they could have done a better job in certain scenes and could have made the characters even more interesting and memorable then where they are right now.

to the point that the main villain can be sympathized with the story is immersive and so re watchable the art is beautiful AND THE OPS HOLY SHIT THE OPS ARE AMAZING my personal favorites are 1 and 4, the best part of the anime though has to be the character building and reveals plus those stunning ops overwall the best damn anime ever dont @me like i said so uh yeah bye :)

The art of the adaptation is, as any other, a colossal mountain to scale. To reach the summit, nothing short of mastery is necessary. Though, it must be said, there is no shame in climbing most of your way to the top and deciding to call it quits. Either because that final stretch seems impossible to clear, or to make it this far was your goal from the start. This is where many adaptations place their white flags and wave to the rest of the world. In anime, this is where many mildly successful manga adaptations meet their end: good enough. It is rare to
                  see one soar to the top, and even beyond. And even rarer to see two. Of the same work? Now, that's a true treasure, right there. You see where I'm going with this, don't you?
Spend enough time in the community, and surely the name Fullmetal Alchemist will have been shouted from the rooftops a thousand times, at least. In this day and age, who hasn't heard of it, right? Those who have done a little homework will have realised there are actually two separate anime adaptations with that name: a 2003 one and a 2009 one. Okay, easy enough to understand. Which one do you watch? And therein lies the bigger problem. Well, in this review, I'll be taking a look at the 2009 one, Fullmetal Alchemist: Brotherhood, and how it fares in comparison to its elder brother. 
By now, it's a given that almost everyone will have a general understanding of the basic premise of the series: two brothers, in an effort to bring their mother back from the beyond, perform an experiment that goes horribly wrong, and so begins their journey to try to find a solution to their predicament. 
The narrative of Brotherhood is tightly-written, and quite consistent in delivery. It appears to have been a well-planned story with ideas and concepts being developed from beginning to end with seldom a pitfall. There are no stooping lows to the curve, and occasionally it peaks during moments of electric excitement. Arakawa-sensei, the mangaka, has carefully crafted a philosophical epic  which manages to seamlessly weave thought-provoking themes and high-octane action. From Plato to Nietzsche, it is clear that the work has taken a page out of some of the most influential philosophical texts ever written, and somehow combined it with its own brand of slapstick comedy and adrenaline-fuelled fights. And the ending achieves a degree of catharsis that few stories ever do. That said, this adaptation, and even the original source material, is unabashedly Shōnen in nature, more so than the 2003 anime. Overall, the tone of the series is significantly lighter and warmer in contrast to the tragedy-loving 2003 adaptation, despite the underbelly of darkness lurking throughout both. Moreover, for some viewers, the first fourteen episodes will appear to be incredibly rushed or paced rather poorly in comparison to the remainder of the show, and some speculate that this was a conscious decision, to speed through the parts already covered by the 2003 adaptation. Whether or not that is true, I cannot say.
Brotherhood has a much larger ensemble than its predecessor, but manages to develop the major players as well as the original. Nobody is perfect, and the story does well to highlight the flaws in each and every single character, including our beloved protagonists and heroes. Many of the antagonists act as interesting and memorable foils for our heroes and will be remembered for years to come. While some may argue that the 'Big Bad' wasn't really all that much, in my opinion, they were actually a fantastic antithesis to Edward. The 2003 anime on the other had a much smaller cast, but as a result allowed a deeper look into many characters who were not as prominent in the manga or 2009 anime. 
So, reader, should you watch the 2003 anime or Brotherhood? Easiest answer: watch both of them, and if you end up liking them, check out the manga! On the other hand, for those of you who want to make a concrete decision, then it is better to see them for what they are. They are different shows. The 2003 anime is a dark, character-piece which delves into the lives and tragedies of our main characters as they realise the truth of their world. Brotherhood is the epic journey of two brothers and their friends as they uncover the truth behind their world on the path to redemption. 
And with that, I bid you adieu.

Well now.  I've now seen this one.  I don't know if there's anything I can say that hasn't already been said much better by other people, but here we go.
Pros:
- Probably the greatest story ever told in anime.  The calmer moments, the action scenes, and even the backstory moments do nothing except aid the story resulting in one of the greatest climaxes and conclusions I've seen maybe ever.
- Amazingly fleshed out characters which the audience is able to relate with you watch them on this massive, epic, journey.
- Villains are written great as unlike a lot of shows/movies/etc. they pose an actual
                  threat.  There are no OP protagonists here.  Each character is given very believable strengths and weakness that make the action scenes that much more entertaining and awesome.
- Japanese voice actors do a flawless job for these characters (especially Edward).
- Soundtrack is great.  It feels very cinematic and huge which is perfect for this anime which also feels very cinematic and huge.
- Animation looks quite good also.  The final 10 or 15 episodes especially stand out in my memory as having very good art and animation quality.
- Some interesting ideas thrown around regarding the place and purpose of government in society.  There's actually quite intelligent commentary throughout about how a country can disservice it's people simply by being overpowered and lacking transparency and mutual trust with its citizens.
- Without giving anything away (although I'm sure most of you know by now what I'm referring to) Thanks a lot episode 4, you now have the distinction of being the first anime episode that was so screwed up that I had to take a break from this series altogether.
Cons:
- Not really a legitimate criticism, but this series suffers from a serious case of sakuga.
- While I do think such a grand-scaled story deserved to have tons of characters in it, I do think that maybe there were possibly a bit too many characters (mostly minor ones).  Often there'd be characters that were introduced in a couple episodes and served a purpose for that arc, and then about 20 or 30 episodes later they'd show up out of the blue after I'd forgotten about what purpose they served earlier.  Kind of a minor nitpick, and one that's mostly due to the fact that midway I took an extended break from it, but I still think it is something that needs addressing.
Overview:
The best way I can describe this anime is that it's sort of like a Japanese, steampunk version of Lord Of The Rings.  Similar to Lord Of The Rings it is a massive story that needs to be visited at least once in your life.  So much goes on throughout the course of this 64 episode series that the only way they could have done it true justice is by adding 64 more episodes.  For what we got, though, it still manages to captivate the audience and engage it in the journey of these heroes whose quest descends deeper and deeper into hidden, undesired, truths taking their journey in many different directions.  This is truly one of the most fascinating epics I've encountered, and I highly recommend it if you are looking for a fantastic fantasy adventure that is intelligent and adult it nature while also being very accessible and not overwhelmingly complex.  An absolute recommendation.  See it now if you haven't already.

Oh. My. Goodness. At first, I was hesitant to watch Fullmetal Alchemist: Brotherhood since I don't typically love watching Shounen anime but I figured that since this was the highest rated anime of all time on MAL, I'd give it a shot. And in my opinion, it definitely lived up to its hype.
What first drew me in to FMAB was the first opening, Again by Yui. Even knowing that it had such a high rating on MAL, I still didn't really want to watch it. But after hearing Again, my mind switched to "I have to watch it-- for the opening." And after watching that
                  first episode, I was drawn in immediately by the plot line, wanting to figure out the story, the humor, everything just fit well together and made for an amazing first episode.
The characters grew dear to me over the span of these 64 episodes. I cried with them, screamed, laughed. There's a perfect blend of adventure and seriousness which is balanced out with some humor but not overly cheesy or overdone. Given that it's a much longer anime than most others (that are usually not shounen anime), it only makes sense that I, in a sense, miss the characters and miss the fact that there isn't anything left to watch. However, I know that the story ended at a great place and that if there was even one more episode, the story would have been dragged out too much (though I wouldn't have minded a little segment of their lives afterwards...)
The score that I give it, a 10, isn't a score that I usually give to any great anime. FMAB really was a great anime that I will hold near and dear to my heart and that I will miss the fact that I can't watch it for the first time ever again.
All in all, Fullmetal Alchemist: Brotherhood is most DEFINITELY an anime with watching, that is, if you haven't already seen it.

One of the best anime I have ever seen, a masterpiece.
WARNING, THIS REVIEW MIGHT CONTAIN SPOILERS!
Story: 10
No cliches or overused things from other animes. There are also no lame/boring transformations. It only has 1 arc, which is pretty unique cause it's not a seasonal anime.  This is also the very first anime that made me cry (For example, Hohenheim's death) and after finishing it, I felt empty, I didn't know what to do after that without this anime.
Art: 10
The art and animation is absolutely amazing! Good fighting animations, effects, backgrounds, and a lot more. So, it gets a 10.
Sound: 10
It doesn't really have the best soundtracks, but it definitely has some great ones. I remember back when they were preparing for the promised day and then the 4th opening sound started before ending the episode. That thing hyped me up. And this is also the first anime that made me watch all the openings without skipping them, in every single episode.
Character: 10
It has awesome characters. Ed doesn't really train like other main characters do, instead, we have Winry to make better automails for him and that's how he gets stronger. And this is one of the first animes that made me like a few characters in only the first 10-15 episodes. Mustang, Hawkeye, Father, Hohenheim, Ed, Al, Winry... So many great characters with awesome designs.
Enjoyment: 10
Do I really have to even talk about this? I was able to watch up to 10 episodes/day of it... Which is pretty bad cause I finished it fast.
Overall: 10/10 A masterpiece.
P.S This is my first review, so I hope it's good.

This was the first anime that I have watched all the way through.
When I first went to watch FMAB, I had no idea what it was. The only reason I started watching it in the first place was because I saw the opening theme and was drawn in by the catchy opening and animation. So when I watched it, I was no disappointed with what I watched.
This was also the anime that got me into it as a whole. I watched FMAB a while back and saw it as just another cartoon (yes, yes, don't annihilate me for calling it a cartoon) but I got
                  attached to the characters as I watched on and on. It made me happy, it made me sad and pretty much every other emotion. When I pushed through all the 64 episodes, I left saying simply "wow." Because it blew my mind.
The art in FMAB was pretty great and gave it a "feel good" type feel to it. The character designs were also great as each character was different, even the background ones which really shows how good it is.
The characters were all outstanding. From the Elrics, Winry, Mustang, Hawkeye, Armstrong, Scar, all of them! They were all unique and I found it hard to hate them (except you Shou Tucker.)
Honestly, there's a reason this is #1 on MAL, if you haven't watched it already... DO IT, WHAT ARE YOU WAITING FOR.
DO IT

One of the greatest shows of all time, Fullmetal Alchemist Brotherhood is exactly what a shonen anime should be. It has lots of action, a great world, great characters and everything it needs. My favorite part of Fullmetal Alchemist was it's take on power scaling. Unlike other anime, where characters get more powerful throughout, in Fullmetal Alchemist the protagonists stay consistent power wise while only maturing emotionally. The animation was also stayed top notch. The plot is also interesting enough so even if an episode is just talking, it remains engaging. It also handles mature themes well while not being edgy, and retains a funny
                  side to most interactions. There are actual stakes, and the show actually ends unlike other shonen which drag on for a hundred episodes. This has no filler, and if a website labels certain episodes as filler ignore it and watch all 64 episodes. I can strongly recommend this to any anime fan.

one of best anime in the history of anime. period. 
plot is amazing, characters are well-developed, and the soundtrack is stunning. there is not a single boring moment in this show, and it brought me so much laughter and tears. absolutely touching story of two brothers and their journey of self-discovery. the way this show portrayed alchemy is something very refreshing too, and delves into the themes of sacrifice and exchange. although this is a fantastical show, many of the lessons learned and themes explored are applicable in real life too.
all in all, a beautiful masterpiece that all anime fans should watch. whether you like
                  it or not, you will take away something from this show.

In all my years of living, I was holding off this show. I am not an avid anime watcher, but when me and my brother were bored one day in June of 2018, we came across Fullmetal Alchemist Brotherhood. I knew about this show, but very little of it. Me and my brother agreed to watch it and now that it's almost been a year since we've finished this show, we both agreed that it changed our lives. This show has no plotholes, no filler, no bullshit. This anime will always keep you on your toes and the way everything comes together so perfectly in
                  the last half of the show has to be the result of the most genius writing I have ever seen. Every single character is so loveable and well written, I found myself loving the way Hohenheim was hinted at being this good-for-nothing father and then revealed to be the most selfless, kindest, father to exist. The main duo Ed and Al will always have a special place in my heart for giving me laughter and tears. The females of this show are absolutely GOD TIER. All of them are strong, intelligent, and play an extremely important role in helping Ed and Al get their bodies back. All in all this has to be the greatest piece of entertainment I've ever watched! I will definitely be rewatching it for the rest of my life. Happy 10th-anniversary FMAB!

                  Ever since, I have re-watched it a couple of times and even got my boyfriend into it. I totally love the intro and outro songs, and I love show this anime made me laugh but also cry a lot. I totally love it, never got my eyes of the screen one single bit. I love it, totally worth the hype, outstanding anime. Would even see it as a classic later on in life.

A must-see for all anime fans. By far my favorite anime. FMAB takes all anime cliches and puts a huge twist on them, keeping the viewer tuned into the show at all times. Okay, so I'm coming back to this show which is commonly praised as one of, if not, the best anime of all time. Now, we have to consider these many different things that make this anime what it was. This show may start off slow, but gradually hikes up the pace making it big on the anime scene, especially since it had another adaptation before. As this is my second review, take this with a grain of salt.
Story-10: As a piece of Shounen trash, I decided to watch this show. Why? I don't know. I at first thought that it would just be FMA with
                  slight changes. What was actually changed caught me by surprise and made me more intrigued. Of course there are moments where you first think, wow, this is just not as great as I would expect it to. And you're right, but this show always picks up the pace and makes it interesting when it matters. It seems that this show is always trying to hype up some piping hot action. This would seem worthless and stupid, yet this show manages to bring some of the strongest plot points in the anime world. Thus, a 10 would suffice in my book.
Art-8: Now, to the art in this show. The art is spectacular, when the animation team is actually working hard. Sometimes the team tends to either save their budget for later, which is much more commendable, or they're just being lazy. The show has some amazing art and shows how deep the plot points are meant to go. It makes great use of some art, though some points make me feel like I'm watching a kids show. Overall, the show has great art, it's just the occasional bad art that prevents me from making this go any higher.
Sound-9: The sound in this anime is one of those soundtracks that make you endorsed in the show. It makes you feel the emotion the crew wants you to feel. Sound is very important, and this show clearly recognizes it. It makes great use of its abundant equipment and makes it so that the viewers can connect with the characters and keep interest. I would give this a 9 for those following reasons.
Character-9: If you've watched the show, you will either disagree or agree. This is coming from a guy who thinks that they have good personality. Sometimes the characters do things that just seem out of the ordinary and don't tend to make the cut for me. However, their backstory has an extremely heavy point in the show, and though this might not be convincing to other people, to me, this is something that would be important for this show, as it brings the plot into perspective and allows full endorsement. That's a 9 in my book.
Enjoyment-10: What I care most about, is my enjoyment. I'm just gonna say that I enjoyed very thoroughly. 10 outta 10.
Overall-10: Now, I personally think that this show lives up to its name, but if you have a different opinion, it's fine. This show to me, brings out the greatness of what anime can be, and I hope to see things like this in the future.

I usually dont review shows that I didnt finish, but here I will have to make an exception, since FMA is the highest ranking anime on this site. To put it bluntly this has to be one of the biggest disappointments I have ever experienced.
My expectations were high when the show started and the show 100% delivered. The first quarter or so is pure kino and if the show ended there, it would be an easy 10/10. Sadly it didnt. Instead I had to watch as the plot slowed to a complete crawl. Seriously, in the first section of the show the plot was running
                  forward (but it wasnt rushed) and then out of nowhere, it feels like the show completely ran out of gas. Dont get me wrong, it doesnt just stop and stand in place, but you could see that it is rapidly loosing speed and you can only watch and hope that the engine will turn back on. At first I kept watching but when it slowed to a complete crawl, I just opened the door and let myself out. I feel no need to ever finish this show and I am honestly not interested in watching it crawl to its destination where the wheels will turn for a last time and then rest.
So this is my review. I could talk about the animation or music, both of which were good, but what would be the point? Even the best looking and sounding car in the world is completely worthless if it refuses to move. For me FMA brotherhood stands as a grim reminder of what could have been, if only the engine didnt break.

                  mean come on? I just wonder want ask you guys do you really think rated of R or not still PG-13? i just want know of that. o.o It's sound strange to me.. I..don't like how that rated 'R'... >.>

Story 10/10
The story is just perfect. The story follows the adventures of Edward Elric and Alphonse Elric. They try to bring back their mother to life using alchemy. However, the experiment goes terribly wrong, Alphonse's body is destroyed and Ed loses a leg and arm. Edward is able to save Alphonse by putting his soul in a suit of armor. They then go on a adventure to try to bring their bodies back.
The story looks really simple, but it is told in a beautiful way and very well paced. I like how they added humor as well and it is perfectly timed.
Art 10/10
The art is
                  very nice and beautiful. I really don't have much to say here.
Sound 9/10
The openings and endings are very nice. My favorite opening and ending is the fourth one. The music for fight scenes are really nicely done as well. I put 9/10 because I felt like the third ending could've been better but nonetheless all the songs are really good.
Character 10/10
The characters are very nice. If I had to say a criticism of anime a bit is that they develop some characters really well (explaining their past and all of that), but they don't do that with other characters. Why can't they do that with all the characters? Well, FullMetal Alchemist Brotherhood develops all their characters. I like every single character as they all serve the story in some way. Also, their villains are developed, which is also a criticism I have of anime sometimes is that the villains can be very one-dimensional at times.
Enjoyment 10/10
I really enjoyed this anime series better than the first FullMetal Alchemist series (2003). I had a lot of issues with the 2003 series because the pacing was really slow and I really couldn't deal with it. FullMetal Alchemist: Brotherhood just fixes all the issues. I loved every bit of it.
Overall 10/10
This anime is a MUST WATCH for any anime fans and people looking to get into anime. FullMetal Alchemist: Brotherhood is a shonen in a way and even though you don't like shonens, you gotta watch this! This anime really sets expectations for what other animes should be like in a way. If you're looking to understand Edward's story, just watch like the first 15 episodes of the 2003 version, but really just watch FullMetal Alchemist: Brotherhood. I highly recommend it!
Thanks for reading. Let me know your thoughts on this review and any feedback you may have for me. Until next time!

This was the first anime that I watched, and is my favorite of all time. I don't have much to say since enough has already been said. The only gripe I have with this anime, which is very very minor, is that the romance between Ed and Winry wasn't fleshed out as well as it could have been but in the end, it's still such a small thing.
But I have to write more so I guess I'll do so oof.
The story is great. There really aren't many plotholes that I can point out. The pacing is overall great, albeit the beginning was fairly slow. Each
                  arc shows development within the two main characters while fleshing out the world. There are no story arcs that feel unnecessary. Overall, I think that it's a flawless story. 10/10
The art, while it is great, I won't give it a 10/10. This is purely because I've seen animes that look better. But of course, with Bones being the animators, the show itself looks fantastic. Also the openings. MMMMMMMM the openings. They are all fantastic and are some of the best that anime has to offer. 9/10 overall
The music in FMAB is fantastic also. Sometimes, I just listen to the OST for the heck of it. The only "negative" I can say about the soundtrack is that Brothers from the 2003 adaptation is missing. 10/10
The characters are also amazing. Every character, heroes and villains alike, get so much character development or have fleshed out backstories. An obvious standout is Ed. He develops from being a snotty brat who is very cocky and is easily riled up. However, after everything happens within the story, he matures and makes decisions that he would'nt've done so in the beginning. 10/10
Enjoyment gets a 10/10. I mean... it's my favorite anime of all time so there isn't much to be said about that.
Overall, this anime gets a 10/10 from me. As I previously said, I think that this is basically a perfect anime so a 10/10 is an obvious score from me.
Anyways I'm basically done with this cyall

This anime earns it's wide reputation for it's unbelievably well told 'journey' story for the Elric brothers. I love the adventure and the action present in this anime. Brotherhood is worth the watch, it has made an

Personally I still recommend watching the original full metal alchemist first, because it is still an amazing show and the two shows are so different that both can be watched without worrying about overlapping story information too much.

I'm always very picky about that anime series I watch and usually watch anime with many episodes so I have time to process the story and tie with the characters, if that makes sense.
