How does one even properly begin a review of Fullmetal Alchemist: Brotherhood? By discussing its legendary status? By laying out the tricky relationship with its 2003 sibling? One thing is for sure, Hiromu Arakawa created something special when Enix began publishing her manga back in 2001. Brotherhood's top rating here MAL is not difficult to understand in the slightest. It is arguably the most accessible anime program to ever grace the world. The characters are indelibly likable, with strong personalities, distinct appearances, and well-defined goals. The setting is both immediately familiar in its parallels to early 20th century Europe and intriguing with its underlying mechanics
                  of alchemy. The story is straightforward and never devolves into the confusing, bizarre, or abstract jigsaw puzzle-plotting so common in anime despite expanding its scope to cover many characters and a political conspiracy. Both Japanese and English VAs are top notch. And while the blending of drama and comedy can often be abrasive (notoriously so), I find that it only adds to the endearing qualities of the show. Brotherhood is some of the best YA fiction around, with a little something for everyone, and offers what I consider to be an almost perfect entry point into the universe of Japanese animation.
I say "almost" because there is a catch. Brotherhood can only barely be considered a stand-alone work. The figure of Studio Bones's first FMA adaption, which began airing in 2003, looms large over Brotherhood. Whereas the older adaption only managed to cover part of Arakawa's story before catching up to the source material, forcing the writers to take things in their own direction, Brotherhood tells the mangaka's version of the story in its entirety. Needless to say there is much overlap between the two and the consequence is obvious to anyone who has seen both. Brotherhood more or less assumes its audience is familiar with the ground covered by FMA 2003, condensing ~28 episodes worth of material into 14. 
Nowhere is this flippant attitude towards the viewer more obvious than the first episode. With original content not found within the pages of the source material, Brotherhood's first episode plays more like the beginning of a movie in an established franchise (no different than Conqueror of Shamballa or Sacred Star of Milos really), than a proper introduction to its world and characters. Many characters are introduced. Specific events and plot points are name-dropped like crazy. Even the true evil nature of an important character, which is supposed to be a major plot reveal, is less than subtly foreshadowed.  Clearly there is an expectation that we already know all this. 
Brotherhood proceeds to quickly plow through the redundant material from here. While this is understandable, and serves as a decent refresher for the already initiated, it makes for a less than ideal experience for first-time watchers. Granted, there's nothing missing from the early parts of the story. Everything anyone needs to know is covered. But it's done at the sacrifice of real impact and character development. These early parts of the story are key to understanding who the Elric brothers are, how they think and approach problems, what their strengths and weaknesses are, etc. Such clarifying moments are abridged, or even cut out entirely if they don't serve an understanding of the larger story. Worse yet is the execution. Watching FMA 2003 and Brotherhood back to back reveals how much better the former handled these moments. Brotherhood's direction is often flat, with excessive use of odd visual gimmicks like splitscreens, fish-eyed perspectives, and dutch angles. The music can be insufficient or even inappropriate. Brotherhood just lacks the subtle atmosphere of horror and gut-punching impact of its 2003 counterpart. This is a deal breaker, especially when the most dramatic and heavy hitting moments come in this part of the story.*
Thankfully, Brotherhood quickly finds its footing with the introduction of a few new characters unfamiliar to 2003 veterans. It's clear at this moment that Brotherhood is more interested in a bigger picture. Whereas FMA 2003 never gave the country of its setting a name or any geopolitical details, Brotherhood gives us Amestris, a map, and bordering neighbors with a history. This is a bigger story, a more political story, and (for better or worse) a less tragic and Elric brothers-driven story.  The climax is wonderfully epic, finding clever ways to work in the enormous cast, but one can't help but feel some dramatic absence in the mix. While 2003 Ed and Al never lose sight of their goal to get their bodies back, as the motivations of companions and enemies alike converge on its central rule-breaking Philosopher Stone, Brotherhood's dual protagonists get caught up in the whirlwind of conspiracy and cosmic threats. I prefer the persistent and intimate tragedy and horror elements of FMA 2003 (along with its more classic art and storyboarding) than the more traditional machinations of Brotherhood, but the latter can certainly pull it off like no other. Studio Bones manages to do so with gusto thanks to some stellar production values carried across an impressive 64 episodes. 
*Honestly, I strongly recommend watching the 2003 series first. It can make the viewing of Brotherhood more fuller with the characters already being fleshed out. Plus, it's refreshing to see how the story diverges, where mysteries that were solved by the 2003 series are revitalized as they take on new tantalizing intrigue.

Depending on your age and disposition, battle shounen can be an endless source of entertainment or a tedious, tired proposal. Brotherhood--a faithful adaptation of the Fullmetal Alchemist manga, unlike the 2003 TV series--is very much beholden to the tropes of its genre, but rises above most of its peers thanks to its laser-like storytelling focus. A well-developed magic system, an appealing 20th-century steampunk setting, and fantastically fluid action scenes make it one of the most satisfying anime of its kind. It's also willing to indulge in political commentary the likes of which most shounen would consider overly polemic, asking questions such as: is war ever
                  justified? Can you really change institutions from within? Does industrial society put a price tag on human life? And while the ending is a little trite and the 2003 adaptation had a handful of better individual episodes, the beginning-to-end experience of Brotherhood is practically unmatched in shounen.

Here we are, the No.1 anime on MAL is it really worth that spot, let's find out.
I will be rating ANIME so I won't be comparing how well it represent LN or manga.
\\ spoiler alert just in case //
Art: 9/10
From snowy regions to hot deserts we get to see every possible region of our protagonists world and every region is beautiful, as expected of 64 episodes.
Characters: 9/10Through the series we meet various characters with different personalities, different abilities etc. it makes world of Fullmetal very lively.
Character progression: 9/10
Our MCs are deeply developed and explored, we see their past, their attempt to resurrect their mother, their training and their path to get back limbs and body which were taken away as a fee to the ritual of resurrection ( failed). Even side characters are heavily invested, some change their beliefs through the series, some comes to our heroes side ( Greed) and etc.
Story: 9/10
Story goal is quite simple our MCs are trying to get back their limbs and body, so they enlist to te army in order to fasten their research. This doesn't go well as planned and our characters later has to stop destruction of their country and stop Homunculi from becoming a god.
Story progression: 10/10
This is outstanding. This is masterpiece. There are many side episodes, but NOT even once I felt they were unnecesary or boring or just time extension. Every side episode was interesting and it added something new to our main story, I have to applause to the studio and I think this was masterfully done.
Villains: 9/10
Homunculi family: 9/10 They are creations of the 1st Homunculi and are absolutely loyal to him except of Greed. We get to see them trying to stop our MCs in their effort, but they are also taking care of our protagonists so they can use them in ritual, which will allow 1st Homunculi becoming a god. Even though they are not humans they show emotions towards humans. Pride loves his human mother, Envy is envious of humans. They were very well done villains, which I liked to see everytime they appeared and that is a good villain by my book.
" Father" 1st Homunculi: 9/10 He's creation of Hohenheim ( father of our MCs), he wished to get out of bottle which he managed after a ritual which was supposed to give immortality to the emperor, but Homunculi tricked him and gave it to Hohenheim and he appeared as human looking being, his ultimate goal is to become a god. He isn't " unnecesary evil ( that means he doesn't do thing which would artificially make him hateable villain)".
Sound: 8/10
Fullmetal offer many soundtracks, though I didn't found any that struck to me, but that doesn't mean they're bad I think they are pretty good, but they just didn't struck to me.
Sooo overall rating of Fullmetal Alchemist: Brotherhood is 9/10 exact. As I am writing this, Fullmetal has the best rating in my reviews, so I guess it deserves it's spot yet.

"Deserving of its #1 title on MyAnimeList and many other sites that it claims", is something that I'd say about the shows, and for different reasons than to other people might give, this show is NOT my favourite and isn't even close, so then what's deserving about this show to be so high up and deserving you might ask as a casual viewer, answer is simple, objectively, it's the most well written and broad mainstream I have ever watched and probably ever will. 
While some people choose to reject the fact that Fullmetal Alchemist: Brotherhood is good, either because they watched it's anime predecessor
                  or aren't a fan of the concept, what they are unable to escape from is that objectively speaking, the writing is about as perfect as you can get in the anime medium, name me one plot hole or flaw worth speech, you can name any small ones, but are they really worth throwing a show over? Even so these details are just ignored and are in the manga, overall, it's just super difficult to prove Fullmetal Alchemist: Brotherhood as bad in any way, I guess the only real negative comment you can make with any sort of valid point to it is either that it's a generic battle shounen (which means nothing for its quality), or that it just isn't your kind of show, which is respectable which leads me to my next point of discussion.
Moving on from the objective quality, is a topic I found to be more relevant to my personal placement on my list. Despite the broad demographic that this story connects with; that being the shounen demographic, and relatable theming that most people can connect with and empathize, is that the show does not meet my own personal quota for philosophy and psychology. While this seems generic you can talk to any psychological fan such as myself, who will admit to Fullmetal Alchemist: Brotherhoods quality, but who also fail to enjoy it as much as other shows due to its lack in that general department of anime. Which proves that Fullmetal Alchemist: Brotherhoods only "flaw" is that its genre is so broad it fails to connect with people who like niche and exotic shows. Which if anything is more of a compliment, just saying that the show is so easy to follow that it is, as you could put it, "boring" because it does not require much amount of thinking to really get or understand, which brings me to my last point of this review: 
How can a show have a meaning and a lesson for the viewers to take away, and yet be so easy to understand that it can get through to even the most braindead and stingy people? Simple, something so common place that most people overlook, equivalent exchange. You pay for bread with money you worked hard for, that's time out of your day to earn those coins, which you exchange for bread worth the same amount, it's so simple yet so overlooked that when it's shown to anyone, they realize how much they connect with it and are almost blown away or at the very least impressed to an extent, it's hard to find any well recognized shows, or even shows in general, which bring you something so simple yet so ingenious, which happens to be Fullmetal Alchemist: Brotherhoods greatest strength.
To conclude, this show may not be for everyone, and anyone can escape from watching it or accepting that it is a good show, but what you cannot escape is how well written this show is, writing, moral, character, pacing, and all, it's pretty much impossible for you to give a valid reason to say that this show is even mediocre, so submit to equivalent exchange, spend 24 hours of your life, and appreciate the unembellished genius of the show.

Fullmetal Alchemist Brotherhood is one of those rare anime series that found acclaim all around the world. The reviews in this forum has already shown how popular it is in the Anglosphere. I just like to add on that in her native country, Japan and in the Sinosphere, this anime received similar universal praise. For example, on douban (the most critical Chinese movie review site), it has a rating of 9.4, the best of any anime. In Taiwan, it was voted unanimously as the best in the last decade on a similar review site. In Japan, Arakawa has won two awards for the manga and
                  was consistently voted as one of the best anime/manga ever. So why do this story resonates with so many people across different cultures? Perhaps, it is because its story is on an epic scale spanning several regions/countries. It deals with moral values and dilemmas that would concern any human. Its characters are relatable and believable. Its pacing is astoundingly crisp and to the point. The artwork especially the fight scenes are done extremely well. The story has a satisfying conclusion and feels complete. It is certainly not perfect but every aspect of this shonen anime is near the very best of its genre. If only I can write and draw as well as Arakawa...

Fullmetal Alchemist: Brotherhood (Bones)
Part 1: (Episodes 1-13) Sometimes I wish this show went full edge-lord and took the dark topics that it has and rolled with them while omitting the goofy cringe anime humor. (See that section below) But at the same time, I love the Elric brother's relationship with each other and their backstory. And even though Lieutenant Colonel Hughes was annoying at times, I did like his character, and like that his death is sparking a darker tone in the story, and am curious to see how the brothers react to it. The show has a lot of potential. I am enjoying it,
                  but I feel like it will grow in quality in its upcoming seasons. 6/10
Part 2: (Episodes 14-26) As I suspected, the show really gets kicked into gear upon the death of Hughes which thrusts us into a political thriller with Homunculi entities as enemies which exhibit traits of the Seven Deadly Sins. Early on the show did a good job of making me mistrust Colonel Mustang before letting us know how brilliant he's going to be. He's wildly outmatched against an enemy that has powers that we can't even fathom, but so long as he's still breathing, he's a guy that you can't count out. He reminds me of Captain Levi from Attack on Titan and he's a badass that is easy to root for. As for the Elric brothers, Ed still is prone to his childish outbursts, but the duo go through some heavy character growth when they revisited their old teacher and inevitably get lumped into Mustang's plot to stop the Homunculi. I suspected that the show was going to get better, but I never anticipated it getting better this fast and staying consistent. The themes of the show get darker each episode with the philosophical question of what makes us human and what the value of a soul is being asked in a variety of ways. Unlike season 1, this season ends at an appropriate time leaving a lot of questions left unanswered and a few encounters awaiting the brothers with their father. God damn that "Let It All Out" song hit me in the feelz right there at the end. 9/10
Part 3: (Episodes 27-39) The show continues to be strong as it builds upon the fantastic season 2. We get the backstory on the Ishvalon War, our heroes are halted in their plans of overthrowing the Fuhrer, and the Homunculi's plans of creating a new Philosopher's Stone seem to be progressing while Colonel Mustang tries to fight from the shadows with his allies purposefully scattered by the Fuhrer. Scar and May Chang try to find out the purpose of his brother's research in the hopes of getting vengeance on those that caused the Ishvalon genocide while Ed and Al continue looking into how to get their bodies back with their new lead being the alchemy of the Ishvalons somehow being unaffected by the Homunculi's temporary blockage. There's a lot of intrigue in this season and it continues to build up to bigger and better things... 9/10
Part 4: (Episodes 40-52) Kimblee is an awesome antagonist. I love how he is limited in what he can do to the Elrics because of working for the Homunculi but he still suspects them every step of the way and even was even willing to kill Ed to get what he wanted. The Dwarf in the Flask episode which gave the backstory on Johenheim will go down as one of the best episodes in the series. Excellent backstory! I was so glad to see Envy finally taken down. Scar and Dr. Marcoh working together to destroy his Philosopher's Stone was awesome and with all of the atrocities that Envy has done, it was about time that humanity got a little revenge.
I don't get why the Dwarf in the Flask keeps making Greeds since he actively works against him and he knows it, but I am glad that he does because he is a lot of fun to watch. Plus with Ling Yao's body being the construct for the Philosopher's Stone, having Yao fight from the inside adds a whole new dynamic to the homunculi which already makes that even more interesting. Then having him team up with Ed and get in a showdown with Pride the most terrifying of the Homunculi? Yeah, that was all awesome. Then as always, Colonel Mustang keeps getting himself backed into a corner but just when you think he's down for the count, he flips the script with an elaborate scheme and finds a way to come out on top. They have yet to interact, but I would love to see Mustang duke it out with Kimblee. It all builds up to a final stand to prevent the day of reckoning... 9/10
Part 5: (Episodes 53-64 ) The beginning episodes were frustrating. On the one hand, it has some super powerful moments and the story remains fascinating. And everything about the eclipse and the Father's quest to become the perfect being was awesome. But it becomes way too Shonen for its own good and it drives me nuts. And for the life of me, I can not understand why Mustang does not use his flames more. He could have mowed down the mannequin horde, burned the super-soldiers to a crisp along with the scientist, and hell, he had a shot at Bradley when he was talking. But he chose to fight hand-to-hand until it was too late in all of those scenarios. It was so annoying. But boy was that Envy scene super satisfying! I was so pissed when Edward stopped him.
The season picks up for the better once all five sacrifices were brought to the Homunculus Father and he initiated the summoning circle and tried to become a God. While it was peak Shonen levels of fighting, it was actually really interesting because of the cosmic horror aspects and because the tone went from goofy to super serious with a couple character deaths including Greed, my favorite Homunculus. And above all, the show was an epic journey and it was nice to be rewarded by having a satisfying ending. So overall, I think this season has some amazing highs and it was still entertaining, but the writing wasn't as great as the last three seasons.
8/10
Plot: It's the 20th century and alchemy, the study of deconstructing and reconstructing matter, is used by a select few who are able to master the art. The rule of alchemy states that you cannot create something out of nothing, so when one wishes to obtain something, something of equal value must be paid. When the Elric brothers try to perform a human transmutation to bring their mother back from the dead, the experiment goes horribly wrong and they are left deformed with Ed losing an arm and a leg and Al losing his entire body, and having his soul put into an armored suit. The show follows Ed who has gained renown as the "Fullmetal Alchemist" who is on a quest to find out a way to get his brother and himself their bodies back.
Visuals: A *Besides the show involving elemental users that can manipulate matter, I think the artwork (not necessarily the character designs) for Fullmetal Alchemist: Brotherhood and Avatar the Last Airbender are similar as well as the humor. It's a very colorful world with fluid animation and fantastic fight sequences. And like Avatar, characters are easy to distinguish from each other due to their characteristics like the Ishvalan having red eyes, Alphonse being a giant suit of armor, Edward being short with a metal arm and leg, the central military donning blue uniforms, and each of the Homunculi having their own monstrous forms and powers and the alchemists themselves having their own specialties with how they cast their alchemy.
Voice Acting: B *As usual, I watched the dub and throughout the series, I've gotten used to the few voices that did annoy me at first. Al's voice is super cute and I love him. Ed's voice is fine... when he's not yelling about someone calling him short. But the gag and the yelling grew on me in time especially as the gag gets used a bit less as the show gets more serious. But Ed is far from the only character that screams and gets angry out of nowhere for trivial things for no reason. I'm looking at you Winry! The "screaming for comedic effect" anime trope turned me off in season 1, but the show gets so much better with each season afterward. And most of the voices are really good.
Film Score/Soundtrack: In the context of the show, I felt like the music does a good job of enhancing scenes and being memorable. The themes that repeat in particular are excellent at this and during the many emotional moments during the show, that's where the score shines. However, as a standalone listen, I find the score to be pretty boring to listen to. There are a bunch of songs I hear and I'm like "oh I remember that, I like that one" but there's no way I could sit through a lot of the atmosphere fillers.
***My favorite track: Look, this is 5 seasons worth of material, there is no way I can only choose 1 song ok?
Requiem for the Blind Alchemist
(I am partial to bells and pretty melodies ok? This is a gorgeous song!)
Lurking
(You hear this too many times an episode to not include this eerie track amongst the best. It is a powerful atmosphere setter which is heavily used when important plot points are being discussed by the characters. It's a short and sweet song, but very, very memorable because it lingers)
Postlude
(Ditto to my first comment. I love songs that have bells. Haunting melodic lullabies I find memorable and really pretty)
***I can't find this last track and it's driving me NUTS!!! It's the "happy-sounding flute song" that plays in most episodes which serves as sort of a theme for Ed and Alphonse. I've searched for a long time but I am unable to figure out what to call it. So frustrating!
Characters:
Colonel Mustang is the GOAT. Master strategist underdog that finds a way out of the muck. Plus his flame alchemy is super powerful and I hate how underutilized it is.
Ling Yao started as a funny comedic relief and evolved into one of the best characters in the show.
Alphonse has awesome armor and his personality is so pure and I loved him!
Edward is probably the most likable whiny protagonist I've seen in a show. I love his determination, but he could be a bit much at times. And much like Mustang, he relies too much on hand-to-hand combat when he's a skilled alchemist and it drives me nuts.
Scar is like the Prince Zuko (see Avatar the Last Airbender) of Fullmetall but far more ruthless. He fights with a vengeance and eventually learns that revenge isn't the way of making the world a better place. But that doesn't mean that he doesn't kill his fair share of people either.
Johenheim has an awesome backstory and much like Mustang, he is someone you can't count out because the show likes to make you think he's going to lose when in actuality, he apparently was playing chess the entire time while the Dwarf in the Flask was playing checkers.
Homunculi:
1: Greed *Badass personality and voice. He just had a really cool vibe and I love how much of a wildcard he is. And when he fused to Ling Yao, game over. He already made a good first impression in his limited time in seasons 1 and 2, but then he solidified himself as my favorite Homunculi and one of my favorite characters on the show. "I want money, women, status, fame... and everything else in this world." In the end, he actually wanted friendship
2: Envy *The evilest of the Homunculi that committed the most amount of atrocities. He was a mass manipulator because of his ability to shape-shift into any form that he wished to. And besides that, he has a sharp tongue and has fun turning people on each other. Yet he still could hold his own in a fight because of how many souls he consumed. Envy was a parasite and a monster. But eventually we discover that Envy was jealous of humanity and needed humans as a vessel to survive because he hated his own ugly form.
3: Pride *Out of all of the Homunculi, Pride was the one with the most frightening ability. I almost wish he didn't reveal his identity to Hawkeye because he could have remained a secret and continued to cause a lot of problems for our heroes without them even knowing who was attacking them. Pride was the only Homunculus to share his Father's form and I find it ironic that his original body was of a human despite the Father's resentment to humanity and his desire to ascend to a more perfect being. Also, I loved when Kimblee stepped in to ensure that Pride didn't take Ed's body. That was badass!
4: Wrath *A friend of mine was telling me about a Kung Fu RPG game called Jade Empire and how in the game you can get a gun from a sidequest and that you can use it to kill the final boss because guns > Kung Fu to which I replied: that isn't the case in anime. In the world of Fullmetal Alchemist, somehow not only is Wrath's sword mightier than the gun, but it is mightier than the tank too. It was a bit absurd, but at the same time, awesome to see how many people were required to bring Wrath down. And it was beautifully ironic that Wrath died peacefully with a smile on his face
5: Lust *She was an interesting opponent for the time she was in the show. And much like Envy, I enjoyed it a lot when Mustang was able to unleash his power. Manipulation was her game and she did a number on Havoc and made Mustang's life a living hell.
6/7: Glutonny/Sloth *I lump these two together because outside of their main traits, they don't really have that much personality. Gluttony was always hungry and Sloth hated existing. Both could always be outsmarted by the heroes or manipulated by their fellow homunculi. And because of this, I always saw these two as minor players.
Cringeworthy Anime Moments: For a show with a premise as dark as this one has, it sure has a lot of light-hearted humor. Sometimes I like it, but it was often cringe-inducing. The loud girl squealing because she sees something she loves stereotype or the main character repeatedly getting pissed off when someone makes a joke to him, or the unrealistic use of violence as a means of characters interacting with each other all irritated the hell out of me as I watched this. But it does get significantly better after season 1 and I've actually grown to enjoy the humor for the most part even if my eyes roll when it happens.
Opening Titles:
Opening 1 *is the GOAT! Classic anime opening that I doubt most people skipped. Super catchy and badass! (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ONlpjTnXlms)
Opening 2 *No offense to people that like this type of music, but it's not for me. Sounds too much like whiney emo rock. (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UqIahGU9ZtY)
Opening 3 *Not bad but looking back these intros a couple years later, I totally forgot that this existed and I have no urge to add this song to my anime playlist after relistening to it. (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=et7oxRRkPEo)
Opening 4 *Ditto with part 3. (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6FMPUhjUmRI)
EndingTitles:
Ending 1 *Cute animation and melody. (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PHbUcpXypd8)
Ending 2 *Easily my favorite of the bunch. Super catchy chorus, lovely progression and great animation. In the never skipped once territory for me. (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Vi9zgj8foKo)
Ending 3 *Hard to follow up "Let It All Out" but somehow the cute big-boobed Winry being mechanic with Japanese rap and Xiao-Mei looking cute playing with her panda holds up pretty well even though it is totally pandering with cute anime girls doing cute things. (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yQ6Bp9E3OFA&ab_channel=1)
Ending 4 *Back to never skip status again. Super catchy rock song with a memorable chorus and flashy and exciting animation. (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yxkyElx0pXI)
Ending 5 *The type of song that tries to hit you in the feelz with the chord progression and the build-up to the catchy and powerful chorus. It hit its mark on me. Fitting for the final ending track. (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7hpfhV9SLx0&ab_channel=RinElric)
Final Verdict: 9/10 *Fullmetal Alchemist is a ridiculously entertaining show with an awesome premise filled with lots of likable characters, awesome action sequences, entertaining villains, and a satisfying conclusion. Even though I won't rank it as my favorite anime, I have no qualms with this being one of the highest rated and most beloved anime series of all time. I loved the ride that this show took me on.

I put off watching this anime for a long time, despite all the high praise I heard about it, thinking that it would probably be overrated. And boy was I wrong. Very mild spoilers ahead so read at your own risk!
Story (10/10): I can definitely say that in my opinion, FMA:B deserves all the praise that it gets. The story is fantastic and moves at a good pace - with 64 episodes, it never felt like the story dragged on or was ever boring. There are some good twists and turns to keep you on your toes, and the fight scenes are great. I'll leave
                  it at that as to not spoil too much. 
Art (8.5/10): Compared to some of the newer shows, the animation still holds is own (Bones Studio comes through as per usual), but it is definitely not as polished as some anime from more recent years. They do a great job with the fight scenes, especially in the later half of the show 
Characters (10/10): Aside from the story, one of the most compelling things about this show are the characters. You truly grow to care for the Elric brothers and are rooting for them to get their bodies back and get a happy ending. Edward is probably my favorite shounen MC of all time, and it is so satisfying to see him grow (mentally and physically) and learn from his past mistakes.This show is also jam packed with amazing female characters, which is something that the shounen genre is sometimes lacking in. Winry, Riza, Izumi, and Olivier are all amazing (just to name a few). In addition, Greed and Scar are some of the best anti-heroes that I have come across in anime. There are really no one-dimensional characters in this show, and it truly allows FMA:B to shine. 
Enjoyment (10/10): To be honest, I have a hard time finishing shows as I get bored easily. Not once did I consider dropping FMA:B, since it kept me entertained throughout. Especially in the last 2 seasons, it was pretty hard to stop watching once everything that had been leading up to the Promised Day got set into motion.
I do want to talk about a few things that some people might dislike about the show:
1.) Again, the animation is good, IMO, but if you are used to watching anime from more recent years, it might look subpar.
2.) Some people have issues with the comedy in the show. Personally, I didn't have an issue with it, but I can definitely see why some people might. I will say that some of the jokes/running gags do drastically decrease after the first season or two, so if that is something that bothers you, keep in mind that it will not be as prevalent as the show goes on. 
3.) I think this is mostly for people who have seen the 2003 version first, but some people do find the first few episodes to be rushed. I watched FMA:B before reading the manga, and I didn't notice any pacing issues, but just thought I would point that out. 
Overall, FMA:B really is a 10/10 show for me. If you are putting off watching this like I did for a long time, GO WATCH IT! 
FMA:B weaves an amazing and philosophical story about family, war, revenge, love, and ultimately, humanity.

After rewatching it again, it is still a damn masterpiece 
I cried, laugh, and enjoyed it.
I still can’t believe that this was made in 2009, the animation in the fight scenes were so smooth and fantastic. The blending of funny, sad, and hype in this is so well. The story is very unique, the morals being taught was done well.
The characters are so well written that even you would feel sympathy with the side characters that you’ve only seen 2-3 episodes.
This is still the best of all shounen animes out there.
Berserk and FmaB really deserves to be the best seinen and shounen or even the
                  top.
Every episode is just a masterpiece, The voice acting is magnificent thanks to the talented seiyuus that are here. A 2009 anime beating the latest shounens with this kind of animation, really hilarious, thanks Studio bones for this wonderful adaptation and also thank you for the wonderful story, mangaka <3
And also one thing that makes this even better is how human every characters are in this anime.

Summary:
Fullmetal Alchemist: Brotherhood is a fantastic show with an engaging plot and interesting characters. This is for good reason. This is one of the best anime to watch if you have never watched one before. Its overall quality is superb, although it is not a masterpiece. The suspense will keep you invested, and it’s awesome that you can now binge-watch it. I recommend it to anyone interested in trying a new show or getting into anime.
Story: 9/10
Unlike many anime with the same genre, FA:B is not overly plot-driven. The characters develop over time and make choices that coincide with the plot. This is an important
                  aspect of any good story. The viewer gets to know the main characters based on their traumatic past and their goals to reverse the mistakes they’ve made. The world-building is excellent, and watching this from start to finish makes you feel as though the characters’ world isn’t just a fantasy world. 
Art: 9/10
The art is beautiful 90% of the time. There are some scenes where it seems like there are missing frames, but the overall art quality is amazing.
Sound: 10/10
The soundtrack, openings, and endings are absolutely the best part of this anime. If MAL ranked anime based on these categories, FA:B would probably listed #1 for sound alone. Even the voice acting is great, and that can be hard to find in English dubbed anime.
Character: 8/10
Compared with many anime, this show has well-written characters who gradually develop over time. Ed’s face literally gets bigger and more mature as he grows older. Some characters seem to lack depth while many are quite life-like. Overall, the characters help to depict the themes throughout the story.
Enjoyment: 10/10
This is absolutely one of my favorite anime because of its overall quality and how enjoyable it is. It keeps you wanting more until the very end. The ending is also beautiful.
Overall: 9.2/10

I loved the series. I laughed with it. I cried like a baby, especially whenever Ed shows his selfless nii-san love for Al. I was intrigued with every ending of the episode, which was one of the reasons I finished the whole thing in a week. The series was not a disappointment in my part, and it made me wish that all of the other remakes would be AS GOOD as this. This is a quick recommend to my friends who love to watch shounen and for those who were familiar with the original FMA, because Brotherhood was told in the manga's point of view,
                  and the story came in full circle in the end.

Full metal alchemist Brotherhood was one of the first anime i watched and i am sure the same can be said for many others, I believe the reason for this is not purely based off of the fact that it is very popular but also because it is a great starter/beginner anime. The reason i think this is thanks to the shows inclusion of everything that makes anime what it is (music,animation the works) and the fact that the anime isn't missing anything crucial like some other anime shows is a testament as to how much care was weaved during production. What i am trying
                  to say is the show does everything well and in my humble opinion has no glaring flaws aside from the fact that while it does everything well it doesn't go above and beyond in any aspect so in retrospect it has no glaring negatives but also no glaring positives, it is simply put a tightly made show, a jack of all trades if you will these facts combined make it very appetising for newcomers. 
Now don't hate me for this but i do think the show is slightly overrated. Majority of people who watch this show watch it as one of their first anime due to it being recommended to them through various means and because it is so balanced overall (as mentioned) people hail it after the first watch and that is because they don't really have anything to compare it to. Now i'm 100 percent sure that there are people who have seen the show after seeing many others and still give it a shining star of a rating and that is fine everyone is entitled to their opinions this review is just my opinions on the matter.  
If you want to describe full metal alchemist in one sentence it would either be : the perfect starting/beginner anime (death note is up there as well) or one of the most balanced and tightly made anime.  
I feel there is no need to go deeper into an analysis as if you have not seen the show watch it because the show has everything while also having no major flaws. As i have mentioned countless times (sorry) it is a great beginner anime for those reasons, but just because its a good starter anime does not mean you shouldn't watch it if you are not new to the anime scene as its an absolute joy to watch from start to finish thanks to it being a great quality show all the way through. 
Its an anime that sets the standard for other anime for a reason. A must watch.

Brotherhood is an amazing show. Although I like the 2003 adaptation better, I think that Brotherhood still deserves the hype that it gets. 
STORY:
The story is a refreshing and entertaining adventure that never ceases to impress. The knowledge and mystery that goes on in this show mixed in with its own unique philosophy make this show supposedly one of a kind. The first 12 episodes start off a bit rushed, this is only because the author created it assuming everybody watching had already been familiar with the manga or have watched the 2003 series. The rest is solely based on opinion, I think that it's
                  good but it also turns into a typical shonen near the end of the series. FMA 2003 is more of a darker-seinen type of show that doesn't fall into the horror genre but isn't happy-go-lucky at the same time. I recommend you watch both shows.
CHARACTERS: The Elric brothers are an amazing dynamic along with a lot of the other characters in the show. Each of them barring their own hardships that affect their decisions and how they act and or view the world. The characters in this show are pretty good and they give the show a good atmosphere.
ART: Stunning, crisp, great quality, enough said.
ENJOYMENT:
Fullmetal Alchemist will always hold a spot in my top 10 anime and I will always re watch yearly, it most definitely deserves the ratings it gets I think everybody should watch it when they get the chance. I enjoyed it a lot.

No spoilers
A very nice anime. Excellent in every aspect. 
I have watched it three times. 
The plot twists are especially entertaining. 
The animation quality is also great.
 The character development is exciting.
 It's much better than the original.
 The openings are magnificent and extremely memorable. 
It's worth it to watch all 64 episodes and the ending is especially satisfying as no plot holes remain. 
The relationships between characters can get confusing at times but overall adds to the plot.This show is definitely a 10/10 and deserves to be watched by everyone who considers themselves an anime enthusiast
Although it's true that the plot can get slow at times, this is a common theme in any large anime. This also provides a much-needed break for viewers.
Overall an excellent anime, I would recommend to a friend.

I really really loved this anime, its a masterpiece and a really good entry for non anime viewers, however I personally think that the opening episodes are weak compared to the rest of the show, the humor is not very good (it's not THAT bad just used poorly), and has some very awkward tone shifts, despite all of my gripes and criticisms, it's still great and I highly recommend it. 
Edward Elric is one of my favorite characters of all time, his development is so great, its such a great story about tragedy and becoming stronger by learning from your mistakes, he's also a very
                  flawed person, who has trouble compromising and changing, and feels entitled to certain things, but his flaws are understandable because of what he's been through as a child, not to mention he's still a young adult, and despite all his flaws he's able to move forward and improve both himself as person, and also the world for the better. I also love his design, and personality.
I also love other characters like Ling Yao, Roy Mustang, Riza Hawkeye, Alphonse Elric, Greed and others.

Okay so there's so many awesome things about this show. I'll start with my favorite thing about the show. The female characters are written so well. They have their own desires and motivations throughout the show. They're really awesome and just as important as other male characters. Many of the side characters also have a lot of really cool aspects to them. There are very few characters who seem flat. There's just a lot of attention paid to everyone in the show and I enjoy it. 
The use of a power system like alchemy is also very unique to the show and I enjoy seeing
                  how Alchemy is used in inventive ways throughout the show. It's also the main means for others in the show to create conflict (and then resolve the conflict) It's a cool magical system without being "magical"

Fullmetal alchemist brotherhood is a highly acclaimed show that i started years ago but i couldnt finish it cuz of the slow start , but all my friends who have watched it gave it 10s , so i decided to give it a second chance and finish it , here is my brutally honest review about it .
Story 7:
The main story line is fairy simple ,it tells the tale of  2 brothers trying to get their bodies back after committing a taboo (trying to revive their dead mother) , this premise is very good and effective plus its unique among the i wanna be
                  the very best overused formula of other battle shonens , but sadly i didnt get as invested in this particular premise cuz of hte 2 main characters but i will leave the reasons  for later .The sub plots are what carried the show for me , scar's revenge , the corruption of the military and the seven sins's objective...etc , are all excellent sub plots that made me finish the anime . the show also tackles some very deep and interesting topics and themes , from religion to the morality of science . to racism and corruption and evem exsitentialism , the show is one of deepest shonens out there with the greastest of ease . But sadly it suffers from a very big problem imo , the freaking comedy and especially in the first half , not only its repetetive and unfunny ,but also used in a lot of serious moments and mid fights which breaks the tone and makes me furious , this is a problem you find in low tier shonens like fairy tail and dr stone we dont need that here . The final arc is one of the best climaxes of a story ive seen in anime in term of fights , and sheer numbers of characters present , and the big majority of them played a big role in the narrative which is something rare to see , but on the other hand the ending felt forcibly happy i would  ve prefered if the author had given us a more bitterswet finale with more deaths and heavier prices to pay . Another thing to note is that , i ve wanted to see more about xing empire maybe an arc about it , or the agenda of the old military geezer who i was expecting to pull a plot twist on us . Also to finish this paragraph there was some plot convinience in the mix but its not a big problem by this point.
Art and animation 9/10
Very consistent through all the 64 eps run , with some animated scenes of mind blowing sakuga in the final arc , sasuga studio bones 
Characters 7/10
Its time to address the elefant in the room , the freaking main characters , the mc edward (and this might be a little bit harsh)  is one of the worst protagonists i ve seen in an anime  , not only he is the source of the comedy i hate so much in the show , but he a goody goody too shoes with naive ideals that survives to the end of the story just becuz the villains need him to be alive so they can complete their master plan  , he also has this atheist ideaology going for him which i wont dwelve into . His brother is a little bit better than him , but he is  in the majority of the times a dumbass , a beta male with a body of a hulk but the brain of a bird.Tehir childhood friend wnery , is a character that i didnt care about at the first half , but i ve come to appreciateher after her developpement . Other characters carried the show like : mustang , scar , greed , ran fan , lin and others , they are so many good characters you will have at least 2 or 3 of them that you like .T wasted character imo is king bradely who had the potential to be the best character in the show , but i wasnt a fan of the way the author handeled him , the same can be said about mustang and his revenge  . the final character that i need to talk about is the main villain , the dwarf in the flask , the concept behind him was very deep and interesting(him wanting to be free from the flask at first then becoming greedier and greedier wanting to surpass humanity ) but overall i think he was lacking as a final villain , he is cartoonishly evil and his masterplan that btw could ve been stopped with greatest of ease if the main characters used their small brains , was kinda underwhelming and even generic . 
Sound 9/10
Excellent , opening 2 , 3, 4 ,5 are all great , the soundtracks are varried from sadness , to hype to dread , it music i can evoque every emotion possible from you .
Enjoyement 7/10
Despite the high expectations i entered this show with , i would say for the most part it paid of,  it had some pacing issues in the beggining and the middle , there was one episode about a random women giving birth that i feel it could ve been removed too .
Overall 7/10
In conclusion , full metal alchemist brotherhood is a very deep show , its not perfect by any means , but at the same time its very solid , is it the best anime of all time ? Hell no . Is it the best battle shonen out there ? Its not my fav personally but i can see why it is so praised . The exact score that i calculated is 7,8/10

I was definitely late in watching Fullmetal Alchemist Brotherhood, and even more late in writing a review because I finished the anime over 2 months ago. In addition, I actually finished the original Fullmetal Alchemist today. But despite my wrong order and lateness, I only have one thing to say about the show. 
Outstanding. 
I was very hesitant about watching Fullmetal Alchemist Brotherhood because I was worried of not understanding the storyline or not being fond of the characters and animation, but I'm glad I decided against it. 
I won't spoil either of them, but they are indeed very different stories and I overall prefer
                  Fullmetal Alchemist Brotherhood. 
The pace is definitely much better, the story fits together beautifully, and the events that occur are much more...preferable and enjoyable to say the least. This anime had about every good aspect that I could think for an anime to have. A good story, amazing characters, humor, sad moments, and moments that make you think. 
I usually adore any anime that involves a relationship between a family, and Fullmetal Alchemist Brotherhood definitely takes the cake for that in the struggles and obstacles Ed and Al face to triumph in the end.
It was a great watch and I highly recommend it, especially if you're someone like me who's hesitant about starting an anime with the unique background this one contains. Its worth it.

Brotherhood has the strength to appeal to the masses, which is why I believe it is a very strong anime. Whether you are just starting down the path to watching anime, or if you've been an avid watcher for years, this series still has the potential to reel you in. 
Every aspect of this show is pretty solid, especially the art, the story, and the characters. Some characters are not as likeable as others, but there's a nice ratio. The music was OKAY, as most tracks sounded pretty 'generic'. There's a few dull moments here and there (as with MANY other shows), but there are
                  also some great moments too. Brotherhood could be described as the perfect "mid." A very average show, but the best average show out there, which is why I think it has one of the biggest fan bases out there. Do I believe it deserves the highest rating on MAL (as of 1/23/2021)? Sure, why not?
I would like to point out that the anime came out in 2009! And compared to a lot of shows that came out during that time, this assuredly stands the test of time. 
This is also 100x better than the original series in my opinion, and the ending is much more fitting.

FMA brotherhood is great, In my opinion I would prefer FMA brotherhood than FMA. FMA brotherhood's story is imaginative and and has a great plot, The characters are memorable and it has great animation and good fights. The ending is perfect and i can see why this is the highest rated anime. 
A lot of people say this show is over rated, but i would say no because FMA brotherhood doesn't seem relevant now a days. FMA brotherhood is a great anime to start with and it has a great philosophy of nothing can be achieved without sacrificing something else in return.

My first review:
I dropped it but then rewatched it. The beginning is a little rushed (relations mainly) and not very good. And I found the action VERY weak, it had a maximum of 15 seconds of good animation every 20 ep. I mean really good, fluid, well choreographed and exciting. Okay, it gets exciting but, only because of the great direction. The real bad thing about it was the 'cuts' of a bunch of fights just to don't animate them, there were times when the camera just turned around, to someone who was watching (for example) and then turned back to the guys fighting and
                  the fight was over. There must have been a lack of funds. I saw so many people making a great deal out of it, when it wasn't. That's all I have to complain about. The rest is really good. The characters are very good and well developed (like 90% of the cast), the comedy was good, the music, the alchemy (what a well thought thing), the drama, the brilliant story, but it's all thanks to the EXCELLENT script, my god.

I am still quite new to anime in the sense I've watched more mainstream types, however, FMA:B is one of the best anime I have come across. I think what really sells the story is the rich character development as well as motive. When you look at different types of shounen, it's all reaching for the top. I do like those kinds of animes, however, it gives a different and warm feeling when watching this show. The family bond is one of the most important driving forces in this anime which the creators keep consistent. The only mark that was lacking was the art/animation style
                  since with the anime now lacks compared to most. (demon slayer lol) But, at the time of release (2009), this was one of the greatest. Sound is great, love the music. Love all the characters. Not as tear-jerky, but I do consider it pretty emotional. Any new anime watchers NEED to see this masterpiece. Probably one of the only 10s I consider giving out.

It was beautifully animated and there's not really any negatives that I see. I've not yet read the manga or fully watched the earlier series, but I completely loved Brotherhood.

My biggest problem with this show is its start, which is why I gave it 9/10 on the story because the intro doesn't really flesh out the characters because they assume you already know everything because of the original series, but this leaves the original having a great intro and this one having a really lackluster start. I was someone who watched the 2003 FMA and considered it to be the best anime I'd seen even though I hadn't seen a lot of anime's at the time. I had only heard of Brotherhood from the top 10 best anime of all time lists that I watched for recommendations. When I realised that Brotherhood was an authentic adaptation of the manga I bought it on Blu-ray and was completely blown away by how different (and better) it was to the 2003 version. 
Brotherhood is just a perfect all round show. Everything from the story, worldbuilding, characters and action just work together to create
                  something that is flawless. FMA:B isn't a show where the Story or Characters or Animation is the highlight of the show. Everything that is needed in a show is done to near perfection. 
The way it builds one of the greatest stories, worlds and characters in just 64 episodes is simply incredible. There's nothing more I can say about this anime because everyone's heard how great it is but it is truly one of if not the greatest anime's of all time.

A story about two brothers overcoming their greatest past mistake from childhood, they learn the harsh reality of fair trading with the supernatural, or in the case of what the anime itself calls it, "the law of equivalent exchange", and Fullmetal Alchemist Brotherhood makes this message perfectly clear all throughout. It masters many elements of the story it tries to convey, from fleshly developed characters, dynamic battle sequences, and the setting of the world these characters inhabit. It is all shown without feeling too fillerish or forced as well. This is an anime that I highly recommend to anyone looking for a shonen of top
                  quality, there is a reason why people say this is the best anime of all time. I just might agree with them, though I can't say for certain as I have a tough time deciding whether this is my favorite anime series or "One Piece" (And that is still ongoing).
With all that said, this anime is not perfect, sometimes the comedy while mostly good, can be a bit forced, certain jokes can be showcased during moments that don't call for them, whether it is directly after a very serious conversation or a very serious fight. I'm all for a good laugh but it's best to keep your comical moments far away from the very emotional scenes and they can appear very abruptly too. Thankfully, this doesn't happen too often and most of the comedy (while not the series' strongest point) is relatively good. Also another problem is the tiny handful of characters that annoyed me, like Mei Chang and Olivier Armstrong, this is merely just a nitpick as they aren't necessarily bad characters, just not well developed characters that I've grown to respect compared to a lot of others that are way better.
With all that said, Fullmetal Alchemist Brotherhood is a beautifully crafted story with moments of sadness, fear, excitement and happiness all blended together to form one of the best anime of all time that will stand the test of time and live on in anime history as a testament on what makes a good anime. To end this on a metaphorical note, "Human life is short lived and time is precious to every single person on this planet, but the sacrifice of watching all 64 episodes / 1408 minutes / 23 hours of this series is most certainly worth the time I gave away, I'd say that it's a fair equivalent exchange. :D

This is an astounding anime - heres why. the story starts off slowly, but as characters develop throughout the story, it blooms into this masterpiece of an anime. Theres many twists, revelations, and fun times in this anime. It's funny when it needs to be, and in other times it's intense or sad. The music is by far the best I've heard from any anime to date and I still listen to it often.

First of all I can definitely see why it's a lot of people's favorite anime. There's a reason why it's ranked so high. It also has some of the deepest feels in anime history. It's a different kind of feel than the psychological things that darker anime can throw at you. It's a simpler kind of feel. Although this show is about alchemy, it's very relatable. This show will make you want to hug your parents and siblings. This show just gives you raw emotion. There's nothing really to think about. Everybody knows what it's like to lose something that they love.
Story: 10
Our amazing main
                  character, Edward Elric, loses his left leg when trying to perform human transmutation to resurrect his mother. His brother's body disappears completely, so Ed sacrifices his right arm to bind his brother's soul to a suit of armor, making him a golem. His brother can't enjoy the simple things of life like eating. So they both go on an adventure to get their bodies back. I wanted to phrase the plot of the show in my own way, because I just want to emphasize how deep this show actually is. It will most likely make you cry. They really couldn't have made the story any better. So much thought and emotion was thrown into this anime. This anime is also the perfect length.
Art: 10
Very pretty animation. Definitely deserves a 10. I HAVE seen better, but that doesn't mean that this animation style and quality deserve anything less than a 10. I can only say good things about it.
Sound: 10
Going off of the feels of the overwhelmingly deep plot, we have the haunting chorus from "Lapis Philosophorum" and all of its forms. Also, this anime has 5 intros and outros, and THEY ARE ALL GOOD! It's really rare for that to happen. This soundtrack is perfect. Just as much time went into it as with everything else. That is apparent.
Character: 10
Okay, as good as EVERYTHING about this anime is, this is probably the best part. The characters are incredible. All of them. They are all deep and all have fantastic backstories. If they don't make you cry, I don't know what will. The main villain is really cool, too. Definitely in my top 10 villain list. I can't say ANYTHING bad about them, and I don't want to say any spoilers. So I think that I'll leave it at that. Also, there are some biblical references in some of the characters, which is interesting whether one is religious or not.
Enjoyment: 10
What's not to enjoy about this anime? I was so sad when it ended. I'm usually really critical about things, and I would critique it if I could. The ONLY thing I could nitpick is one thing during the end, and that's how a couple of our main characters handled a particular death, but I'm not going to spoil anything. But that's it, and that's me really looking for something to complain about.
Over: 10
Obviously I'm going to give this a 10. There are 10s across the board. I'm going to have to rewatch this anime with my dad, since he likes the anime that I show him. Anyway, this anime will always be close to my heart.

There isn't much more I could say with all the praise it already has, but I truly believe that Fullmetal Alchemist: Brotherhood deserves every bit of it.
The pacing is phenomenal; filler is minimal to nonexistent and every episode serves as another step forward. I know a few people who thought that the first few episodes were not explanatory enough, but one of the great things about it is its lack of unnecessarily long narratives; it gives you just enough background information without petulantly walking you through it.
FMAB is also one of the only anime that I prefer the dubbed version over the subbed. The voice
                  actors are fit fantastically in their roles, and the openings and endings were, for the most part, great. The animation was gorgeous as well, especially in action shots.
But I think the most important thing to be taken into account is the plot and characters. At its center, FMAB is about two brothers who have just enough flaws for you to emotionally connect with them, but not so many that it crosses the boundary into overly annoying. The length (64 episodes) allows for steady character development, whether it be for the better or worse. Even the villains have some sort of depth without making it seem like a rushed pity backstory. It can sometimes have crass humor (which serves surprisingly well as comic relief), but it is also harshly realistic; good people die and there isn't always a good reason for it.
https://www.philadelphiatruckingpros.com/
So go watch it! I hope you'll love it as much as I do.

I don't know how to word this out without sounding too biased, but here we go. First of all, I have not seen the original, 'Fullmetal Alchemist'. Now, this review is simply based on my own opinion and preferences.
STORY: 9
The basic plot is great, outstanding, even. It's about 2 boys who committed a 'taboo' and their journey to getting back their bodies. 
ART: 7
The art is great however, I'm not much of a fan with 'childish' or rather, some characters look like teens and not their own age.
SOUND: 10
Absolutely amazing. That is all, one of the few anime in which I never skipped the opening.
                  Soundtracks, background music, definitely adding to my playlist.
CHARACTER: 5
The characters are basically pawns or a 'plot' rather than a character. I mean, they are treated as a plot. I don't see much character development and if there were opportunities to, the character overcomes the problem and they learn close to nothing. Or at the very least, it isn't shown on their actions that they learned something at all.
ENJOYMENT: 7
Unlike other anime, there were definitely times in FMAB that made me distracted. I would often quit the site I was watching the anime and begin starting other anime, but it's more a 'me' problem.
OVERALL: 8
I mean, it's too far of a stretch to call it 'the greatest anime of all time' but I can't deny that it was a pretty good anime. Would recommend watching.

When compared to the first fma, it's more funny than dark, it has a lighter kind of humor and still remains serious. In a world of equivalent exchange we all know we've gotta give things up in order to gain things. Just like how I'm giving up time I could use for more productive things but I'm writing this review. Or how you'll give up all your time watching this awesome anime. The characters are great, there are many funny situations, and the animation is great along with the animation. The plot is wonderful and there isn't a boring moment in this show, there is
                  also a lack of fillers so the awesome keeps on coming.

Context:
This was one of the first shows I watched, so I am naturally gonna be biased a bit positive throughout this, do keep that in mind.
Story:
FMA:B is a relatively simple story, a classic adventure plot, with a bit of mystery thrown in (albeit one that resolves itself long before the show ends). However, what it lacks in insane depth and complexity, it makes up for in execution. Every single plot thread that gets brought up, pays off, most of them even coming in right to the end of the 64-episode run. No scene feels wasted, but equally, you don't have to be keeping notes of
                  every little event just to understand what's going on. It finds the sweet spot for flashing back, where it does it enough to remind you of what you need to know, but not so much as to become annoying. 
Art:
Visually this show is perfectly passable. Nothing ever looks particularly terrible in motion, save a few moments where they get a bit...pain. But equally nothing is ever particularly jaw droppingly pretty. Equally, it being a show from 2009, it has a few attempts of what look like CG. They're again, mostly ok, but do occasionally grate a bit. The art does not ever detract from the rest of the show however, which is the most important part.
Sound:
First and foremost, this soundtrack is a gift from God. Akira Senju knocked it out of the park with this piece of work. The sound effects are, as all good sound work is, unnoticeable, with one glaring exception. There's one instant where for reasons unbeknownst to man or god, all ambiance cuts out to have a man sipping tea in total silence. And the dub (yes, yes, hang draw and quarter me for watching dubs) is wonderful with all the actors giving top tier performances. 
Characters:
This is again an area where FMA shines through. It has a wide cast of characters, and yet each and every one of them feels deep, developed, and for use of a better word, alive. Even those who turn up only briefly, like General Grumman, have well fleshed out personalities. It's one of the few shows where nearly every death, for heroes and villains alike, brings a tear to my eye.
Enjoyment:
Yeah, this show is fun, in case you hadn't got that already. It can bounce seamlessly between laugh-out-loud comedy, brutally enticing action scenes and heartwrenching emotional moments, and everyone already knows this. It's a show that I'd heartily recommend to anyone who hasn't seen it, and even those who have should give it a re-watch. 
Overall: 
FMA: Brotherhood is one of my favourite shows, one that I keep coming back to, and one that inspired me to actually make an account on this site, to start cataloguing and see if I can't find a show as good as it. Watch it if you haven't, watch it again if you have.
Random Notes:
Favourite Character - Envy
Waifu - No strong contenders
Favourite Hero - Mustang
Favourite Villain - Envy
My poor green baby deserved better.

This is the most deserved anime to be described as a masterpiece i have ever watched . every piece of it is a master and the overall is a master of pieces . action ,drama ,comedy ,tragedy , military ,history , adventure, philosophy , fantsy even romance all together . a story about family and brotherhood , a story about friendship and a great story about humans .

I finally got around to watching this anime and quite honestly I am glad that I did, despite the confusion between this anime and Full Metal Alchemist. 
I frequently find myself in a 'funk'. The kind where I set myself in a panic when I think about things such as death. I feel like after watching this, I am a bit more at peace about the topic of death. 
There are many lessons to be learned from this anime that I think many people  need to take the time to learn. The main one would be the consequences the come from revenge/hate. 
The story
                  itself was written well and I hope to read the manga soon to compare the anime. 
The artwork is still good for the air time (2009). I thought the sound work was great! Especially when it came to Alphonse Elric and his metallic voice.
Well worth the watch and I highly recommend to anyone who has not seen it yet.

I rarely write reviews. In fact, this may even be my first. But I felt the need to say a bit about FMA: B. I neglected watching it for a while because I don't normally agree with the masses when depicting what makes a great anime. 
 I tried watching the first episode some time ago and it honestly bored me. I couldn't bring myself to keep watching it.  And now, I was running out of good anime to watch and decided I would finally go through it. 
 I can't say that I didn't enjoy it. But for so many people to claim
                  it to be the best or greatest anime ever, the only reason I can fathom that they would think so, is because they haven't really watched that much anime. Because it was far from being great in my mind. If anything it was really good at best. No better or worse than most anime I have watched.  It introduces so so many characters, many of which you never really get to learn a great deal about. The story however, was quite intriguing and did at least get a happy ending, which is more than what many anime get. Many other shows I've watched are lucky to get a second season, let alone a proper ending.
All that being said, I've watched hundreds of different shows, which may not be an immense amount to some people but even still, I likely wouldn't even have this in my top 20 favorites. It would be safely in the middle of the pack with the rest of the shows I rate an 8/10.  Good enough to keep me busy for a few days but not great enough for me to want to watch again.
So if you're bored and haven't seen it yet, then watch it. You'll probably enjoy it if you enjoy most anime.  But don't expect it to be the best thing created  since sliced bread.

What  could  I  say  about  FMAB ? Well , it's  an  excellent anime  and definitively  one  of  the  best  anime  of  all  time , if  not   the best , with  all the  aspects  getting  at  least  an  8/10.

through the anime, know  when  to  be  serious  and not  joke  around , it  feels  
 ike  they  are  real  persons.

If you plan to see Fullmetal Alchemist Brotherhood for the first time, be prepared to be horrified by the first episodes! It took me a long time to get used to the way things work. Many lives are taken, many shadows lurking and many sacrifices are made.
Between being immortal and having all the knowledge of God or being human, most people would choose the first option. But with Fullmetal, you'll find that even immortal beings would want to be human. Because there is nothing more precious than that, human being.
Every human life is extremely important, which is why human transmutation is impossible. What's more, one
                  of the basic things you'll learn about alchemy is that to have one thing, you have to sacrifice another. This is the equivalent exchange, and if you are smug you may lose your most precious possession.
Funny how I identified so much with the homunculi, human means representing the seven deadly sins, and I was so moved by them. Each farewell hurt my heart a lot. Even though they were horrible while alive, they also had feelings and suffered in silence.
I can't help but say that this anime filled with Plot Twists, with characters that initially make you angry, and then you will have an inexplicable affection for them - as well as vice versa. The fact is that some have the opportunity to start over, but not everyone is so lucky.
I confess that at first the atheistic thought of Edward Elric the protagonist bothered me a great deal. It seems that he thought himself on the same level as God. But over time, his maturity surprised me too much!
One is all, and all is one. This is the flow of life, this is the universe. Edward, whether alchemist or not, always was only a mere human being in this stream. No more than the others, but also with a significant existence for the universe.
Everything I may be saying may seem a little confusing. But the fact is, even you go out with a slightly different head after watching. There are so many things that make you reflect on the importance of life, feelings, compassion.
It also urges us to think about what "Truth" is. There are characters from many different cultures in Fullmetal, each with their own beliefs - or religion, their own culture. That's why I believe the truth was different for each one.
The Ishvalians, for example, believed in God Ishvalia. But Edward in the laws of the universe. We shape our reality, which is why it is different for everyone. The truth is in you. The truth IS you.
An anime that at first seemed so dark and violent actually has an immeasurable depth with good, sentimental teachings. Still being horrifying in many parts, of course. So much so that characters really die in this anime! It's all very unpredictable and you really get scared if someone is going to die.
Not like the other shounens where the protagonist is the strongest of them all, the good guys remain firm and strong and there are no big losses down the road. On the contrary, it is just the opposite. Although Ed and Al are strong, most of the battles are fought by other incredibly talented characters, mostly adults, not children. Precisely because everything is so unpredictable, the battles, which already had everything to be great, become even better!
Regarding art, I find the appearance of the protagonists basic, but of many other characters is beautiful. Nothing exaggerated, but nothing ugly. I liked very much. The soundtrack is also very good. It fits perfectly with every situation, and will no doubt leave a trademark in your heart.
Finally, the last episode showed us that there are new beginnings even after the end. This is the life. This is the universe. This is the flow in which we live. Yes, this is alchemy!

Non-spoiler review
I have always been curious about why FMA:B is rated no.1 in MyAnimeList. After watching it, I understood completely why it is rated no.1. Its very enjoyable anime for all ages and all kind of people. 1. Story = 8.5

Protagonist finds a way to undo his pact with a god. (about his body and his brother body) This adventure turn upside down by military act of their country and the reason behind that. However, around the end, things will get more intense. Most questions from the beginning of the story will be answer and what I'm really

This show does a pretty great job in progression of the body. At the start of the show, the protagonists will look like a child but in later episode. They will all grown up. Also, all the characters have their past which will project in the story quite well. At least most are share same experience in Ishwa civil war. This make every characters deep and had their motive. 
and most surprisingly is an awesome performance of homunculus in this show. They play a vital row around the end of the show. Their emotion and motive behind them is breathtaking. Their existence or meaning of life is well-design. 
2. Art = 7.5
 2.1 Character Design (5) = 3.5
Simple design and easy to remember yet unique in its own way. Also, suit with the setting of the world as well. 
 2.2 Background (3) = 2
I understand that its old but I can't give point more than this.
 2.3 Animation (10) = 8
For its age to be ten years ago, It has a very well-done animation. All the action that perform in story really match with anime nowsaday. 
3. Sound = 7.5
 3.1 Voice/Dialogue (5) = 5
All voice actors are expressed characters emotion into their voice very well. For example, you may not see face expression of 
Alphonse because he is an armor that walk around but you can feel how he was by the voice that he talks. I really like this. They nailed it.
 3.2 OP/ED (5) = 2.5
OP that good (2 out of 5) = "again", "Rain (レイン)" by SID
ED that good (4 out of 7) = "Uso (嘘)", "LET IT OUT", "Shunkan Sentimental (瞬間センチメンタル)", "Rain (レイン)" by SID
 3.3 OST (3) = 1.5
I only remembered the Main Theme. I don't recall any catching ost than this. So I give this half the full. 
 3.4 Special Effects (3) = 3
The sound of alchemist using is immersive. To create sound that no one hear before and feel like it's real is perfect for me.
4. Settings = 8.7
 4.1 Feeling with Genre/Enjoyment (10) = 7.5
I count this as Action-Fantasy then. It suit its genre pretty well. The action pretty short but they made it with care. 
I can say that this is masterpiece if it cut some unimportant things out from the story. Unrelated part make story too long and boring and I see a lot of this in early episode but in latter it's very lit!
 4.2 World Design (5) = 5
Great job with world design. After you pregress through the story, you will realize that there are more than two nations in north, east west and south. This intrigue me to look for more in the world of FMAB.

Well this is my first review. Out of all the animes i watched, this one stood out. The story was fast paced but was really interesting. I recommend watching the original fullmetal alchemist before watching this because the old one is slower in pace.
