First 10 episodes are really boring, in fact I left watching FMAB after them and thought would never look back. But from episode 11-20 it is just fabulous. It's here where they make you watch the next episode just after the current one finishes unlike the first 10 episodes. It is a visual treat to watch battle between Roy & ---(censored to avoid spoiler) in episode 19. Story is told in a fine way, art could have a bit mature like death note but this I guess appeals more to teens. Talking about sound 'Again' by Yui is great but other openings and closing songs
                  are just okay. Edward Elric is a very focused character. Alphonse lacks character development and is interpreted as a side hero, most of the times he is seen helpless and weak in battles. Few characters and topics who deserved more screen time and background story telling are Roy Mustang, Trisha Elric, Doctor Marcoh, water alchemy, flame alchemy, etc. Ending feels stretched over lot of episodes thus loosing the impact a little bit. Overall the ending is good but lacks a fulfilling climatic ending fight. Some major questions are left unanswered like what did ling do with the ps when he got back ?, can alphonse still perform alchemy without transmutation circles ?, etc. I wonder what would have happened if the Elric's didn't perform human transmutation, probably no one could have saved Amestris then. It's over dramatic when Izumi Curtis and her husband meets the Armstrongs. Sloth is a very badly written character.

Fullmetal Alchemist Brotherhood is an immaculate show. From the characters, plot, art style, action, and thematic elements: all of them are masterfully crafted. The show has very serious themes and asks the viewer very deep questions like: what it means to be human, how does one value sacrifice and loss, the plausibility of zero sum games, how far are you willing to bend or not bend your morals for your goal, and so many more. As well as touching on themes of brotherhood (of course lmao), loss/sacrifice, morality, mortality, human nature, genocide, friendship, love, as well as plenty of others. The characters are all very
                  nuanced and have much depth to them, all of the characters are complex in nature with tangible motives. The action is top tier and extremely entertaining. And the plot is so well executed and planned out, like the show ends with no loose ends. The soundtrack is extremely catchy as well. All in all, Fullmetal Alchemist Brotherhood is a masterpiece that I would highly recommend to anyone. A perfect 10 out of 10.

Fullmetal Alchemist: Brotherhood is an amazing anime. 
It deviates significantly from the previous Fullmetal Alchemist anime as Brotherhood follows the manga to the letter. 
One of the most interesting aspects of it is the hard magic system. Alchemy has specific rules and limitations that it sticks to. Deviations have explicit and important explanations rather than being a deus ex machina like a lot of magical systems tend to be. 
There is a lot of mystery and intrigue that's well delivered, makes complete sense, and is just plain satisfying as the plot unfolds.
That said, the story is pretty dark. If you can't handle villains doing truly
                  villainous things, I would recommend you not watch it. However, it isn't super edgy. The characters feel human and not entirely 2 dimensional or melodramatic.
I love almost every opening and ending theme. That's unironically one of my favorite things about it.
If you prefer dubs, the voice overs are pretty good. I fondly remember the Adult Swim reruns although I later watched it subbed.
My nostalgia is probably influencing the score a bit, but I honestly have nothing bad to say about it unlike other anime from my childhood. It's a solid anime and I highly recommend you watch it.

I used to watch this show back when I was around the age of 13 to 14 but I didn't get the opportunity to consume the series as a whole until I was 17.
At the end of the day, I am extremely glad to have finally gotten around to it because this show was an extremely well-executed series that balances a plethora of both subtle and diverse themes that can be enjoyed on a number of different levels and the series' ability to disguise more mature themes into the background of this entertaining story is almost matched by no other Anime I've seen before or
                  really ever since.
There are a few points however that keeps this series from being a 10/10 in my books that range from mildly cliche moments to a wonky first few episodes that don't really gain the true direction or direction of the series until a little bit further on.
Overall none of these issues is anywhere close to being noticeable through the first viewing and they're buried underneath so many other highly well-produced elements ranging from animation, sound design, story, characters/development and interesting lore.
This Anime is definitely one of the must-watch Anime of its time.

An indeed legendary classic anime. Fullmetal Alchemist: Brotherhood has all the elements a typical anime should have from comedy to sheer thriller. I loved the one thing about this show is Fullmetal Alchemist: Brotherhood has shown profound character development of each of its characters including Maria Ross to chimeras like Zumpano. In the end, the friendship part is most focused upon like in the Dragon Ball franchise. At the start, I was reluctant to watch it because of so many characters and a totally new technique in anime called alchemy, but I kept going for a few episodes, and then after that, this show build
                  up a great story and I couldn't stop myself from finishing. Overall it's a wonderful anime with the precaution that it's a little dark which only mature people can handle. I would say don't hesitate. GO FOR IT, it would turn out to be one of the best anime you've seen.

I have seen the original FMA. What's the difference??? This version is better than the original. The story, characters, everything is perfect. Every episode is canon and none of them are fillers, that's the best part. The villains were also likable. They are powerful in their own ways. If you noticed, the characters' appearances especially the MC is aging, which is also required to see the time during watching the anime.  Truly a masterpiece. It deserved the No. 1 spot. Very enjoyable to watch but not for little kids though, wait for them to reach 10 years old. 
SPOILER:
There is a scene that it
                  will leave you a great depression after watching that scene. Believe me,  I became depressed after 1 hour.
So watch it now, if you haven't. I'm also worried about the live action of this anime. Pls. don't ruin it.

Story - I'm honestly not a huge fan of the actual story. I can look passed potholes but some things seem sloppy or only halfway thought out (example, the gold toothed doctor). I don't hate the story but the fact the last fight because Edward punching shit in your typical Shounen fashion kind of really devalues the more interesting Team dynamic between Alphonse and Edward that they had in the beginning of the series. It's far from terrible and I kind of wish it gave more of an idea of what every character did after the events (it doesn't tell you what Olivier Armstrong or
                  Izumi Curtis is doing at the end) because the show felt like such an ensemble but instead it only focused on Edward and Alphonse and I find that to be a weakness. 
Art  - Gets an 8 because while I like the style and the visuals are great, it still suffers from the fact it spans 64 episodes and therefore there is a lot of people laying still in the frame with only mouth movement and the camera pans slightly. Otherwise, I like the style and some sequences look stellar. Very solid.
Sound - Some of the music is great, some of the music is very forgettable and serviceable at best. It was never distractedly bad and some tracks really elevated the scenes. The sound effects were fine, no complaints. The english dub is way quieter than the Japanese dub for some reason so switching between them was kind of a pain but this is a minor problem. Overall the sound was alright. I wanted to give a 7 for the sound but it gets an 8 because of those few tracks that really pushed a scene from being typical into fascinating.
Characters - The best part of this anime. I have heard arguments that the 2003 anime has better character development and that may be true. But the reason this show kept me at all was due to some of the really strong characters that I liked. So many very strong female leads which surprised me like Hawkeye, Olivier, Ross, etc. It wasn't perfect but it was by far the biggest reason I kept going with this show and the story is very much secondary to the characters and I'm fine with that.
Enjoyment - I only gave it a 7 because Story is such a huge deal for me. I know this show could have an even better story if the manga hadn't been written as it went and was planned a bit better in advance. I can't say I want to watch it all again anytime soon, I just wasn't that enamored with it and I think it's highly overrated for being ranked so highly... I just don't see why. It was alright though.
Overall - A solid 7. Definitely above your average anime, still don't understand the overwhelmingly positive reviews. It's elevated above most Shounen so maybe that's enough. I still prefer the HxH manga to something like this.

Overall Rating 10/10
This is one of the anime that you can call "Original".
I will keep myself from writing any big spoiler.
First of all, the most important one, the story.
At early episodes, you will see this anime as a general shounen anime with naive MC that doesn't want to kill anyone with a big dream on his heart of returning their original body back. But as the story progressed, you will see the exact differences. That is because instead of winning by being OP thanks to nakama power at the lasts second in a battle, you will often see MC either being saved by someone else
                  or running away instead. Me, who actually expecting a generic shounen, am impressed by how good the author played the cards on their hand. Even though he seems so OP, seeing the despair in that anime makes even me realize that his OPness is only a small being compared to the climax. 
The author also played the " sacrifice" and "equal exchange" thingy beautifully. 
As for Art and Sound, I'm pretty impressed too. The OP and ED fits pretty well, and the BGM were played out nicely. The art animated beautifully for a 2011 anime, though in one of the fighting scene, I realize some minor things like when there are 2 people join hand fighting a single enemy, while one of them fighting the other one just stayed still for a few seconds which is weird. But that doesn't stop me from enjoying the scene.
The characters development is one of the good thing too. I thought that most of the important role might become naive after meeting MC, but surprisingly they still maintained their former personality, but I still can see the character development. Some of the example were Roy and Greed.
It's definitely something worth trying, and doesn't leave a bad impression.

Although there were some important informations in the original than "Fullmetal Alchemist: Brotherhood", I prefer "Fullmetal Alchemist: Brotherhood" better because of better plot line. Furthermore, the art is really good that even my friends who watched it didn't realize that Ed beat Winry's height. I don't remember when that happened either...On the other side, it's really grotesque. There's a lot of blood and it's a surprise that some of the main charatcers didn't die of blood loss. And a lot of people dies. I'm not going to tell who, though.
Overall, it was an oustanding story. I hope you'll watch it too.
P.S. I heard that the
                  dubbed version was pretty good... I actually watched it and it was one of the best dubbed anime I've ever seen!

One of the things that defines a good anime to me is when it both stands the test of time and how it is when compared to other anime I watch.  With those things in mind, I can't say enough how much I thoroughly enjoyed this series.  I have watched ALOT series since watching it, and this one still ranks up very high for me, even almost 10 years later.  
It's funny, I enjoyed the original FMA series so much back when this came out that I avoided this series, in fear that it would somehow make me upset at the mishandling
                  of this series when compared to the original.  I waited until the series was almost over before starting it, and in the end I kicked myself for denying myself this series.  The story does get slightly weird at the end, but it cleans up nicely.  The characters are great, and you get alot of new characters to follow and like to really set it apart from FMA.  Art is good, this one has more comedy than the first series, and it is pretty well done.  This is a great series for new or seasoned anime watchers, and for me serves as one of the series I use as a ruler on how other series measures up.

Although I have not read the manga or watched the original version of Fullmetal Alchemist, I can say that this anime is the whole definition of perfect. From the animation straight to character development, was absolutely outstanding.
The story is very unique as the two brothers; Edward and Alphonse have one main goal, which is to get back their original bodies. Through this tough journey, they have to overcome many barricades with the help of others. The story is exquisite as it also focuses on the other characters apart from Edward and Al. Therefore each character gets their own sort of development and this gives the
                  audience a better understanding of every character. The way the story is set and how it slowly unveils the true intentions of the characters,  even the villains, makes the audience feel quite sympathetic towards them, even though they have caused a great deal of damage to others due to their selfish desires.
You could clearly see that there was a lot of time and effort put in the animation, which makes the anime even more appealing to watch. Fullmetal Alchemist is an anime that definitely gets better to watch as the episodes go on. Through part 1, the story is quite slow-moving but it suddenly picks up pace after part 2 and it puts you on the edge of your seat waiting for whats to happen next.
The sound was beautiful from the openings to the original sound tracks, which fit accordingly to its chosen scenes. This made the anime more emotional and tense. 
Overall the anime was impeccable with minimum defaults. I would definitely recommend to anyone.

Fullmetal Alchemist: Brotherhood, is quite an amazing watch. It nails its interesting setting, featuring tonnes of world building and fitting characters with individual values, cultures and reasons to fight. And therefore following the Elric brothers on their difficult journey to get back what they lost. Truly feels like 2 kids crossing paths with the worlds powerplayers and getting entangled in the nations larger conflicts.
To repeat myself, then it's an amazing watch, that at least partly deserves the praise it's recieving. However its really broad appeal may have hindered it's potential. 
At times it feels as if the series is having an identity-crisis. With deep dives
                  into serious story telling, such as multiple army-characters being haunted by their past contributions to an ethnic genocide. And other times it flips and uses very "anime" comedy such as slapstick humor to brighten the mood. Which (and I hate to say this) I actually never found genuinely entertaining as much as forced. The very "shonen like" conflicts and fights also end up feeling a bit the same. Like they were meant to entertain a younger audience. Losing a lot of the groundedness to the supernatural abilities, by introducing characters with so strong abilities it gets hard to understand them in context to the rest of the universe.
My biggest complaint with this series however, is something I have to reserve to the soundtrack, which is odd, as I usually don't put this much focus on the music, I've also never head anyone complain about this, so keep in mind this is exclusively my opinion.
But I disliked the soundtrack, not in itself, but mostly how it was implemented. Again, it feels like it's executed with a younger viewer audience in mind. There are many emotional scenes in this series that would actually be more impactful if there was different or even no music at all.
There are also "themes" that play at certain times. Such as when something is revealed, or there's mystery plot afoot, or when a fight is going on. It sounds good, but many of the tracks are so bold, loud and most importantly  overused, that it can get atrociously repetetive if you're binging the series. 
Now that might sound like an overly negative point to leave an otherwise positive review on. But I think it says a lot about what this series does right, if these are the primary concerns I've got. FMA Brotherhood is absolutely a series you must watch if you'd like to jump into an interesting universe you've never seen the likes of before, that will keep you entertained for all 60+ episodes. All I wanted was to address a criticism of the series that I haven't seen yet, and I still enjoyed it to the point that I'd only give it 1 point less in a review score that it has otherwise been recieving.

REVIEW WITH NO SPOILERS
FMA is one of my first animes (tha classic version)... and the story is really great and fun. But the classic and the Brotherhood has a lot of differences.
First, let's talk about this one isolated. The story is outstanding: all the philosofical and mystical elements, the metaphors... but it has some deffects. I thought the FMA classic had a lot of supporting characters but this one breaks records in this task!! And it's not like they are useless... actually there some really charismatc! But in some situations with them, it happens an EX MACHINA effect.
I could say that this version explores the
                  FMA universe way better than the other.
As well, the animation is better than the classic one... there are some deffects but the fights are better and the Bones Studio reached a high level and consistance here. And the end of this one is more satisfying and exciting.
So if you are looking for a fun mystical adventure and a really good (techincally) anime, here it is!!

Minor but basically irrelevant spoiler warning...Except the character section which is paragraph 5...do not read that if you do not want to literally have it ruined for you. But if you cbf any of it it's 10/10 overall in my very unprofessional opinion.
Ok so to be honest, this is the second review I have written for this anime. However I deleted the old one because I realised how susceptible I am to viewing something I just finished enjoying through a filtered lens and did not give as honest a review as I would have liked to. From the start I will say that regardless of
                  the re-write my rating is still 10. However it will not be as hard of a 10 it will be worth more because without the filtered lens I still view this as a masterpiece unlike many others which usually lose value in my eyes when I start to look deeper.
Let me say that in any other circumstance I would probably have given this a 9/10 for story. Even with the very...I struggle to find the word...um...issues with the final arc (Anyone who has watched the anime will know what I am referring to but do not let it differ you if you have not). The only reason I would drop the story to a 8/10 is because honestly it just does not start up as strong as the 2003 anime. And though I do not want to judge them the same, it simply is that we saw what it could have started as and if both combined the best aspects of each other I think story wise it could have come out as a true masterpiece. I can not drop it any lower than a 8/10 though because as far as story goes it is still a cut above the rest. Mainly due to the many intricacies of the plot that tie in so very well. With such weight placed on philosophy and the value of a soul everything feels like it has weight beyond the lives and world of those in the anime. I would like to note that putting story for 8/10 only occurred due to me trying very hard not to rate it higher as I truly do believe it to be great however I can not ignore the issues that came about.
Art was good for the time. I appreciate the lack of fan service being shoved in your face and the detail put into transmutations. The art style though appearing simple is actually one of my favourites and though it may be partly due to bias on that it could influence the rating. Objectively however I think the we'll say dusty style of art suits the old setting of the anime. 8.5/10 The mark being less than 9 is me trying to slightly dull the bias.
Sound was overall great honestly great. I remember the sound tracks being very classical but suiting the themes of the show and whatever setting they were played in well. Unfortunately I don't really pay attention to OST's most of the time. The openings and endings however were exemplary. I can say without a doubt that the second opening for good reason and how they used it will always sit in my heart fondly. All of the openings and endings however are great, foreshadowing most of the time is very creative, seen most in the first opening (I realise this is less about sound now but I usually judge sound like this due to lack of anything else I recall to judge when watching anime). Now I'll be honest, in most case I am way too impatient to sit through endings to anime (bar some exceptions). But in the case of FMAB I feel as if I have cheated myself to not let them run as they are some of the greatest you will hear and have the pleasure of viewing in my opinion. 8/10
Characters show continuous growth throughout the series. What can I say? Ok look there will be more SPOILERS for this one so prolly stop and just accept you should watch it if you haven't. If you don't care. Keeping reading. The series manages to fit a good deal of character development in for not being long running. Before I go into the good I must critique what they could have done better. Which falls into the first third of the series. Maes Hugh's needed more time for the viewers to care like in 2003 just as the Shou Tucker ARC needed that extra episode. I feel like Lust could have been done better but at the same time I am less effected by her treatment as I think however way she was dealt justice was done to her character in different ways. I want to first acknowledge Mustang overcoming the loss of a friend. Because to me that is what stuck out most in his character. Beyond him trying to become Fuhrer by moving up the ranks, and beyond being a guardian of sorts for the Elrics I think the most interesting part of his character was watching him trying to follow through with these self appointed obligations whilst trying to deal with the losses that life had dealt him. Eventually this became too much as he exploded on Envy in the end where his constant bursts of fire represented his uncontrollable rage. Who better to take it out on than Envy who is one of the biggest reasons for Mustangs pain? I think this is why he is a fan favourite. That and he makes f***ing fiery explosions by snapping his god damn fingers. I think Ed and Al Both place blame on themselves for each others fate and it was beautiful to see them go on in hopes to find salvation for themselves but more importantly each other. Ed feeling like he needs to bring Al back to his own body regardless of cost and Al regardless of the literally hollow shell of who he was is ready to and did give his life in order to save his brother. Only for Ed to give up what he believed would save them both to save his brother (Alchemy if you didn't guess). I could cover a lot more but I think I've made my point. 10/10 for character.
Enjoyment...seriously I mean look this may be a re-write but I still love the anime. Like the enjoyment section is where I am basically obligated to be bias in my results like come on. 10/10
Side note if you have any wish to discuss philosophy and psychology blah blah blah based on anything you might find in FMAB, some other anime or just for the hell of it, be sure to message me because I love that shit. Have a good one.

I dropped the original FMA after hearing that FMAB was a much better adaptation, so this review is solely based on my opinion of Brotherhood. The only way to truly explain how I felt while watching this is to explain every single element I enjoyed... and every single element I HATED. The basic review structure by Sound, Art, Story, Etc would not do the obvious problems the show has justice and I believe it is the biggest reason the show is rated so
                  highly.
Things I like: 
-Best OP of all time no cap
- almost all the characters. love Al and hawkeye
-the way "god" is portrayed
-Every single flashback. Seriously, anytime there was a flashback, the quality of directing and even animation would go up like 3 tiers.
-The general Idea of Alchemy and how it was utilized
-The philosophical questions; morality being subjective, what defines being a person, and Equivalent exchange. 
-That episode with the dog transformation thing. Just a solid episode. 
Things that Sucked:
-Every single "fight scene", I swear to god it went the exact way every single time. "Oh wow, you ar  homunculus. now u must die. oh wait but u wayy stronger and homies with the government so ill wait and pretend like I don't know sheee. ok now let's fight. U can heel and are LITERALLY IMMORTAL??!?!? Ok, mustang come here." Rinse and repeat that 7 times. Sometimes they get creative like when defeating Sloth but by then I was so bored. The problem with having so many villains is that after a while it becomes a huge chore to just sit there and watch them fight these meaningless battle when deep down you down that eventually it's going to end up in their favor without consequence. 
-When they stand around and discuss the plot forward. Yeah, I hated that.
Like in a good anime like Breaking Bad, It isn't a long conversation about the events in the plot that drives the story forward. It is the events and circumstances and the way the characters react/responds to them which drive the plot forward. 
-The relationships between the characters (except for Alphonse and Edward) 
I completely understand why people thought the relationship between Ed and Winry was handled great. but I think the complete opposite :D.  Ed and Winry have great chemistry as characters and obviously were gonna end up together and I liked that alot. The problem is that the part where they.. yah know... GET TOGETHER is completely rushed and feels so empty given the fact that Ed DIPS immediately after confessing just like his father. 
Also Mustang and Hawkeye... yeah that was supposed a THING. Felt like there was so much build-up and then I was robbed.
Final Thoughts:
This show is good when it good but is really boring most of the time but your brain tends to suppress it from your memory entirely. This show just feels so unsatisfying I almost want to say it should be continued, but I really doubt with the ending it can. 
Very Iconic, show is worth watching but definitely OVERRATED.
6.7/10

I went into FMA: Brotherhood without watching the manga or the original 2003 anime, so this review is from the standpoint of someone who really knew nothing about the series or source material.
I'm going to start with what I believe the series' main weak point is: I found the first quarter of the show to be somewhat of a confusing slog. The problem, in my opinion, is that the show introduces a large number of characters and threads at once, and bouncing back and forth between them hinders the development of any one of these threads. The advice many will lend regarding this is to
                  watch the first part of the original anime before jumping into Brotherhood. I can't comment on that approach, so my advice is to stick it through the first part of the show, even if the thought of "where is this all going?" comes to mind.
Once these threads come together a bit, the story is really fantastic and intriguing. I found myself constantly wondering how the Homonculi were going to hatch their master plan, and how the alchemists were going to attempt to thwart. The show has a knack for teasing some very intense, epic twists. Additionally, the show looks and sounds amazing and really sets the bar for other shonens. It has a really amazing art style throughout, especially when it comes to the dark, supernatural aspects.
I found the cast of characters on FMA:B''s journey to be enjoyable and interesting. Learning about everyone's backstory's was compelling and very much important to the overall story. Ironically, the two characters with the most boring/plain backstory were probably the two main protagonists. I initially was somewhat annoyed by Edward being little more than a cheesy caricature at first, but he does develop quite well and become likable.
The final quarter of the show was not quite as exciting as the middle portions, mainly because a lot of the mystery was wrapped up at this point, and what remained was for our heroes to defeat evil once and for all. I definitely enjoyed the ending of the show, but the show still really shines in its middle, and the thrilling intrigue of that portion is what makes FMA:B such a fantastically rewarding show.

There's a reason this is #2 on MAL. I originally didn't want to watch this because I binge watch all animes, so 64 episodes seemed too time-consuming. BUT after finally being nagged by my friend to watch, I did, and I was sucked into it. It's so worth the time it takes!
The plot is action-packed but incorporates some deep themes (e.g. nature of humanity, divine power, family) and light-hearted moments as well! 
The art is great. Everything is full of color, and the contrast between duller scenes really serves well to emphasize the more sullen nature of them. I also think the classic anime expressions
                  were incorporated very well. The battle scenes are depicted amazingly too.
I really liked the soundtrack, though it doesn't make it my top 1.
I think the character development was good, and it was present in supporting characters as well! In fact, I'd say the character development in one of the supporting characters matches (or even exceeds) that of Ed himself. The only complaint I have about the characters is that Winry seems to become irrelevant towards the end of the series, which was a bit disappointing.
Overall, this is a great and must-see anime. If you want action, it's here. If you want humor, it's here. If you want deepness, it's here. 
One thing I find particularly interesting is how although this anime/manga is probably the most well-known shonen, it was actually authored by a woman. I liked observing the contrasts between the various female protagonists, but that analysis is just for me :)

I just finished watching FMA Brotherhood AGAIN after a few years of not rewatching, and once again I cried and laughed with the characters and practically devoured the entire show. It’s just a piece of art - interesting and captivating from the first episode to the last, only one filler/recap episode (and even that one offers new insights), a great (first) opening, a lovable and diverse cast and many deep and intriguing storylines woven together in a net of questions and answers that won’t let me put the show down until I watched the entire thing through in a matter of days - in fact,
                  this show was the entire reason I just did pretty good on a final exam yesterday, because I only allowed myself to watch as many episodes as I revised that day! Also the length of the anime is PERFECT - enough to fully dive into the world, but not so much that it stretches beyond something you can’t watch and finish in a few days and weeks. The ending is very satisfying - hurts just enough, leaves you wanting more just enough, but also satisfies plenty and doesn't leave you hanging (which is pretty important for me when picking up an anime and devoting days of my life to it)! 
All in all, this might‘ve been the best time I’ve had with the show ever since I first watched - since it‘s been a few years, I’d forgotten many details and some more major plotpoints, but still knowing the characters and their journeys well enough, I connected to them on a level I hadn’t been able to on my prior viewings. Maybe because of my prior knowledge, maybe because I’ve grown as a person myself since I first watched this at like 16 years old. Especially Ed - I liked him a lot in my prior viewings already, but he might’ve just overtaken my other favourites in this show and become one of my overall favourite characters in anime in the span of this rewatch (what a truly basic pick, especially with having had Mustang as a favourite before.. probably half the populations top two, at least after episode 19). Anyways - legit bawled my eyes out on the outro - had a great time 10/10. 
To break down:
The art has aged a bit at this point, but it still looks very good - just not an anime I'd recommend on the basis of visuals purely (7). The sound is petty good aswell and I adore the first opening, but overall the sound is not as outstanding as some other animes I've seen (8). For the characters I'm inbetween a 9 and a 10 - this show is full of diverse and interesting characters and some great story arcs. I'm leaning slightly towards the 9. Lastly, for enjoyment and story I'm giving 10s, because I enjoyed every minute of watching this AGAIN, for at least the 5th time now (maybe more, I didn't start counting my anime consumption until I was in deep already). I absolutely love how many deeply intriguing plots are woven into the main storyline for it to still run at just 64 episodes - without feeling rushed or overexplained at any point!
I should really finally check out the original some day now...

While many series can hold the passing interest of an audience due to novel concept or execution, create hype by playing up a recent trend, or revamp an old idea with some original magic, Fullmetal Alchemist Brotherhood delivers on all fronts from start to finish. 
In a world where Alchemy has trumped science  ,two brothers embittered by the loss of their lone mother pledge to use forbidden methods to resurrect he. Suffering terrible consequences, the two are forced to embark upon a journey that will lead them across the continent, as they experience war, tragedy, and an evil that coils around the very heart
                  of the land. 
Whereas the first series focused in on a smaller number of set pieces and actions, Brotherhood roars out of the gate and almost never lets down the pace. With every episode devoted to furthering the plot arch's, the story is very focused and driven. Though it lacks some of the fun that was exploring characters on "off-days" in the original series, it compensates with action that keeps you glued to the screen. 
The animation was top-notch, with many of the abilities used my the Alchemists wonderfully rendered. The world is party static in terms of interactivity, by the cast chews up the scenery and spits it out at every turn, so this is hardly the focus.
While the soundtrack to the original was appropriate, if noticeably re-used, the emotional connect with numerous tracks is a testimony to how well-placed much of the score was. From the overture to the haunting, Chaconne-sounding end, it was a memorable experience. 
The characters are universally fun and different, a particularly enjoyable exercise being to contrast the differences between the series. My only criticism is that some of the characters lose some depth due to a larger cast in this series; this being more than compensated for by a widely different and fun group, plus a better realization of the romantic sub-plots.
All-in-all, another resounding champion of the genre. The series is the heavyweight hitter for accessible, fun and mature treatment of all the topics it broaches, and is a must-see for anyone interested not only in animation but quality cinema in general.

Hi,
Well, let us first of all talk about the story very briefly. Two sons lost their mother and sought to recover her. They became alchemists, but their attempt was unsuccessful, one of them lost his body and his soul was locked in a body of iron, and the other lost parts of his body; In this show, we will see their adventures as they strive to return what was taken from them.
I think everything is clear for now, but .....
The show itself is very interesting, wonderful and beautiful, the effects and sounds deserve a 9/10 rating, the graphics and animation are at a very good
                  level, but the realisation and the story, here I want to clarify some points:
The story is great and good, but unfortunately it is not original. You may see several anime when you see that the hero has lost something in the beginning, then the adventure start, same thing here, so the story here needs to be renewed, we need new ideas that not make me feel "Oh, I saw  some show like this anime before ";
The realisation has several question marks. Yes, the events are somewhat fine, but there are scenes in which you will wonder about "what does the producer want to tell me here?" I don't want to spoil you, so I'ill stop here.
And now the question that haunts you now: Should I watch this anime?
I will answer: Yes 100%, you will not regret every minute of this anime. FMAB deserves to be fully evaluated, although I think that a 10/10 evaluation is too much for him, but we all have different a point of view. 
So yes go watch it it worth it

FMAB is a darling of anime. I think it's good, but not as great as
people say.
This review will mostly be negative, but here's the positive. 
- The story. The story is beautiful. At face value, it's the story of
  two brothers, Ed and Al, journeying to recover their bodies after
  committing Alchemy's taboo: human transmutation. Their journeys take
  them far and wide, pit them against enemies both human and monster,
  and force them to face their fears. And in the end, they return back  home, to the place they were in their innocent days, away from the
  crazy world of monsters, conspiracies, genocide, and the like. 
  However, it's also the story of Scar, the manifestation of revenge for
  a downtrodden people, and his journey of reconciliation. It's the
  story of Hohenhein, and his journey from slave 23 to being forced into
  an immortal body, facing a seemingly insurmountable enemy in a
  conspiracy that could consume the world. It's the story of Roy
  Mustang, and his journey to turn the country he loves around with a
  band of comrades willing to descend with him to hell.
	The story starts out slow, but once it picks up, you're hooked. You're
  glued to the screen, pressing the next episode button.
- It's a classic shounen. This is both good and bad, but if you like
  classic shounen anime, this one is exactly it. You know the good guys
  will win out in the end, you know there'll be great reveals about
  characters' pasts and how they interrelate. If you like this kind of
  anime, this is the one for you. 
Now, for the negative. 
- The characters. Above, I seemingly praised the characters. Yes, I
  liked their concepts. But I didn't like many of the characters
  themselves. Almost all of the characters felt one-dimensional. Ed and
  Al were standard goody two shoes shounen protagonists. You know that
  they'll never sacrifice their friends for anything. You know that
  they'll fall for silly tricks of the enemy, until of course the grand
  final plan occurs, at which point they'll have predicted everything
  the enemy does (luckily FMAB doesn't have this issue too much, but I'm
  making a point). The other characters are the same. Whenever any tough
  decision arises, you pretty much already know what the characters will
  do.
	Furthermore, there's very little development. Ed and Al seem barely to
  change over the course of 64 episodes. The other characters are the
  same.
	As for the other characters, many got basically no development at
  all. This is fine, but it docks some points for me b/c it detracted
  from the story. I mean, really, Kimblee's men join their group just
  like that?  And then furthermore, in every scene after, they're just
  there. This is standard in shounen, but for such a masterful (and
  mature) story, I was left a little disappointed.
- The world. Usually when I digest some piece of fiction, I can tell
  whether the author did significant worldbuilding beforehand. In this
  case, my verdict is no. 
	There are small details that bug me. What are the power levels of the
  various characters? Ed and Al were completely defeated by Scar the
  first time around, but later they're an even match? Wrath completely
  beats up the first Greed, but the second is fine? As usual with
  shounen, every competent character seems a reasonably equal match for
  every other, which makes no sense. If you have a gun, you beat a guy
  with a sword, and a guy with a sword beats a guy with just his bare
  hands. It isn't rocket science. 
	There are also issues with alchemy. How is it Ed can transform a car
  into a completely different design? Actually, why does Ed usually just
  transform his arm into a short spear-like thing? Why isn't Ed using
  alchemy in more clever ways? At some points, there appeared to have
  been limits to alchemic power, but then we are shown them creating
  massive platforms hundreds of feet into the air. Speaking of which,
  why are there so many alchemists, each with their own special name?
  Shouldn't there be more systematization? Mustang's flame alchemy seems
  pretty OP, how has no one else figured out how to copy it? And
  furthermore, why has the military not tried to get the secret of it
  out of him?
- Comic relief. There's random comic relief. Really random. And
  unnecessary. 
Bottom line: this is an anime you watch for the story, through and
through. Don't expect anything too meaningful. But it does what it sets
out to pretty damn well.

This animation is a story of a paranormal phenomenon called alchemy and the alchemist who manipulates it.
All alchemists and non-alchemists are unique, and there are various types of alchemy, and you can feel a very attractive view of the world.
Elric, Edward is a so-called genius with a peculiar talent, a boy but well known as "Fullmetal Alchemist".
But the story is not a monotonous success story, and Ed feels frustrated, conflicted, and defeated by other alchemists. Still, he keeps moving towards his purpose.
I recommend it because you will get a very good feeling of satisfaction after watching the final episode.

FMAB is a good anime. Everything in this show is good wheter it is the concept of the story, the characters, the soundtracks and so on. But the main problem of this anime is like I said. Everything is good (except for the comedy that was horrible, childish and overused, which remove a lot the impact, the seriousness  and emotions of certains scenes), but there's nothing amazing. 
There's nothing in FMAB who blew my mind away. Not even the philosophy of the serie (which was the main point of the serie).
I noticed that the author of the anime decided to not take risks this
                  time and mainly wrote this story to please the fans. It was most likely a fans service anime which i understand why it is at the top and most likely recommanded by others. 
For least to say, it's the perfect anime for teenagers. The story isn't hard, the plot is predictable and easy to understand, same for the philosophy which is at the level of a high school student. It's a good anime to just sit down and enjoy. I understand why it's so popular, but if you are older, i would say 21+ don't waste your time, you are most likely gonna drop it. Tried to watch it again at 24 and that wasn't it anymore.
It's a 7/10 for me

There are anime that you have to watch. There are anime that are overrated and underrated (in your opinion and my opinion.) There are anime that go as quickly as they entered on in the scene. And yet this show always stayed. As a reminder of how to do a shounen correctly. FMAB is hands down one of the greatest pieces of art ever to come out of this medium. And it is great that this site advertises this show as an essential watch for everybody, veterans and newcomers alike. The show has now been talked about for over a decade, and will be talked
                  about for decades to come.
Scores:
Story - 10/10
Art - 9/10 
Sound - 9/10
Character - 10/10
Enjoyment - 10/10

My first anime and my eternal love. I cried that's how much I cared for the characters. I was suggested to watch this and was rather skeptical but it truly lived up now I am an anime addict. The soundtrack is perfection the story telling is immaculate and the quality is astonishing a must watch for everyone!
One will come to a sad realization that FMAB is one of the best things ever made with a minute amount of content leaving you with such an imprint. The lack of plot holes the lack of issues or complaints will leave you longing for much more but nothing
                  will ever fill the gap. There are only 2 shows in the whole world that reach such a level of excellence that's FMAB and ATLA.

SPOILER FREE***
FMA Brotherhood is the peak of anime, my personal favorite series, and the only anime I can stay deserves a 10/10. The creators went above and beyond and the result is outstanding.
Story:
Incredible story, it does speed through the first 10 episodes but its not something that will detract from the experience. The story is both enjoyable and really builds the world around the incredible cast of heroes and villains.
Art:
Really high quality from start to finish.Sound:
They really topped the original series with its excellent music and spot on sound.
Characters:
You really fall in love with the characters, feel their pain, excitement, and wonder as we follow their adventure.
Enjoyment:
Will have you laughing, sometimes crying, and interested basically the whole way through. Intense and really sticks the landing too.
Overall:
FMA Brotherhood exceed and far surpasses its predecessor. Some will recommend watching the original FMA but in my opinion its completely fine to watch Brotherhood without bothering. This iteration is just complete on its own. Everything is true to the original excellent manga and they pulled everything off amazingly cleanly in its adaptation. Please don't miss this series, it is the best of the best in all of anime.

I'm a be real I haven't really seen the 2003 FMA, not that I hate it or anything.. but they really should have waited until the manga was finished.
So FMA:B huh? Where do I begin.. the story about being about 2 brothers: Edward and Alphonse Elric, their main goal trying to get their bodies back. They're trying to find something called the "Philospher's Stone" that is powerful enough to fulfill their goals. A doctor warns them it's "The Devil's research" if they try to find out how to make it.
Don't wanna give too much away but this show isn't afraid to get dark, because early
                  on.. it gets messed up real fast. It's still a good show, Edward is still trying to work through his trauma.. slowly but surely! Lot of the characters are cool, Ling being my most favorite. The fight scenes are amazing and I love the comedy! If you don't mind a show to go from 0 to 100 then FMA:B is up your alley.

Fullmetal Alchemist Brotherhood is a lopsided experience. 
The world and plot are well-crafted. This is its strong suit, the biggest pulling factor of the show. Its an epic quest with heartfelt moments along the way. Its what anybody would expect out of a fantasy action series. The setting takes place in an area inspired by early 20th century late industrial Germany, with obvious references to WWII, among some other locations being other countries with their own cultures, giving it a sense of geopolitical worldliness. Although the series starts off with a rough first season, mainly only there for exposition, it progresses pretty well into the
                  final sequences of the show, setting up characters and uncovering mysteries along the way. There's a great sense of finality within the last few episodes that really give the series most of its praise. The fights were really well animated and choreographed, I loved the way the music would swell during certain moments. I found the whole philosophy and morality of the show to be uninteresting. With all these cool inspirations, including a literal f***ing gnosis moment, where Edward meets with "Truth," and has literally all of the world's sophia poured into his brain, there's definitely an empty spot where it could've had an extra layer of religiosity and exploration of philosophical beliefs in "goodness." Hell, this show is a big reason why people even know about the esoteric magick of alchemy.
 Most of the key plot points had good pacing, not a part really sticks out in my mind that lasted too long, although i didn't like when they were in the winter place, that was really boring. The little side stories that existed to make the world seem large in themselves were mediocre sketches. The priest episodes in the beginning were terrible. Also the moment when the guy releases the dummies and they fight them for idk like 5 episodes is really really boring and absurd. Highlights for me were Scar, Ling, Greed, Wrath, and Kim Lee scenes. All in all, it has a sort of a grand building up to the final episodes, which made it cool. The journey along the way isn't as interesting though. This is because of the lack of interesting characters within the show. 
Edward Elric is a generic shonen protagonist. His whole personality revolves around the motive to "Get Al & I's bodies back," which is more of just a personal goal than anything laudable or fiery. Alphonse is pretty bland in this series, he mainly just plays the little brother troupe, and has no actual character development without Edward. Winry is a sorry excuse for a female side character. Its kind of hilarious how badly she is written. Von Hohenheim is also some lame, later introduced character, who only serves to progress plot and nothing else. His backstory is cool but his character is super duper lame, a lot of lost potential. The homunculi are all unremarkable except for Greed. His character is this reject from Father, a confused loner-leader sort of bastard, who finds his own morality along the way, and in fact even shows up Father in the end, which makes his whole development complete. Later on when He and Ling share the same body, it creates a sort of synthesis of characterization, one of my favorite dynamics in the whole show, I just love it when they interact. Kim Lee is also one of my favorites too. Just a genuine cool guy strung along with these idiots. The military crew are all merely problem solvers. There's scenes with interactions between Mustang and Hawkeye that could've been expounded upon, but there's a certain lack of personality from the whole team. Mustang is the only notable one, but there was so much wasted potential that could've made him more cool. I found his scenes to be lackluster in important dialogue. Just generic really. Its clear they went the route of having a diverse cast of characters, constantly making blank interactions, for the shonen world aspect rather than making any memorable people.
The comic relief of the show is god-awful. Its almost cringeworthy how reused the joke of annoying screaming. I find it extremely grating to the experience as a whole, making a lot of moments annoying to sit through because of the terribly written dialogue at times. It takes away from the experience more than I'd like it to.
It did what it set out to do, make an epic story, some cool fights, and used only the bare minimum characterization necessary to make it seem "cohesive." The artstyle is generic, yes, but not bad. Animation is pretty good. Soundtrack sounds tight. 7/10

The show did characters very well. There is a wide array of main and supporting cast that each have
their own values, personalities, etc. Most are very memorable. 
The character development was done pretty well, notably so in the antagonists.
	The world building is another thing that the show did incredibly well. The various nations, the history, the
laws, etc. make it all very immersive and well fleshed out. Nothing much else to say here other than it was great.
	The art is one thing I had some issues with. I didn't really like the art style from the get-go, it felt 
simple (though that isn't inherently a bad
                  thing, it didn't seem too well done here). "Easy on the eyes" is not always
a great thing. That said, the animation was fantastic for most of the time. CG was only used for a couple things 
(envy and father in their "true" forms), though it wasn't used very well. Many parts during alchemy and action had 
me very impressed, and it was very fluid and crisp. 
	The show had very good sound design as well. SFX were well made and fight scenes were put together cleanly.
The OPs and EDs were good songs and I think they fit the show pretty well, but none of them were really memorable-
I can only remember the tune of one off the top of my head and I just finished the show. Additionally, the themes 
in the show itself were especially forgettable. A show like death note had me humming to L's theme every time it came,
but I didn't ever even notice the BGM of the show and I don't think much was gained from it. The voice acting was
done very well (sub), and I've heard a lot of the eng dub from clips and I know it's good as well. 
	The plot was well done, though it was simple. The ending was by far the best part - it was exactly what you 
wanted... though that brings me to my next point. A lot of it was predictable. None of the dramatic moments were
impactful whatsoever, except maybe Hughes' death (though with all the monologuing he did about his family and such
it wasn't hard to tell that something bad would come of him). More on this in the next section. On top of that, I
never really felt "gripped" to the series - in fact at some points the only thing keeping me watching was the fact
that I had already seen so much of it (briggs arc). The first quarter of the show was pretty good, the second was 
better, the third was mediocre, and the fourth was best.
	The execution of the show was decent. I think the pacing was fine for most of it - the start could be slower
and the third quarter could be faster - but overall it was good. I think the show could have greatly benefited from
a more serious tone - it would make the dramatic moments more intense, heighten the suspense, and make it feel like 
there was something actually on the line. The lightheartedness of it all made it feel like nothing was important, 
really (I know that's a bold statement but I can't really think of any other way to put it). A component of this
was the all-too-often comedic relief and chibi moments. I feel like many of the moments that could have been heavy
and intense were ruined by a reused joke followed by a chibi sequence (see: ed is short). Most of that, however, was
only in the first half and as things got more serious it got much better. My final nit to pick is that the show does
too much telling and not enough showing. Sure, Ed and Al want their body back. It's the whole driving force of the
show. But I think they don't show us why - they show us all the benefits of Ed's metal arm which gives him a weapon
and durability, and Al's body that never gets cold or tired. However, they tell us a million times why they lost
their bodies and that they need to get them back, without showing us the psyche issues or all the nights Al needs to
stay awake because he doesn't sleep. The closest thing they do to that is talk about how Al wants to eat and taste 
again, but I feel like it could have been so much better in that regard.
I made a lot of criticisms, though I did genuinely enjoy the show a ton. I expected a lot out of it because it is the number one anime on countless sites, but I just don't think it lives up to that name. I thought on whether I would give it a 9 or a 10 for a long time, but I've settled on a 9 - though it's easily the highest 9 on my list.

Somewhat spoilery review of why I love this show. I'm not really going into an objective breakdown of what good anime should be, but I want to talk about why the story of this series is such a compelling one that I still think about today:
Now over 10 years since the completion of this series, I've looked back and wondered if Fullmetal Alchemist: Brotherhood was as good as I remembered. Why would anyone want to go back and watch it today? Is it really a classic masterpiece that still holds up, or is it a fairly standard action show by today's standards? First of all,
                  yes, I think it's still amazing. This was the show that got me into anime and I still love it.
I need to start by noting that I think the goal post has moved for shonen anime today. The best of the best as of 2020 and in the last few years are absolutely gorgeous with stellar action choreography, animation, and effects. Fights are hype and exciting as heck. And that's what we're all here for when it comes to shonen. 
When the original FMA and FMAB came out, its contemporaries were the likes of Dragon Ball, Naruto, Bleach, One Piece, Inuyasha and Fairy Tail. While many of these shows are still beloved today, they did kind of drag on with tons of filler, and you had to wait ages to get to the good fights. Shonen of this era tended to have high peaks but pretty low lows as well. Full Metal Alchemist: Brotherhood, however, with its comparatively low runtime, is remarkably consistent in its quality throughout.
FMA stood out in another way. What these other shows provided was a constant stream of cool fights, cool powers, cool characters, and sense of constant and inevitable progression as we watched the protagonists become stronger and stronger, and we consequently became invested in their growth. However, FMA kind of doesn't do that. There are fights, sure, and I think some of them are pretty cool particularly near the end. But the steady stream of one-on-one fights, the battle of powers, wits and will, that anticipation of "Oh, man! Ed and Scar are finally going to a show down and it's gonna be epic!" just doesn't materialize as much as in other shonen. Honestly, this show seems to be barely about the action sometimes. So, why watch this when there are so many hype shonen anime coming out today that drip feed better animated adrenaline filled goodness straight into your eyes?
FMA pulls the same trick as another one of my other all time favorite anime, Mob Psycho 100. The characters all start out incredibly powerful. There are a couple of level up moments, but in general, the show isn't about the main characters getting more powerful. This is where, in my review, I now proudly exclaim, "It's actually about the characters!" but I think it goes a bit deeper than that. They still have villains to defeat. Incredibly powerful villains. And if we're not getting stronger, then how do we overcome them? Every major hurdle, every major fight displays the power of one thing: Collaboration. Oh gosh, it's just the power of friendship thing again isn't it?
Our connection with humanity, nature, and all. The duality of the self and others. Everything in this show is about that idea. Every villain sees human connection as a weakness and attempts to destroy it, to exploit it to manipulate other for their own selfish gain, or to elevate themselves above it often through an abuse of religious zeal or scientific power (aka alchemy). Scientific knowledge and religious belief are notable some of the most important core values for many of the main characters. These are things that should be used to serve others and provide hope in their eyes, but are instead twisted into tools of destruction by those who care only for themselves.
Every regret, mistake, or potential dark path for the protagonists involve them forgetting their connections to the rest of humanity and nature. The Elric brothers get struck down by god itself for forgetting their place in the cycle of life, Scar becomes consumed by revenge and mercilessly hunts down those that defy his personal creed, Dr. Tucker is desperate to continue by the progress of his work no matter the cost, Mustang and his crew are haunted by the war crimes they committed in Ishval. And many of these lapses in judgement are caused by the loss of their most cherished and personal connections. For Ed and Al, it's the loss of their mother. The Ishval war starts with the death of a child. For Scar, it's his brother and people. Mustang almost succumbs to destructive revenge himself due to his losses. And the few sympathizing glimpses into the life of the villains all revolve around their own desires for connection, be it Envy's, well, envy of humanity or Fury's pride in his own free choice of his wife.
But what ultimately saves each of them, and the world as a whole, are the vast connections that remain. Every protagonist is dependent on others for support and healing, for their aide and strength, for their knowledge and ideas. In so many shows, the main character is destined to seize victory through their own willpower and strength alone. But in Full Metal Alchemist, none of us are as strong as all of us together. But only if we recognize our mutual dependence and strive to serve others as well. Which each and everyone one of the heroes does. The eventual defeat of the villains requires the collective effort of nearly every character we've met in the show. 
The show isn't about the power of friendship or cool fights. It's about what it means to be human, and our individual role as a part of humanity and the world. All is one, and one is all. And that story of humanity is brilliant one that is told expertly from the first to last episode of Full Metal Alchemist: Brotherhood.

How dare the creators of this show forget about best girl Sheska?
At it's core, Fullmidal Alchemist: Brotherhood is a bog-standard Shonen anime. Like most Shonen, this show makes it hard to care about anyone with a bloated, uninteresting cast (aside from a few great characters) it doesn't bother fleshing out. In equivalent exchange for sticking more closely to the manga, Brotherhood sacrificed almost every character having a bigger role and more development that was present in the 2003 show. For example, Lust is turned from a homunculus pondering her own mortality and desiring to be human by any means necessary even if it meant going
                  against her allies in the original show, to a generic Saturday morning cartoon villainess lackey with no goals or agency of her own, known only for her huge pair of tits and drops out of the story fairly quickly in Brotherhood having done nothing of note or importance, never to be brought up again. Honestly now that I think about it, this whole show is like a Saturday morning cartoon a.k.a a Shonen anime. There are no stakes and anytime anything bad happens that would make the show more interesting, it is immediately reversed (especially in the last few episodes).
When deaths happen, it's drawn-out and cheesy with people you don't care about giving their last words for 20 minutes straight while other people you don't care about scream their name over and over. Comedy is much more prevalent in this than in the 2003 adaptation, which gets annoying when it's used in scenes that are supposed to be completely serious.
It's such a shame too, as the dub is fantastic, there were many times where the funny moments made me keel over with laughter, and any scene with Roy Mustang (and Sheska) is guaranteed to be phenomenal. But ultimately, I just can't see anything in this show that warrants it to be the #1 anime of all time. It's not even good enough to be the best Shonen anime. So to watch people claim it's the best anime ever makes me laugh.

This anime is by some reffered to as the best anime ever, and while i can certanly see why it on some points could be a contendor there are just way to many things that rub me the wrong way for me to agree. 
First of all is the ending. In my oppinion it is one of the most anticlimactic endings i've ever experienced, and that's not to say it was bad. In most other animes i've watched it would've been good enough. But my problem with it is simply that it's a letdown. I spend the series watching these people grow, become stronger and
                  just generally become more fleshed out character. Just to then have the main villain become the most steriotypical bad guy and start shooting lasers from his hands. And that's not even mentioning the METAL-ALCHEMIST getting stuck to a rock by a METAL object which results in his brother having to sacrifice himself. We also have the brother who many previous times during the series has repaired himself with alchemy, but for some reason he doesnt do it. This actually happened a bunch of times, if there is a reason i didn't understand it. 
The reason this bugs me is that the beginning was great. The chimera episode was amazing and i loved colonel roy mustang. The mystery Führer Bradley was also a very dope addition. And this is the reason these little inconsistansies and poorly played out moments annoy me so much. Because i was expecting so much more.
Now of course there are positives. The soundtrack is amazing, i give it a 10/10 and i frequently listen to it just for enjoyment. The art is also amazing, these are some of the best fight scenes i've ever seen. The characters are also wonderful, as previously said i absolutely love Roy mustang, but Bradley, Riza, Marie Ross, Lin and Greed were amazing. The only reason i didn't give the show a 10/10 in character is because of the main character. I think they are very bland and while Alphonse is fine Edward just annoys me so much. And since the main characters often are the most important i have to drag it down a bit. Luckily the show often focuses on other plotlines and that's where it REALLY shines imo. I would've loved to have watched the ending but with just Bradley vs Roy Mustangs people.
