This was my third ever anime i ll be honest, but I still think this some sort of gta of anime lemme explain. I know it s the highest ranked game but so are the gtas and thats because they have plenty of good stuff that makes almost everyone happy, but it will allways be in the top third or second spot or just even in top 5.
Story: I think the plot is really good, the pacing is really good and consistent, I never felt like some episodes were too dragged. The only little problem I have its with the script as I felt that
                  sometimes it feels like japanesse trying to be more western-ish. And I do believe thats what they went for as even the characters names aren t most of the times asian.
Art: It s pretty well done but it wasn t that groundbreaking, but for anime this one felt really cartoonish, and a friend compared to the last airbender and i think thats putitng it right
Sound: The problem is that its either really repetitive like you ll have the same track everytime it s a tense moments, at times it felt really empty cuz there was nothing playing. But nonetheless some ending and intro ost are good my favorite one was "let it all out"
Characters: The only dissapointment I have but its not a bad thing is that I expected more complex and top/god tier characters but no one it s really a 10/10, but Eric is still a good mc, him and Al work really well and carry the show, but also all the characters in general are really enjoyable. I don t think I have one that I can say it was bad written. They re all in general +8/10. I liked Mustang, The Armstrong siblings
Enjoyment: It did have a slower start but by the 19th episode i wacthed at least 10 episodes almost every night
My overall rating is a 9/10 (9,15 will be in average as I rated every episode)

More than a decade later and its still the king the medium. The plot takes its time and thinly distributes over each episode but uses that time to develop its characters and environment. It is an optimal pacing. You'll find yourself asking questions each episode. The anime just gives you the answers 10 episodes later which can be critiqued writing wise but it is still engaging.
It isn't immature compared to most shounen but doesn't take its self too seriously either which helps the tone. The humor doesn't always land but it does when it needs to. It has consistent central themes of war, politics, and
                  family that are explored to give the series its depth. 
The characters become endearing overtime especially Al. 
The fight scenes are more like problems the protags solve rather than the common combat simulation of who dies first. A bit like jojo. Often solved with magic which brings me to my critique:
Although this is a magic based show, I feel like the magic could be better explained. It claims to have rules but I don't think the rules are really consistent. Like sometimes the protags come across a similar problem that they solved before. For example edward can fix a radio when its completely in pieces but cant fix his prosthesis when it breaks. Like it or not but it seems to be a very much a power level based magic despite how much the show claims it isn't. All the characters have limits on how much raw plot usefulness they can do with their magic but it isnt really clear what exactly those limits are. Then you'll have characters that are OP when they need to be like Roy Mustang that thanos snaps shit with his flames. Thats my only criticism really. Quite a big flaw but doesn't take away from the enjoyment.

I really enjoyed FMA Brotherhood, even if some of it was rehashing what FMA already had done in previous episodes. The characters are very likeable, even ones you might only see once, and decisions make sense from a logical stand point. I never had to second guess why a logical character was making a bad decision, because they didn't. 
More so, the plot and music were beautifully executed. The sound track hits emotional beats and the story unfolds in a well paced manner. I loved fight scenes, because with the world building, you actually get to see the creativity and limitations the creator has clearly
                  thought through. Plot twists are nicely foreshadowed, but not so much that the anime is spoon feeding you information. 
All in all, the anime was enjoyable to watch and I never really wanted to skip episodes because they were all entertaining. FMA Brotherhood is a great anime to watch for the first time and again and again when I want to revisit badass, fast paced, cool fight scenes.

For my First review on MAL : As a person who has seen a lot of anime , the anime i would suggest to a begginer (who just started to watch anime) , AND a seasoned watcher ....(really to anyone) is most definitely FMAB .
It is 64 episodes long , so it doesnt feel like a short 24 episode anime where they have to rush the story AND also doesn't feel like those 200 episode long shonen anime. And thus it has the perfect length to smoothly unfold its amazing story.
It very nicely blends both the serious and comical scenes . 
A very unique story
                  and i would strongly suggest you watch it if u haven't seen it already!

"Hagane no Renkinjutsushi: Fullmetal Alchemist", aka "Fullmetal Alchemist: Brotherhood" is the second anime adaptation of the FMA manga. Unlike the first anime series, Brotherhood follows faithfully the original material. It's considered a masterpiece and an amazing adaptation by many people, but I disagree.
 Story: 8/10
 The plot is really grandiose: in the beginning the story focuses only on the Elric brothers, but then a lot of new characters are introduced. There are no real plot holes, but sometimes the story can be really predictable, especially during the last arc. The ending felt artificial and saccharine. The beginning is pretty bad too: the first
                  episode is a poorly written filler, and the first 14 episodes cut away two chapters. Also, the world building isn't as good as people say: in fact, we know nothing about all the countries introduced in the story (like Xing or Drachma), except Amestris. 
 Art: 7/10
 The art style is similar to the manga one, but it didn't work as well as the original. It feels lifeless and the bright colors don't fit he dark tone of the story. The backgrounds are really bland. However, the animation is fluid and the CGI is fine for a 2009 anime.
 Sound: 6/10
 I liked the OPs and the EDs, but the OST is pretty forgettable and the same soundtracks (like Lurking) are reused in almost every episode. The japanese dub is really good.
 Characters: 8/10
 Like I said before, FMAB has a solid cast, but not as much as the manga. Also, there are too many characters, and because of that the main character doesn't have enough screen time to grow as a person. The brotherhood between him and Alphonse is never explored.
 Enjoyment: 9/10
 Despite it being inferior to the manga, I really enjoyed Brotherhood. It wasn't really emotional or anything and the themes aren't very well explored, but I just couldn't stop watching it. The only things that I really didn't like were the first and the last arc, the way the main character was left aside and the cheap comedy. 
 Overall: 8/10
 FMAB is a very good anime, but it's not the best out there. It's vastly inferior to the original manga and it doesn't excel in anything. If you're new to the franchise I recommend  to watch FMA 2003 + Shamballa first, and only then to read the manga or to watch Brotherhood.

It's one of the greatest anime. 
The character has their own thoughts and feeling, not just something you use to push to the plot. Animation is outstanding, every fight is enjoyable. MC is not overpowered, and there isn't stuff like "RAGE=MORE POWER" like every shonen anime does.  Every fight makes sense. And there isn't power that comes out randomly in the middle of the show to stretch to show. On top of all that, this show still has a good plot. Every action makes sense, there is no sugar coating the villain. Yet you still can feel the charisma in different characters. Halfway through,
                  you will start to discover different character's philosophical theories, which is the main conflict between characters. Adding a lot of depth to the character and the plot. The ending is the greatest part of this show, it's one of the best endings I've seen. It starts with Alchemy, it ends with Alchemy itself, like a perfect circle. If it isn't for the somewhat cringy comedy part, it's definitely a 10/10.

At first, I though this show was very slow and wasn't going anywhere. But then once I started season 2, I thought it was one of the best shows, not only anime, but SHOWS of all time. Then I continued watching, and now that i am done, i can say it is the second best show I have ever seen. ( breaking bad is no.1). The story is a masterpiece, and you cant help but love all of the characters. ( except May Chang, she was annoying. Here are all my individual points 
Story: 10. story was possibly the best story of any anime ever
                  written, due to the amazing plot twist and outstanding dialogue. Amazing backstory for the Elric brothers as, well, giving a very sad and heart wrenching story for the brothers.
Art: 9. The art for this was outstanding. It also has a very unique character design, not using the traditional pointy chins and instead using round heads and big eyes. The characters are not sexualized, which is a bad thing for some people but i prefer the characters to super sexualized because it is uncomfortable to watch. The animation and fights were also very clean and fluid.
Sound: 10. The music in this show was outstanding. Every opening was top tier, especially " hologram" and "again". The soundtrack was equally amazing, from the eerie music of the homunculus, to the upbeat music in the battles. It was a perfect soundtrack from end to beginning. 
Characters: 10. The characters in this show were impeccable and probably the best supporting characters of all time. From the military characters ( King Bradley, 
Roy Mustang, Riza Hawkeye, Jean Havoc, and Olivier and Alex Armstrong), The Homunculi, ( Wrath, Gluttony, Pride, Greed, Lust, Envy, and Sloth), the main characters ( Edward, Alphonse, Scar, Kimblee, Winry, Ling, The chimeras, Izumi Curtis, Hoenheim, lan Fan, Maes Hughes, Dr marcoh etc...) As you can see, there is a whole cast of amazing characters in this show.
Ending: 10. The most perfect ending in television history. Period. Everything wraps up in a tear-jerking, heartfelt, amazing ending that needs to be studied by future anime writers for years to come. I can not give this anime enough praise and fully deserves the no.1 spot on this website.

As i'm sure you already know, FMAB is an anime that is known both to anime watchers and non-anime watchers. It has dominated the polls, taking the spot of greatest anime of all time, but does it deserve that title? Let's look and see.
Story: 10/10 
The story itself is rather straightforward. You have Edward and Alphonse Elric, two boys who lost their mother and attempted to use alchemy to revive her. Unaware of the basic principle that encompasses alchemy - The law of equivalent exchange - Ed and Al end up losing their arm, leg, and whole body, respectively. The boys build their notoriety as
                  top-class alchemists and come across other characters with which the story goes into more depth as they face a threat that could destroy them all. Despite the anime's straightforward approach, Fullmetal Alchemist does an amazing job of fleshing out each character and the world around them, something that the original FMA does not do very well. A testament to this would be the introduction of the people of Xing and the development of characters like the Fuhrer and side characters like Jerso. To add on to this, unlike the original FMA, this anime is faithful to the original manga and paces it very well. The show itself doesn't feel too long or too short; It's just the right length. The worldbuilding and lore are top-tier, touching on subjects like the Ishvalan War and the after-effects of it, which serve as one of the main driving forces in the story.
Art: 10/10
Bones Animation did a great job of animating the series. I don't have much to say about this. Even the animation for the openings was absolutely amazing, the first two openings in particular.
Sound: 7/10
Despite the amazing storytelling, i believe it does fall short on the OST side of things. There were a few soundtracks that would stick with me and others that i'd just forget about. The openings, however, were amazing and well-chosen. The voice actors were spectacular as well. Romi Park and Rie Kugimiya do a wonderful job portraying Ed and Al,  and don't get me started on the Fuhrer and Greed's voice actors. Overall, the cast was amazing and brought more life to the anime, offsetting the "good but not great" soundtrack.
Characters: 10/10
The best thing about the series. The original series had more focus on our two main characters, Ed and Al, which isn't necessarily bad. With that being said, I appreciate when stories touch on the main character's surroundings and give you a more thorough understanding of the climate they live in, and Brotherhood exceeds my expectations in that regard. The introduction of the characters from the fictional country of Xing, to seeing the most irrelevant side characters have some sort of role to play. It outdoes it's predecessor in terms of fleshed out characters. Some series have characters that you can't seem to like, but with FMAB, even the most rotten individual is well written. I mean, have you seen how many FMAB fans talk about how great a person Shou Tucker is....?
Enjoyment: 9/10
As you've probably seen (assuming you've read up until this point) I've had nothing but good things to say about this series. It's a very enjoyable series, but the fast pacing might take a bit of getting used to. When i was watching it, I got used to it about 5 episodes in but some people would take about 15 episodes before they got hooked. Each person is different but once you're hooked, you will enjoy it.
Overall: 9/10 
FMAB is an amazing series, especially for those that are trying to get into the anime scene. It's one that I've recommended to friends of mine, both anime and non-anime watchers, and is a great starting point for anyone trying to take a dip into the wide sea that is the anime scene. Don't even watch the original FMA release, if you want it as it was released in the manga, watch FMAB. You will not regret it. :)

This show is literally the most amazing show ever. There is not a single part about it that deserves anything less than a 10. All the characters are fully developed and fun to watch. The art is nothing less than beautiful and both the dub and sub are equally matched in their quality. It has a perfect mix of humor and seriousness. This is by far the most enjoyable show I've watched. By the way, if you like Brotherhood, I would recommend also reading the manga since I believe it does an even better job at fleshing out the characters. The extras are also very
                  enjoyable to read.

There is nothing I can say about FMA that hasn't already been said. and no words I have express how great it is, masterpiece is best verb to describe it. Firstly do not think of the original Fullmetal Alchemist and Fullmetal Alchemist Brotherhood as the same story or a continuation, because they aren't. They are based on the same story points but their stories go in vastly different directions because of when they were made. The original was made while the Manga was running and eventually they caught up to it, so instead of waiting for new volumes they made their own where as Brotherhood
                  takes place after the Manga is set and sets that as the bottom-line. The first few episodes can be slow as we meet the characters but they aren't bad episodes by any means, just different. As the story goes on and you learn more you put the pieces together with the characters, their problems are mental games you endlessly play in your head as the viewer. Their moral challenges are questions you end up asking yourself. The themes, teachings, and philosophies stick with you years after finishing the show. As you go from knowing what they are saying, to understanding their words, and finally accepting it as real to you as they are the characters. A story of sadness, hopelessness, bittersweet, and hope for good at the end of the story.

Brotherhood is a completely different ball game to the first FMA, actually starting the series in the past and spending more time focusing on each character and their developments. There are a lot more characters introduced in the series, such as the people of Xing and Fort Briggs. Because of its darker and grittier tone, the story and characters could go further with what they could allow and it makes for great action and emotion. The ending is much more well rounded and deserved and I think that the final fight is definitely better. 
The characters have been fleshed out a lot more and go
                  into deeper backstories. There is just enough time devoted to side characters that the focus on the main characters isn't lost, but that they are still worth a watch

Short Review: (minor spoilers)
A great anime indeed. Stable quality throughout, thematically consistent (mostly) from start to finish. In comparison, some classics I was obsessed with in my childhood are full of retconned elements (Saint Seiya, Fist of the North Star, etc.). When the actions start to get going, the show is usually a total blast. A few things held it back from perfection for me though, namely, immersion-breaking gags; wishful-thinking resolutions for some core antagonists and a not-so-subtle anti-male ideology (to be fair many anime sport "goddess-dominating-over-men" trope, but this issue sticks out in FMAB's otherwise amazing writing for me). Sorry FMAB fans and MAL,
                  but in my opinion there are more stellar shonen/seinen shows. 
For clarifications, I never read the FMA manga, nor have I seen the 2003 anime version. I went into FMAB only knowing the basic premise--that two brothers paid a great price after a transmutation attempted for resurrecting their mom went horribly wrong. On MAL, the show might just permanently occupy the throne of the best rated anime ever. I never hated or resented that (just as being an IMDB user and casual reviewer for years, I've never had a problem with Shawshank Redemption permanently being No.1, despite it's never my favorite movie). Some of my friends shunned MAL for this reason (to quote a friend, "the rating system on MAL can only give you an idea of the most popular shows, but not really the best shows"). I want to give the top shows here a fair chance, and I am glad to see different views from people here. That said, I started FMAB with my expectations cautiously cranked to 9.5/10. When I finished the last episode, I was happy that the show mostly lives up to the hype, mostly.
Pros: 
+ Overall a fantastic production. Very consistent quality. As a fantasy/action/adventure/military-themed shonen/seinen that dishes out supernatural combat in spades, the show is surprisingly grounded and gripping. Almost on the level of Hunter X Hunter for me (close but not). 
+ Sustained suspense. Around half-way, the show becomes easy to binge in a single sitting. Most episodes ends on an intriguing cliffhanger. 
+ Overall story and themes. A very straight-forward take on modern humanism among other heavy subject matters (Fascism, Scientism, Existentialism, Utilitarianism vs. Moralism, etc.). Again the show shines in its consistency in its treatment of these matters. The entire anime has only one single arc from start to finish (mostly driven by the dual protagonists' quest to get their bodies back).
+ Art and animation. I am sure the design for Envy's true form alone deserves some kind of award. It's one of the best examples of blending 3d and 2d elements in an anime. Butter-smooth explosions and special effects. Characters have their distinct designs (unlike some popular shows that keep copying and pasting the same face on characters). 
+ Endearing characters and their suitable fates. For example, the major twist regarding the protagonists' father is layered and smart, and a clear testament to the talent of the writer/author. Von's ending could have easily been generic (but still proper), yet the author was able to put extra thought into it. Same thing goes with King Bradley, Dr. Marco and Scar. 
Cons: 
- The show seems to be shy/unconfident for being serious and brutal, therefore inserting countless chibi-character sequences, sometimes at the cost of the immersion/thrills (e.g. during some of the most intense and white-knuckled battles the main characters suddenly turned chibi for gags, and the enemies just stopped attacking). I am not 100% against comic relief or gags during intense/mature sequences, but I'd prefer that they don't break my immersion. 
- For a show about demonic forces and their real consequences on humanity, the author went for a wishful-thinking, naïve conclusion for some of the main antagonists (e.g. a certain deadly sin's turn of heart and final sacrifice as he was "transformed" after taking over another character's body). This problem, in my opinion, undermines the show's overall believability and the weight of the Xerxes incident (if the lesson Von learned at Xerxes is "don't let the devil play with your seemingly innocent wishes and desires, for the devil never plays fair", he should never had led his sons onto the path of Alchemy, but then again there wouldn't have been this story at all). All the serious explorations of morality/metaphysical aspects before the climax/ending were also weakened for this reason. 
- Anti-male imagery dominates the show. I lost count how many times our male heroes were casually bullied or beaten up by super-powered, dominating and sneering female characters. A main villain is just named "Father". A most masculine character has the head of a baby, and often soils himself at the mere sight of his ultra-tough sister. The ideal "family man" is really just a bubbling idiot who shows off his happy family around (causing dire consequences for himself). By the examples of some characters (e.g. Col. Mustang; Lt. Hawkeye; King Bradley), the author is very capable of writing layered, nuanced and realistic characters. Therefore it puzzles me why she couldn't write more strong female characters who don't need to assert their independence, prowess and dignity by beating men into pulps. To be fair there are other exaggerated representations of this type of "girl power" in many other anime, but for FMAB's overall amazing writing, this issue sticks out like a sore thumb for me. 
- Some uninteresting side stories and slow-to-a-halt episodes. Like I said, when the actions start, the show is usually a total blast. There are also quality quiet character moments, but some episodes made me just want to fast-forward. For a large portion of the final climax, Edward as the central character was just given generic brainless zombie-like creatures to fight with. Moments like this made me shout in my thought: "come on, FMAB, you can do much better than this!"
In conclusion, Fullmetal Alchemist Brotherhood is a great show with some caveats. 
Baseline quality: 9/10; in the end a strong 8.4/10 due to the issues mentioned.

This is it chief, the supposed #1 anime of all time (at least until "Shingeki no Kyojin Final Season" finishes :P).
So I've been putting this one off for a long time and only a year after I started watching anime did I actually manage to watch this one. It took a solid two months to finish (school has been hectic) but the show was worth it. But, does it really deserve the number 1 spot?
"Fullmetal Alchemist: Brotherhood" is famous for a reason. And not only is it famous, it is really, REALLY good. The story is ridiculously creative and everything comes together incredibly smoothly. I
                  was initially worried they were going to sacrifice the "let's get our bodies back" plot line for the other that I can't talk about in detail because of SPOILERZZZZZ but they didn't do that which I appreciate. The story develops very well and once you get through the first two parts you're left with a super fun, epic, enjoyable action/drama which is very nice. It goes without saying that Bones does a great job with animation. I've never been a huge fan of their art style, but that's just my personal opinion, it's better than anything I could draw lol. The Kono omoi wo song is really good. The rest of the soundtrack has some strong points and I really like the voice-acting. Especially Al's voice, it's just super cute/cool/nice/I'mnotgayIpromise. The characters are all really cool. I really like Ed, Al, Winry and Hohenheim. Scar get's really good and ROY MUSTANG aside from having the coolest sounding name of all history is an absolute machine. Maes Hughes is... aaaaahhhhhh- Yeah the Armstrongs are fun and I really like the Xingese guys. Especially May Chang. I mean, she's a cute girl with a miniature panda, how can you not like her? And all the homunculi are interesting. I especially like Greed and his dynamic with this one character I can't mention because SSSSSPPPPOOOOIIILLLLZZZZZZ. All in all the show was super entertaining and fun.
However, despite being the #1 anime I do have a few problems here. I really feel like sometimes the themes they try to mix don't mesh too well and some of the emotional moments are awkward. There are some cheesed that-guy-should-have-died moments but they make up for it with some crushing that's-the-one-guy-I-didn't-want-to-die moments so it balances out I guess. I also was completely lost in the final fight scene. Like... What??? Huh??? Idk I can't go into detail cuz SpOiLeRz but it didn't really make sense. I don't like the comedy moments, they get on my nerves, and so does the way they're animated. The soundtrack honestly isn't particularly amazing, go ahead and beat me up idc. And sometimes the characters say some really bizarre stuff where I'm just like: 'Huh? Why? Do you have brain? Ooga Booga?' and the first two parts are a bit slow which takes away from the overall enjoyment. Those are my problems.
Despite MY problems with this show (emphasis on the my) it's really good. The philosophy behind it and the great story (which I gave a ten despite its shortcomings because it's just so dang genius) make it an anime absolutely worth watching. Is it the best? Eeeeeeehhhhhhh I'm sorry but I'm more of a "Steins;gate" man, and I honestly think a lot of people give "Your Name" a really hard time just because they don't like romance, but Fullmetal is still really good, definitely deserves the watch, so give it a shot and enjoy it to the max.
Ja ne,
-Kallocarina

this is probably my favorite anime. i'll preface this by saying i havent watched the original FMA anime (yet) so i cannot compare and instead just gonna focus solely on FMAB itself. 
FMAB has a really good plot. it certainly has its ups and downs but id say it's still consistently good until things get a little out of hand in the final part of the story. 
the world building is phenomenal, alchemy is nicely explained without going in too deep (*cough* hxh nen). the world is very interesting and while the plot is always good enough to stay in one place for a good
                  amount of time, it makes you want to see more of the worlds diversity all the time. 
again, its not all great and theres a bunch of unnecessary scenes as well as the dumbass "meme animations" (for a lack of a better word) in between. while i can easily live with some scenes that dont contribute anything to the plot, the caricaturesque scenes just make me cringe. it's not even remotely funny and it's hugely annoying if they keep repeating the same terrible jokes and memes over and over. the series has a lot of positivity and heartfelt moments in between a rather dark main plot. it wasnt at all necessary to try and "lighten up the mood" - if anything it destroyed the suspense and the "feel" there was to the show.
Moving on to the art i think the art is mostly brilliant. the fighting scenes arent the only aspect that makes the series shine in this category, the facial expressions, background etc. all look really nice. if youve watched the series and read my review so far you already know what i didnt like: yea the meme-cringe-scenes and their terrible artwork. moving on.
The sound is the only part of the series where id give a full 10/10. aside from one OP i think theyre all nothing short of amazing. the endings are great as well and i liked the voice acting, too. no complaints here - to be fair: judging the music is rather subjective. 
With the evaluation of the characters we are now entering the part where i had most of my concerns about the show in general. while i know a couple of people dont like ed and a lot of people do like al, for me its the other way round. i think al is almost always acting like a little baby - which is a stark contrast to what is happening around him. i think he doesnt fit the narrative. and while ed often goes on the borderline of that, al constantly crosses it sadly. 
luckily FMAB has a bunch of amazing villains as well as a couple of great side characters to make up for that. the homunculi in particular were really well fleshed out and they had more character development than basically ANY of those that confronted them. i liked envy and wrath a lot in particular, up to the point where i was actively rooting for them not to die. i would say this is good writing - but i'd also see the point if someone would say it is bad writing in the sense that the main characters are overshadowed too much. 
of the side characters the relationship between mustang and hawkeye obviously stands out - they have great synergy and its a bit of a shame this doesnt get explored more (no i dont mean shipping them necessarily). 
As for the enjoyment i had a lot of fun on that journey. i always wanted to see more, even the scenes that didnt particularly advance the story were good way more often than not. the xerxes-flashback episode was particularly great. 
all in all i'd say this is the closest to a masterpiece i've seen from anime so far, but not quite there yet. 9/10 with a tendency rather to 8 than 10.

Overview:
It's strange that out of the two "Fullmetal Alchemist" anime series, "Brotherhood" is the one with the subtitle, because it should really be the other way round. This is because "Brotherhood" is the anime that faithfully adapts the original manga series written by Hiromu Arakawa, something that very much works in its favour. While the first "Fullmetal Alchemist" was certainly a great anime in its own right, there is much, much more to love about "Brotherhood". This is a better-written, more powerful, action-packed and enjoyable experience from top to bottom, and to call it a masterpiece would be an understatement.
Story & World (10/10):
No matter what
                  powers you may have, some things just can't be done. That's a lesson brothers Edward and Alphonse Elric learn the hard way when they try to resurrect their dead mother using Alchemy, a scientific process that revolves around creating something in exchange for something of equal value. However, resurrecting humans with such a process is regarded as a serious taboo, and for good reason. The experiment proves to be a colossal failure, as not only do they not bring back their mother, but Ed loses an arm and a leg, while Al loses his entire body, forcing Ed to bind his soul to a suit of armour in order to save his life. Now stuck in these forms, Ed and Al embark on a several-year quest to fix their mistake and get back what they lost- not their mother as they planned before, but simply their bodies. Of course, things prove to be far from simple, as not only do they have no idea to find what they need- a Philosopher's Stone, which supposedly has the ability to bend the rules of alchemy- but they soon find themselves in conflict with mysterious demonic beings known as Homunculi, who are plotting something extremely sinister that threatens to reshape the entire world.
While the setting of "Fullmetal Alchemist", the country Amestris, is fictional, it is heavily inspired by early 20th century Britain and Europe. As far as anime go, "Fullmetal Alchemist" is on a whole other level when it comes to world-building, as we end up learning a ton about the country's history dating all the way back to its origins. The concept of Alchemy is explored immensely as well. To be brief, many of the Alchemists are employed by the government as high-ranking officials, and such Alchemists are known as State Alchemists. Edward is one such Alchemist, with Fullmetal Alchemist being his title. What truly separates him from most Alchemists, however, his brother included, is that while most Alchemists need a special symbol called a Transmutation Circle to use Alchemy, for Ed, using it is as simple as clapping his hands together, a power he gained as a result of being confronted by Truth, a supposed God of Alchemy that is believed by many to punish the arrogant. But honestly, as far Alchemy is concerned, I've barely only scratched the surface. When you hear someone say that anything can become anything in this series, they mean it. Throughout the series, you will see Ed, Al and others transmute everything from spears, swords, doors and even fire. It is a concept that is used to its fullest potential, and the series is much deeper and more original because of it.
As incredibly rich as the world-building is, however, the actual storytelling is just as good. While the series starts off very fast-paced, that's only because it's quickly going through things that were already covered in the first anime (with that in mind, I would recommend watching that series, or at least the first half, before you attempt this one). Once all of that is covered, things slow down a good deal to the absolute perfect pace, with things just consistently getting better and better with each passing episode. Everything makes sense, nothing is anti-climactic and things are almost never quite what they initially seem. The themes are plentiful and there are plenty of messages here that are not subtle at all, but absolutely need to be said. Once the series gets its momentum going, it never loses it, and tops off everything with one of the most rewarding, fitting and well-earned endings I have ever seen in any story, anime or not.
Art & Animation (9.5/10):
Even by Studio Bones standards, "Fullmetal Alchemist" is a fantastic-looking series, both for the time it was made and in general. The characters all look distinct and are masterfully drawn, the environments are equally brilliant-looking, the fight scenes are incredibly well-animated and choreographed and the various Alchemy visuals are an absolute joy to behold. There's a little too much deranged animation for my tastes, but this thankfully never distracts too much from the series and, better yet, it appears less and less as the series progresses. In particular, the final quarter of the series features some of the most gorgeous visuals I have ever seen, in animation or otherwise.
Sound & Dialogue (10/10):
There are so many great tracks in "Fullmetal Alchemist: Brotherhood" that it is pretty much impossible to list them all. I honestly don't have a favourite part of the soundtrack for the simple fact that all of it is brilliant. That said, when it comes to particularly noteworthy tracks, the final two openings, "Period" and "Rain" come to mind. The voice acting, however, is even better; Vic Mignogna delivers an incredible performance as Ed that earned him several much-deserved awards, and the series in general boasts one of the finest dub casts ever assembled, including Travis Willingham as Roy Mustang, Maxey Whitehead as Al, Colleen Clinkenbeard as Riza Hawkeye, Caitlin Glass as Winry Rockbell, Monica Rial as May Chang, Todd Haberkorn as Ling Yao, Christopher Sabat as Alex Armstrong and many, many more. Ultimately, just about everything sound-wise is near-flawless, accompanied by a truly fantastic script, and this is just one of many reasons as to why I love this show so much.
Characters (10/10):
Edward Elric is an incredible protagonist, and calling him three-dimensional would honestly be putting it lightly. He starts the series as very immature and short-tempered (particularly in regards to this height) and while this is definitely hilarious, he tones it down a ton over the series, especially when things get very serious towards the end. Even at his worst, though, Ed is shown consistently to be very compassionate and extremely selfless; restoring his brother's body always takes priority over restoring his own and there's never any question that he's becoming what he's fighting against. Hiromu Arakawa could easily have written him as this ruthless person willing to do anything to restore his and his brother's bodies but she didn't and I applaud her for that. After all, part of the brothers' quest is atonement for thinking they could play God, which would be rendered meaningless if they were willing to become monsters. Ed's flaws instead lie in his belief that he can solve all of his problems with Alchemy and, more prominently, his guilt complex, which leads to him initially unwilling to accept help from anyone but Al, and that's largely because they share the same situation. Overtime, however, he learns to accept help from others and to share his burdens, as well as coming to terms with the fact that he is only human, which in turn allows him to forgive himself for his failures. In short, not only is he the single best character this anime has to offer (which is saying a LOT), he's one of the best anime characters ever conceived.
Al is, in many ways, the opposite of his brother. Where Ed is brash, short-tempered and eager for a fight, Al is kind, calm and pacifistic. He also hates to see anybody in pain and will go to great lengths to keep people from dying. However, while it's a lot harder to anger him than his brother, it's not impossible; he doesn't like people claiming it would be cool to have a suit of armour for a body, generally responding to such comments by saying they should be careful what they wish for. After all, while his armoured body does save him and his brother numerous times, it also means he can't eat, sleep or even feel the air around him. As such, he is notably more eager to have his own body restored than Ed is, even keeping a diary of things to eat when he has it back, though his brother's body is ultimately still his main priority. However, while Al is a fantastic character, one who I found myself liking even more is the brothers' commanding officer, Lieutenant Colonel Roy Mustang. Known as the Flame Alchemist, he has the ability to convert air into flammable gas using a Transmutation Circle on his glove, then lighting a fire to cause a huge burst of flames to attack. He's also a master tactician, deliberately acting much shallower than he actually is so that people don't take him too seriously. Not only is he one of the most badass characters in the series, he's also one of the most idealistic, having grand ambitions for Amestris that will very much benefit the people, in no small part thanks to his strong faith in humanity. These ambitions stem from a desire to make up for a terrible tragedy he took part in in the past, making him come off as a lot like the Elric brothers in this regard, but very different from them at the same time.
Another truly fantastic character is Riza Hawkeye, Roy's second-in-command and closest subordinate who lived through and was forced to do many of the same things he did. She's an incredibly loyal woman who would do anything for Mustang, yet also won't hesitate to remind him of his shortcomings or call him out when he goes too far, generally showing a no-nonsense attitude that hides her warm heart and desire to make up for her past actions, which is justified by the fact that she's a soldier. Plus, as her name implies, she's master marksman, with pretty much all of her best moments coming from her incredible aiming skills. Speaking of great female characters, there's also Winry Rockbell, a childhood friend of Ed and Al as well as the love interest of the former, and a highly skilled mechanic. She doesn't fight, but she still proves to be an invaluable asset to the brothers, both as emotional support and for the fact that she's the one to fix Ed's automail (artificial limbs that he wears in place of the ones he lost) whenever they get broken, which happens quite often, and you can expect her to be pissed whenever it happens. As a bonus, she's a huge geek for machinery, and I'd consider her to be a great character just for that.
As a whole, "Fullmetal Alchemist"'s cast of characters is absolutely mind-boggling. Throughout the anime's 64 episodes, we're introduced to over 100 different characters, and by some miracle, most, if not all of them manage to be important. There's also plenty of strong connections between them, on top of the ones I've already mentioned, which really helps to reinforce the story's many themes. Even you don't like certain characters, you're not meant to. The Homonculi act very much like the sadistic, misanthropic demons they are, but even they all manage to have at least one sympathetic trait. The only real exception is the big boss, and trust me when I say that while you may enjoy the threat he delivers as an antagonist, and the great performance from the voice actor (whom I will not name to avoid spoilers), you will HATE him by the end of the series.
Enjoyment (9.5/10):
"Fullmetal Alchemist" is a massively enjoyable series, having some of the most original fight scenes I've ever seen thanks to the many different uses of Alchemy. There's a ton of great comedy relief as well, whether it be Ed's comical overreactions, Winry's geeking over technology or Ling Yao's trolling among others. The only thing that stops this category from getting full marks is that it takes a bit too long to get to the good stuff, though when it does it will have been absolutely worth the wait, and as I mentioned earlier, things just get better with every episode, meaning you will absolutely want to see it to the end.
Overall:
Even more than a decade after its initial run, "Fullmetal Alchemist: Brotherhood" still stands as an absolute benchmark for all anime, making it hardly a surprise as to why calling it bad or even okay is such a sore spot in the anime community. There isn't a single aspect this series doesn't hit the nail on the head, from its amazingly well-developed characters, its fantastic visuals, its impeccable sound design (the voice acting, in particular), its brilliantly creative fight scenes to its incredible, deep story with a long list of powerful messages that only "Dragon Ball" could hope to match. This is easily one of the greatest shows I have ever seen and comes highly recommended to anyone who is unfortunate enough to have not watched it yet.
Score:
10+9.5+10+10+9.5=49/50=9.8/10

An amazing story with an undying soul. The fullmetal Alchemist brotherhood has more of a theming that are not even cared by the children at the age of the characters in the show.  A carefully crafted characters and emotions make it to stand out as an anime and made itself be comparable to an epic. Yes, it is an epic and it is good. The Elric brothers are the most beautifully develo9ped protagonists among the five seasons or the 64 episodes long show. The show was paced too fast and it's predecessor paced too slow. It seems the series couldn't get rid of the
                  pacing problem that they are having. Except for that the brotherhood had a better ending than the original. Thus, making it a truly epic story for the anime p-latform..

king of shounen.
everything was wrapped up perfectly. everything made sense. nothing felt out of place or unnecessary. very memorable. 
even the dub was amazing,
 moreover the female characters aren't treated like crap by the author (ahem like in Naruto) which probably has something to do with the mangaka being a woman. Unlike in other stories in battle shounen Fullmetal alchemist portrayed a romance between a man and a woman that didn't involve the woman also fighting, but in an equally useful role (mechanic) because other battle shounen (ahem naruto and bleach) just sideline them and make them useless in fighting anyway lol 
the story dealt
                  with some nice philosophical issues without going into territory the mangaka wasn't equipped to handle efficiently and with nuance (ahem attack on titan). 
The idea of "alchemy" as a power system was also very unique and memorable.

Overall: 10/10. One of the best anime of all time.

Fullmetal Alchemist Brotherhood gets great, but it has a sloppy start. The first 14 episodes of the anime were already adapted into a show before and so this version decides to go through those episodes at a fast pace so that we can get into the new stuff.
The bad news is a lot of iconic moments are rushed and some important characters and setting (like the coal mine and its workers) are mostly absent from this. The good news is they adapted the new stuff really well and so we can finally see some of the best moments in anime history in their full glory
Said
                  moments are brought to life by the top of the class animation that still impresses 10 years on and a great (but repetitive) soundtrack. But animation and soundtrack wise FMAB's greatest achievement are the ops.
Every anime franchise has that ONE op that sucks. FMA doesn't, sure some rock more than others but the entire package is filled with visual marvels 
However, none of that compares to the great cast. Ed is a great character and one of the few shounen protagonists that actually have a character arc. His brother Al is a great spin on the big guy with a secret heart of gold trophy and the supporting cast surrounding the brothers is amazing and everyone gets at least one chance to shine.
There are very few shows that deserve the title of classic, but FMAB is one of those few. Heartbreaking, exciting, funny, and many more things. This is a must-watch for anyone that likes regular series or anime

I recently just finished Fullmetal Alchemist: Brotherhood in a week from start to finish. I had high expectations going into this one as it currently sits as the #1 ranked anime on MAL. Initially, throughout the 1st and 2nd parts, I felt that the show was enjoyable to watch but I did not understand why it was the top-rated anime. I think in the beginning the pacing and story were a little bit boring at times. I didn't feel immediately invested in the story and especially the antagonists. 
Once I got to Part 3 of the series I felt that the characters started to really
                  shine. And ultimately I think the quality of the character's personalities and design makes the show as good as it is. I think that you combine that with a very good story and you've got a recipe for an excellent show.
Until the final 20 episodes or so, I would give this show a low 8. But the finale is very satisfying and I think the Homunculus started to become very cool and interesting villains towards the end. 
Overall I would give this show around an 8.7 but since there are not decimal scores on MAL I will settle for the 9. I would definitely recommend it to anyone interested in a fun adventurous series with very likable characters.

First of all, I have seen the original FMA and although it was very popular and original, the pacing and conclusion did not sit too well with me. Brotherhood is meant to be a remake of the original, this time sticking to the manga all the way through, but there were people who thought it would spoil the franchise. That myth should be dispelled, as there's only one word to describe this series - EPIC.
I admit that as I've seen the original and read the manga, the pacing of Brotherhood seems to start off being VERY fast (I finally got used to the pacing after
                  watching the first fifteen eps or so). Events that took up half a volume of the manga and had spread though a few episodes of the original anime were now shown in just a single episode. However, after trying to look at it from the perspective of someone who's new to FMA (not comparing it to the manga nor the original), I believe that the pacing works and it manages to tell an intriguing story effectively with little confusion. The plot is full of clever ideas and unpredictable twists that link various parts of the story together. By the final episode, all loose ends are neatly tied up and what's left is a hugely satisfying epilogue.
The animation in FMA Brotherhood is crisp and very well done (although it does sometimes dip a bit in quality). Compared to the original FMA it's a bit simpler but that's just because the original set a very high standard to follow. The facial emotions of the characters are also perfectly presented. The action scenes are brilliant and VERY well animated, with a variety of alchemy techniques and other talents being displayed nearly every episode. The various battles are consistently exciting to watch, but somehow get even better towards the end of the series.
The voice acting is of an excellent and consistent quality, and I think that pretty much all the characters have voice actors which suit their personalities. The majority of the openings/endings are a pleasure to watch due to fantastic animated sequences and theme songs. The background music which play during the episodes usually fit very well with the situation, although some tracks seem to be overused a little at first. This becomes less of a problem as the series progresses, with plenty of new music being introduced to support the story as it reaches the finale.
Moving on to the characters (best thing about this series), the original FMA focussed mainly on Ed and Al and on their struggles to regain their bodies, whereas Brotherhood also explores other characters to great detail at the same time. The majority of the spotlight is still on the two brothers, but it highlights their interactions with new characters which were not present in the original anime. New characters include a group of people from Xing (a neighbouring country), another person from the Armstrong family (who I think has become one of the coolest members of the supporting cast), and a new main antagonist. For me, the Xingese characters in particular (Ling Yao and Mei Chang among others) provide a new dimension to the FMA world, by showing us a different culture to the militaristic one we're familiar with. I think the new antagonist is an improvement on the original FMA, as this person has a much stronger and clever link to the Elric brothers' father. Returning characters from the original FMA, such as Mustang and Scar, are much more awesome and developed due to the fact that Brotherhood is 100% faithful to the manga. Plus, Winry Rockbell now has a much more active role in the story. I can say for sure that this anime has one of the best main/supporting casts I've ever seen, and you'd probably find it difficult to label any of the recurring characters (whether they are good or evil) as being either boring or unnecessary in terms of the storyline.
One of the many good things about this series is that there has been absolutely no filler at all (yes, I'm thinking of Naruto, Inuyasha, etc), which prevents the story from losing momentum. All the episodes are concise and every scene is important as part of the huge plot. The dialogue fully explains everything and is straight to the point. As multiple characters are explored there are lots of side stories, but these are all perfectly intertwined with the main story of the Elric brothers and more often than not directly influence their journey too. Like most anime series, there are things from the manga which have been left out, but these are usually just restricted to comedy moments. There has been one episode which shows a lot of flashbacks of events so far, but that's forgiven as it shows the most epic moments of the series, and also provided us with some history on the father of the Elric brothers.
FMA Brotherhood will be sorely missed now that it's finished. It is excellent in every aspect and has very little, if anything, that can be called a flaw (maybe rushed character development at first due to the fast pacing, but this quickly subsides). Each episode feels like it's too short, a testimony to how much it draws you in to the story and characters. There are moments which leave you smiling, laughing, sad and simply amazed. Try this anime, it's recommended for absolutely everyone, to newcomers and to those familiar with Fullmetal Alchemist.

10/10
FMA: Brotherhood was nearly flawless not only because of the amazing story but also because of memorable characters. You quickly become engrossed into this world as you learn about the characters, the struggles that they each go through and how they change. This spotlight isn't just reserved for the "main" character or even just the good guys but we are also informed about the "bad" guys and their struggles. I was truly unable to find a SINGLE character that I found boring, annoying or bland which tends to be true in every other anime.
The writer wasted NO time with insignificant fillers or "fan service". Every
                  single minute was the foundation for this great anime. The pace that the anime goes through is reminiscent of death note. Each and every episode is filled with thrill and suspense. You really can never expect what is going to happen and there are plot twists around every corner. This is NOT a "typical" shounen, beat-em up anime but instead is a cleverly written and exceptionally well executed one.
The ending is neatly tied up without a cliff hanger. I recommend this to EVERYBODY who has not seen it. If you have seen the 2003 anime, you could start at episode 14 which is when the story takes a turn

Definitely, among the best anime I've watched. At this moment, one of the four titles that I've rated 10/10. And it might be because the other version (not Brotherhood) was so bad compared to this and influenced my opinion, who knows. Still, I'm not gonna change my opinion. This is a classic and it is worth watching. Whether you want to watch the other one is your own choice, you don't have to, but at least then you'll know how things went downhill in the second half, totally ruined the ending, sudden cut. Here, we get a lot more (sub)plot, characters, action, logic... Everything.
The magic/supernatural/powers
                  genres are definitely my favourite so if you like them too, give it a try. Well, on the other hand, if you like it I'd be surprised if you already didn't watch it. The overall plot is always what I appreciate the most, I hate when things are boring and I can't watch episodes anymore. Thank heavens, it's quite long but imanaging to be nteresting the whole time. Also, some very iconic soundtracks. Not hating on the art style, since everyone gets used to what they see after some time, it's old, but not bad. The most important is overall enjoyment and yes, I did enjoy it.
tldr; Watch this classic, it's one of the highest rated ones not without a reason.

Before I begin my review I need to advise you to watch Fullmetal Alchemist: Brotherhood it is definitely worth your time trust me.
Story 9: The story of Fullmetal Alchemist: Brotherhood is a must-watch for anyone that wants to or already started watching anime. It builds on a sad story of two brothers determined to get their bodies back and turns into a story of despair.
Art 10: The art included in this anime was ahead of its time with the alchemy and the godly figures featured in the anime
Sound 10: The sound is what I believed made this anime with it being played by an
                  orchestra it builds the perfect atmosphere for this story. The soundtrack featured in this does such a great job building despair for the atmosphere that while listening to the soundtrack for this review my heart just sunk.
Character 10: The characters in this anime did a great job building an emotional connection with the person watching. Which in term build great scenes of tension where you would be wondering whether on not your favorite character would die. And unlike other big series like AOT the characters are not only there to cannon fodder they all have their own scenes to build connections with them or build hatred or fear of them.
Enjoyment 10: This piece of art with its amazing soundtrack paired with its amazing characters, and the story makes for a really enjoyable experience that is almost unforgettable and is a must-watch for anybody that enjoys anime

This is a very good show, but it was still disappointing because I started the show thinking it would be a masterpiece, seeing as it is ranked #1 in MAL and so highly praised by so many people. Here is all the places I thought the anime felt off.
**SPOILER ALERT**
-> I dont understand why it started from a random point in the timeline with episode 1 and then episode 2 onwards it starts it for real. Its a bit weird.
-> Episode 10 : Hughes was starting to put the pieces together, so Lust was sent to assasinate him. But she failed to do so in
                  the first try and Hughes manages to escape her. But after managing to leave the room what does he do? You would expect him to go to somewhere populated in the office or maybe call out for help. But no, he does the opposite of that actually. He wanted to make a phone call to Mustang and inform him about the recent developments. He could have done that call from the office, but for some mysterious reason he thought it was better to leave the office and go to a phone booth in the middle of nowhere. 
  One way to explain this could be that he thought that many in the military were traitors so staying in the office will be worse. But this is not true since he said that he should inform Bradley about the recent developments before. Which means he did not know that all of the higher officials were corrupted yet.
  Another explanation could be that since he had planted a knife right in the head of Lust he thought he was dead and thus did not call out help. But that is still not good enough explanation of why he had to leave the office as there were telephones in there as well. Not like there were no telephones nearby and he HAD to leave the office. 
So this was a big weakness of the plot in my opinion
-> Episode 17, there was no reason for Barry to free Ling, just because he was a foreigner.
->  Throughout the series Ling and also May Chang seek immortality. It says that somehow that will help their clan, help them become rulers etc etc. But there was no clarification on this matter till the end. It makes no sense to me why both of them were strangely searching for immortality.
-> We know that Bradley became the king and manipulated all the higher officials of the military. But how did bradley infiltrate the military in the first place. How did he manage to become the king? There is no explanation to that in the show
-> Why did Van Hoenhan have to leave his kids and go away. I find no good explanation for this throughout the series. It is evident that he cared for his family and kids plenty. Yet for some reason he left. It said in the anime that he conversed with all the souls inside him and sorted them. But that has nothing to do with leaving home.
-> Episode 46: Winry asks why Elric doesn't go see Al at the station, and the reason given was that he was a fugitive so he does not want to go. I dont think there is any connection between being a fugitive and not going to meet his brother after such a long time.
-> Episode 51: Al came up with a brilliant plan of trapping Pride in darkness to remove him until the end of the fight. It happened successfully too. After getting trapped Pride kept hitting Al's head for the whole night. He was signalling his location, but Al was unaware of it. Now I can understand that he did not know that Pride was signalling his location, but still, creating that annoying noise throughout the night, at least he could have not let him make that annoying sound. In the morning when he was asked why he allowed him to make that sound continuously, his reply was that Selim was a little kid so he was just playing. When he knew full well that Selim was no kid.
-> The show always kept saying "Human transmutation is a taboo, for what could be the value of a human being". And finally guess what was used as equivalent exchange to bring Al back to life. It was that Elric could never use alchemy again. Seriously, thats all it takes to do human transmutation. Something that lost Elric 2 of his limbs and Al his whole body and still was not equivalent to bring their mother back to life, it took only the sacrifice of never to use alchemy again to do the same thing at the end of the show. This really made me hate the ending.
 You could say that unlike their mother Al was not dead, but trapped inside that weird dimension of truth. The price was only to take him back to the human realm. Yea, thats an explanation, but I still dont think that it is satisfying enough.
That was all the points I disliked about the show. Feel free to message me if you feel like having a conversation. Thanks.

A series with a very well worked history. With a beginning that little by little warns you of everything that is coming, with a development that advances at a decent but elaborate pace that allows you to enjoy all the problems throughout all its episodes. And as a end, an ending that manages to close the story very well and with the desire to continue.
Good characters (both main and secondary, protagonists and antagonists), very good plot, good soundtrack, decent animation and a significant and considerable amount of enough chapters to enjoy everything it offers. Definitely a masterpiece like no other. A jewel of the anime.

I binged FMA:B after binging the 2003 FMA adaptation, and while I fell in love with both adaptations, there's a couple things I missed.
I personally LOVE 2003's twist of Mustang being the one who killed Winry's parents, and honestly, to me, it just sounds so much more realistic as a show that shows a bit about how people like him are able to do anything under orders. I feel like in Brotherhood (although probably in the manga canon as well, haven't gotten to it yet) he's made to seem more like just an awful person than a vigilante. I missed
                  the whole Dante storyline a bit, since I thought she was just an amazingly written villain. I also feel the whole ongoing joke of Ed being short gets really tiring after the first 10 times (or whatever) it's mentioned.
However, in Brotherhood, I find it very beautiful how Hohenheim is portrayed in a much more humane way, instead of the somewhat selfish man desperate for eternal life we see in 2003.
Brotherhood's animation is simply a delight compared to 2003's, however, I personally think 2003's soundtrack is much more elaborate and entrancing.
Basically, I think both have great parts to them. However, 2009 feels much less terrifying and serious than 2003, which is something I missed a bit. Humor is sometimes used in situations where I think it wouldn't be needed, but I believe for younger viewers, it must be a breath of fresh air.
tl;dr both are great and have their own good parts!

"What could equal the value of a human soul?" 
Fullmetal Alchemist asks this question, and does not give a definite answer. Many different characters put different values on a human soul, yet none of them have the correct value. When our protagonists, Edward and Alphonse Elric attempt to put a value on a human soul through alchemy, it causes the Edward to lose his arm and leg, and Alphonse to lose his entire body, they must set out on a journey to restore their bodies, unknowing on how they can accomplish such a feat.
The only issue I have with brotherhood is that it does not
                  include the coal mine town episode, which in the manga and 2003 version of the show, displays an interesting aspect of Edward Elric's character, how he has a selfless streak.

Legendary status is what this anime has. I honestly don't know why I am even bothering to write up a review on this, other than to save the poor souls who settled on the regular version of Fullmetal Alchemist when they were younger.

WELCOME FRIEND!

There's not too much to say about this anime that hasn't been said already, but I did want to share my opinion on it regardless as someone who went in with high standards and was already aware of the rating of this show beforehand. 
In terms of the pros and cons of this anime, the pros are: Very compelling, thought out, and unique story. It doesn't have many holes in it (none that matter, anyway) and the pacing is pretty close to perfect. It's pretty fast pace at times, especially in the beginning, but it remains to be that perfect balance of not too fast-paced
                  and not too slow. The characters are all pretty likable for the most part and some have more character development than others. The soundtrack is amazing and definitely help to create and amplify the atmosphere of the scenes in the show. The ending is fantastic, and the story wraps up without leaving any important loose strings. I also love the fact that it doesn't go the typical shounen all-powerful kid route and instead opts for a story in which the protagonist and people around him really aren't that powerful compared to the villains (with one exception) and so it doesn't just come around to deus ex machina bs. Instead, it uses actual strategy and plot progression to deal with the antagonists. 
Now for the cons; I honestly hated the comedy throughout this show. It was extremely repetitive and often cringeworthy, which I could forgive, if it wasn't for the fact that these comedy scenes often take place in the middle of what should be SERIOUS scenes. There's plenty of examples of this that you'll see throughout the show, but the creator clearly does not understand when there should be comedy and when there shouldn't be. I understand not wanting the to take itself too seriously, but when you implore serious and thought-provoking scenes and then have a random burst of comedy it just makes the seriousness less serious, giving viewers a strange mood-whiplash. The story was also pretty boring at times, and I don't think it has anything to do with being slow paced, as it's not. Certain arcs of the story just simply don't have much interesting going on and it led to me just being straight up bored throughout large parts of the show leading up to the climax. The main 2 protagonists were also just...alright? I don't have any real dislike for them but nothing about them was all that interesting to me. Edward, to me, doesn't seem to have much of any 'development'. He was already incredibly remorseful for what he did in the beginning and also realized that humans can't come back and he was foolish to try and play god. In the end, it seems that rather than developing he just came to a sudden realization. Alphonse is just simply a young, loveable and sweet child but that's pretty much all there is to say about him. The father (both the antagonist and the father of ed) are definitely the most interesting characters to say the least. 
Overall, I still really enjoyed this show and thought it lived up to the hype for the most part. It feels really complete and just all around a great story. I wouldn't say it was groundbreaking or a 'masterpiece', though. I don't know if this show is really a 9 but I'm going more off of the words use to describe the numers, with 9 being a 'great' and I do feel that this show is great.

FMAB review by Rfonzx (potential spoilers!)
FMAB. This anime is WIDELY KNOWN around the world for being the number one anime on MAL. 7/14 is the date when I've finally decided to watch FMAB. Why, you said? because I wanted to know the reason why does this anime gets the number one spot on MAL. It took me like 14 days to complete the whole 64 episodes of it. I'd consider it a binge watch, since I usually don't watch anime at a consistent amount of rate. And now, here I am, making a review about this anime. 
(disclaimer: this is my first time making an
                  anime review, and there's gonna be a POTENTIAL SPOILERS here on the review!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!)
Plot : 9.5/10
At first, I thought the plot of FMAB would be way more superior than the cast. But I was 100% sure that I was wrong back then. But that doesn't mean that the plot was bad, it was good. The pacing of this anime is fine, you just gotta pause the certain confusing part of the episode to make sure that you don't miss anything. The first 50 episodes are good, but the last 14 episodes are definitely the best part. It was like a roller coaster of emotion, there are times when you feel like you're gonna bawl your eyes out, and there are times when you feel a heartwarming feelings in you.
Art (Sound and animations)
For the sound, it was definitely a 7.75. It was nothing special, but it sure does the job, especially at the last few episodes, it was done thoroughly. For the opening and endings, my favorite openings are the 5th one while my favorite endings are the 4th one. Animation-wise, it was around a 8.5-9. Some of the fight scenes are very well made and I found nothing (about the animation) that bothers me.
Cast : 9.75
So basically the Elric Bros are the main attention of the cast. Their character journey throughout the anime is beautifully made, especially at the 60-64th episode. That's basically their whole character conclusion. The way Ed overcomes his hardships throughout the series and then finding out what was the true meaning of the "truth" really is was defo the peak moment on the anime. 95% of the cast serves a huuuugeee role on the plot. They were made for a necessary purposes. And almost every one of them are well written (IMO the best written characters on this anime are Scar, Hohenheim, and Edward). FMAB's cast is definitely one of the best cast that I've ever seen. (This cast is in my opinion slightly better than AOT's)
Enjoyment: 9.75/10
Well, my enjoyment for the series would be a 10 if only I didn't get spoiled. But it was   very enjoyable nonetheless.
Overall: 9.5/10
Overall, this anime satisfied myself in almost every aspect (except the sound, it didn't fulfill my expectation very well). My predicted rating for the series before I watched the whole thing is actually a 10. I would never expect it to be a 9.5, but you know what? 9,5 is still a high rating. 
Well, now I know why does this anime is the best-rated anime on MAL. It 100% deserves the rating, cause it's a great anime to watch and I had a great journey watching it. It's not the best anime ever made, though. There are a few animes that are better than FMAB (Like Eva, AOT, and ASV). But it doesn't mean that FMAB is not worth the watch just because it isn't the best anime ever made.  If you haven't seen the anime yet, then you're truly missing out! It deserves the watch!!
Thank you for taking your time reading my first review =)

I've put off writing a review for this show a lot of times. It's one of the best reviewed and most praised anime of all time, currently sitting at #1 on MAL. And I felt conflicted on this since I started watching it, so I think I'm just gonna say what I feel and try not to think too much about it.
First of all, the things I liked: I actually thought that alchemy was an interesting as fuck concept and that it was really well implemented in the story. And that was probably my favorite thing in the show, the story. I liked all the
                  twists and turns that it took and how everything slowly unravels. 
The animation was also really good, and the artstyle really fit the tone and world the story took place in.
But I didn't like everything in it, and that's where the problems started forming for me, the story didn't really balance well the attention that it gave to some plot points compared to others. Like Nina for example, for such an important part of the story and the main characters' motivations, I think that it could have used one more episode to develop, since two scenes of them playing together wasn't enough to build a connection with me, which led me to fell nothing when the thing that happens to her happened.
Which brings me to the thing that I probably liked the least in FMAB, the characters, I think that most of them (with the exception of Edward, Alphouse and Hohenheim) weren't that well developed and I didn't care for a lot of them. Especially the villians, since most of them get "last minute development".
Another thing that I had issues with was the pacing, since the show slows down at the middle and I felt really bored when watching it (but I think that that was more of a me problem).
And also the comedy sometimes outstayed its welcome.
However, what saved this show from being a 7/10 for me, were those 2 last episodes, because I absolutely adored them, everything was wraped up nicely and I ever cried a bit ngl.
So I think that’s it, I like this show, the story is interesting, but a lot of the times it failed to keep me invested (especially in Briggs), and the characters were not that amazing for me. But the strong ending, and interesting concepts make me think that this is a solid 8/10 in my eyes.
Thank you so much for reading through this entire thing! It really was hard for me to write this since it is my first review, and I really wanted to like this as much as everyone else xd. But I didn't, and that's ok.

Post Series Depression: ~1
Tear Factor: ~1
Laugh Factor: 6.5
Drama Factor: ~3
Character Attachment: ~7 - 9
Story: Very on track with no fillers or sidetracks from the main plot, and very easy to follow all the way through up until around the ending portion of the series in terms of the complexity.
Art: Can be very playful or very serious depending on the tone/mood of the scene. but overall it is pleasant to view.Sound: Nothing too special or unique, but not low in quality either.
Characters: Each one brings their own angle onto the entire series and fits into place perfectly. Each character is very well thought out.
Enjoyment: I'd say it's enjoyable, especially if you're looking for something with a scientific alchemy vibe that runs like HxH or Naruto (without fillers).
Overall: I'd have to say this one is high up on the charts - it is medium to long length though so buckle up for a long watch.

Visual and pacing
Clear visuals, pacing is tad bit slow for personal taste but comparative to other anime, it's good. Animation quality is very consistent, lowest looks good, best looks amazing. Fantastic imagery and depiction of the world of Amestris. Many different cultures, architectures, and nature and cities. 
+1.8 (Pacing could be a bit faster)
Sound and Voice acting
Voice acting is phenomenal both English and Japanese. Characters really deliver the emotions through the voice. Pain, anguish, suffering, disgust, hatred are highlights of the voices. There are also some loving and emotional lines that are also delivered very well. Sound effects never distract from the story, almost always
                  enhances every element of the visuals. Some emotional OSTs and many triumphant OSTs, that are recognizable but they all blend in together. Some good openings and endings, few of the songs are very memorable. 
+1.5 (Nitpick, it's just OST is very cohesive and maybe that made it less memorable)
Theme and story
There are multitude of themes, at the top of my head there is theme of what is lost can't be replaced, the war soldiers and the consequences, hatred breeds hatred, the value of individual life and the foolishness of grandiose self serving thoughts, etc. The overall plot of the FMA has story of the Elric brother as the focus but there are many other stories as well, Roy Mustang and his revenge against the homunculus, Scar and his story of redemption, the many B plots all have very satisfying conclusion and all culminates towards the finale of the story. The mystery and secret plots from the villain, as well as hidden plot moving behind the scenes by the protagonist groups, many things to speculate, even just the philosopher's stone. The plot twist of how fundamental of how alchemy was performed, what is needed for philosopher's stone, who are the true villains completely changes the perspective of these character interactions happen early on in the story. 
+4 (Full points, perfect)
Art Style
The character design is already tells quite an interesting story between Alphonse and Edward and their dichotomy, as well as this does get addressed as the story progresses. The art style stands right in middle of cute and handsome, and characters can be put into this wide spectrum of style, and most characters can give clear expressions ranging from happy/silly/cute expressions to serious/solemn/cool. Very adaptable style befitting of a long series that has extremely large range of stories to tell, and wide range of emotions to convey. 
+0.8 (In brotherhood I felt there were some misused art style queues, too many goofy moments)
Value to rewatch 
There are so many things going on you are bound to have missed subtle details and interaction, as well as plot twist reveals changing the viewer's perspective. Definitely worth the rewatch and more careful analysis. 
+1 (Mostly carried over from perfect story elements)
Personal Interest
It was very interesting from episode 1 of 2003, not so much in brotherhood unfortunately. If we combined the experience then it gets full marks. 
+0.5 (Comparatively 2003 first episode was very strong unlike brotherhood)
