This is a fantastic adaption of the manga storyline. When it comes to writing about large topics inside tiny tales, Arakawa is a master. Fullmetal Alchemist is, at its heart, a narrative of two brothers who are learning to mourn and grow up together. The serious topics of what it means to be alive in life beyond death are handled delicately and expertly subverted throughout the show. The program's type of alchemy is used often enough to make it a wonderful action show, but it does not get in the way of the plot, which is excellent. The plot and the characters are the ones
                  that have the power in the program, not the other way around. This is an excellent anime for anyone who is interested in topics about their purpose in life as well as the hereafter. 
A recurring topic in the program, grief, is not overplayed or pounded to death (haha). There are many humorous moments in the program, and the characters who are presented in the anime are so well-written that we, as viewers, get emotionally concerned in the fate of each character.
Some of the show's disadvantages, on the other hand, include the fact that the surface plots get complicated. In addition, the explanation and application of alchemy in the program might be a little unclear at times. However, one positive aspect of the writing is that the people and their adventures are depicted so beautifully that the confused power relations may be overlooked. Overall, this is a fantastic program that serves as an excellent introduction for those who wish to watch more serious anime.

FULLMETAL ALCHEMIST BROTHERHOOD: A TIMELESS MASTERPIECE
1) INTRODUCTION:
I picked my words carefully here, because it's far from my favorite anime, it's not even in my top 5, but it's a brilliantly built show
This masterpiece of an anime literally has everything, deep themes and philosophies, characters each of which have their own backstory, beliefs and goals who stay relevant to the end, whether it would be the good guys or the bad guys, an intricate storyline and one of the best and most satisfying endings in all of anime, an amazing power system that actually makes sense and the power scaling doesn't become garbage, good fights, superb
                  animation/art style and great music.
Now let me explain how fmab excels in these categories.
2) THEMES:
I'll be brief here since I'm just gonna list the prominent themes within the story and not expand on them since I'll do so in the other categories.
Essentially, other than your typical generic themes like hard work, friendship and never giving up, fmab masterfully tackles three themes and expands on them in detail, and they are:
- Human nature
- Evolution
- God
3) CHARACTERS:
Without a doubt, the best aspect in fmab, all the characters are so amazingly written and actually stay relevant in the end and not just become sidekicks for the main characters, all the while strengthening the show's themes and depictions. Let me give you examples
1- The theme of human nature is very prevalent in arakawa's characters such as:
-Kimblee who's a clear depiction for power corruption and what happens when power is given to the wrong person
-Bradley who's sole purpose in life is to find a good fight to the death, and he'll do anything to get it, just like every greedy person in our world
-Hohenheim who's someone simply struggling to make human connection, thus fails in his life as a father, a husband, and human being
-Scar who wants revenge more than anything else with a justifiable reason to do so
-Hawkeye, yes, someone as earnest as she is can in fact reflect the dark truth behind humans, it turned out that even Hawkeye finds enjoyment and satisfaction in shooting ishavalens
2- The theme of evolution is as prominent as that of human nature, here are characters who strengthen it
-Greed whose development is just amazing, as his name implies, he always wanted everything the world has to offer, yet what he truly wanted was the cheapest thing to have yet the hardest item to gain, he simply wanted friends, and after making this self-realization, he exhibited the least greedy act possible, he sacrificed his life to save his friends
-Scar who really surpassed my expectations after rewatching fmab, his development is actually fascinating, he just needed another perspective in life, and when he found that in miles, he started his development, to end up helping the very nation he swore to destroy
-Envy whose self-realization at the end and the fact that he finally understood that humans are in the same level as homunculi was just amazingly written
3- God
This theme is always fascinating to witness, seeing how every anime tries to depict God's existence in different manners, whether it would be Steins gate's depiction of the complete lack of a god given that normal humans are doing acts only God can do, conveying the message that there is no god, or the depiction of code geass of God being the thoughts, memories and emotions, or in fmab, in which Arakawa depicts God as the accumulation of all knowledge, truth, or put simply, god in fmab is "all", everything.
And the character that greatly strengthens this theme is none other than father, he just wanted freedom, but the sad reality is that no matter how much he escaped the flask he was put in, he'll always be trapped in another bigger flask, one can't obtain everything, so father's attempt at absorbing God was bound to fail before it even started.
4) STORY:
What can I say about fmab's story that isn't already said really. The storyline is just as close to perfection as you can possibly get. Having one of the best endings in all of anime, the journey the brothers went on felt real and the victory in the end just felt so damn satisfying and earned.
The first half of the anime served as a good introduction to the world, themes, concepts and characters and those first 30 episodes were solid, it was an 8/10 so far
But then, the Briggs arc happened and only then did it start deserving the hype it gets. Not only did this arc expand the world and introduce new great characters like kimblee and armstrong, it also answered many questions about the world, lore, and the past of some characters, like really, episode 30 (the ishvalen war) and episode 40 (hohenheim's past) are among my favorite episodes in the entire series
And all that build-up culminated in one of anime's best War arcs to date, the battle of central, my 5th favorite arc in all of anime, this is where we truly see Arakawa shine as a writer, her handling of the homunculi and how she masterfully executed their deaths, with each one being ironic seeing what their sin is, is just fascinating
5) FIGHTS/POWER SYSTEM:
I'll keep it brief here, the power system's great and the fights are really awesome, Bradley vs scar is one of my favorite fights in all of anime, both on a superficial level and on a thematic level, the fights are a visual treat
6) THE ADAPTATION:
Bones really took the adaptation into the next level with fmab, everything regarding the adaptation is great. The animation and art style are awesome, the music is just on point especially the dramatic soundtracks, and the openings and endings are also great, in fact "rain" op 5 and "let it all out" ed 2 are respectively my favorite opening and ending in all of anime
7) SOME MINOR FLAWS:
Nothing in fiction is perfect, that's a fact. You can nitpick and find mistakes in every fictional story ever. However, the amount of flaws is what matters here. And personally I can't find but two flaws in fmab
1-The beginning is a bit stiff and slow, at least compared to the madness in the second half of the show
2-The comedy is just terrible, especially in the beginning, it's forced, artificial, and it just ruins the moment. 
Like for example, in episode 9, Al blames Ed for what happened to his body and accuses him of faking his memories, and winry overhears them and then talks to Al to tell him how wrong he is, the moment was really touching, seeing winry cry and the music in the background gave off that feeling too, only for Al to make that stupid face expression and ruin the whole moment.
Of course that's without mentioning the joke that forms 90% of fmab's comedy that gets old after 3 episodes literally, and the "joke" goes like this:
- Ohh the fullmetal alchemist is here points at al
- ummm actually it's my brother
- what you mean that little kid is the fullmetal alchemist?!
- WHO YOU'RE CALLING LITTLE?!!!
EVERY time rinse and repeat like it really got old
8) CONCLUSION:
As I said, that's just my subjective take on the matter and why I think fmab is the greatest anime ever. Thanks for reading

FMAB is one of the most famous shows on this site, having held the #1 spot for quite some time, and after having watched it in its entirety I definitely can see why. I don't personally think its my favorite show, but I can definitely see why a large majority of people do. It manages to weave a long and interesting narrative through all 64 of its episodes. When so much of the modern anime scene is dominated by 1 cour shows, it can be nice to see a larger scale narrative like AOT or FMAB, they have more time to develop and set up
                  the story, leading to a much more satisfying narrative conclusion. Of course problems can arise within longer narratives: the larger amount of space can lead to lengthy filler portions in works with poorly planned or paced narratives, lengthy plots can sometimes become complicated and convoluted, or they can just end up being too damn long for you to ever want to finish. FMAB is the definition of a well executed longer-form narrative, and its 64 episodes are all worth the time investment to reach its conclusion.
The plot woven through those 64 episodes is definitely my favorite part of FMAB, because of how well it fills its runtime. The pacing is sublime, starting comfortably slow as the characters slowly uncover the plot and basic characters, elements, and setting are set up and established. The first chunk of the show is at this slow pace, as Edward and Alphonse go on small adventures dealing with relatively small scale problems as the bigger plot is teased more and more until part of its revealed in a big sub-climax and the stakes are raised and the pacing is sped up. This formula is then continued all the way up until the finale, where all of the elements come together in a super epic climax that ends the long journey with a satisfying conclusion. FMAB also has its own fair share of interesting plot twists throughout its runtime, while none of them are anything as crazy as what's in AOT, they all keep the plot fresh and interesting to make sure our heroes aren't just following the same exact goal for the entirety of the series. Bones did a great job with their execution of the plot and it is easily the strongest part of the series.
FMAB also carries a great sense of humor along with it in addition to its fantastic story. I found the jokes decently funny and they were great at easing the tension in the moments in the show when Ed and Al weren't fighting for their lives against incredibly powerful enemies. Humor is obviously even more subjective then other aspects of an opinion on a series, but personally I liked a good majority of the jokes  in the series and found them to be a refreshing break from the rest of the action and drama that populates FMAB.
Second to the story, my next favorite element would have to be the characters. While I don't think they are a masterclass in character writing, I believe they all feel a bit grounded and relatable in some way. Their are plenty of valid arguments as to why they aren't good because of things like being defined by trauma or wearing their goals on their sleeve, I don't think they are necessarily bad characters for those traits. While sometimes a character can feel like just existing to die in a dramatic fashion, if I still enjoyed that character and their death impacted me, then I say its fine. Their are plenty of really blatant examples of "tear-baiting" characters as I am going to call them and I feel that FMAB isn't really one of those blatant examples. With one exception, I think pretty much every tear-baitey character in the show has some other reason to exist other than just getting a reaction out of the audience when they die. They are more developed and well rounded than characters that exist literally just to die. I ended this series enjoying a majority of the characters and I think that overall they did a pretty good job in their execution of them.
The art of FMAB was definitely one of its more weaker aspects, it was far from anything even resembling bad, but it was definitely one of the most average feeling aspects of the show. The overall style feels pretty generic barring some character designs. It wasn't something that detracted from the viewing experience, but it didn't add anything too special.
The music definitely fairs much better. The show has some good OP's and ED's for one (except for the bad ones) and has some quite memorable tracks played throughout the series. I don't know if its just because they were played throughout a 64 episode series that I have some of them engrained in my memory, but they are memorable all the same. The tracks are all well suited to the show and its style and setting, and exercise great control over the tone and feel from scene to scene.
FMAB is definitely one of the great shows in the vast medium that is anime. It is not personally one of my favorites, but I think it is a great example of what a shounen anime can be given time, effort, and sufficient development. I can totally see why it has received so much praise and will probably continue to for some time. I enjoyed my time watching this show and can firmly recommend it to basically anyone who likes anything even closely resembling the shounen genre.

Story:
Thrilling pacing with an addictive flow. It is a beautiful blend of simplicity and complexity which carries over well from the manga. There's plenty of meat to get one's teeth into and yet it doesn't overload the mind, and it represents its somewhat complex dynamics in a highly effective and clear way.
Art:
Consistently very good with no jarring sequences and many truly splendid battles filled with scintillating direction and dynamism.
Sound:
Some of the best music in a TV show I can recall, though it's a little lean. The tracks are memorable and paint the moods exquisitely and often profoundly. The added dimension introduced in the soundtrack toward
                  the end as the gravitas of the plot becomes ever-greater is one of the key elements which takes this show to rarified heights.
Character:
Adequate balance of character development without disturbing the tempo of the storytelling. We learn just enough about the characters, the depth of development sufficing, without getting bogged down. The important feature here is how the flow of the show isn't compromised by clunky writing, and a large part of that is the handling of character development and the time given to it.
Enjoyment:
Wish I could give it 11/10. The main draw of this show for me is how endlessly enjoyable it is. Perhaps other shows have better peaks and better sakuga and such, but the sheer joy of watching this tale unfold is simply unsurpassed perhaps in TV show history - so that includes shows which are not anime. If there is one show I could watch again and again it's FMA: Brotherhood. It's the way in which the show weaves together all its aspects with a flair and brilliance rarely matched, which gives the show a perpetual impetus — albeit I must confess that episodes ~30-39 didn't pull me through with the exhileration of the rest.
Overall:
It's a 10/10 - a score I give out very infrequently, whether that's for TV, movies, music, so on. Not that I ever want to instruct what people should do, but FMA:Brotherhood is one of the few "must at least try it out" shows.

FMA:B is certainly a great anime, but personally I didn't find it that outstanding.
Concept: 9/10 the cocepts and ideas behind FM:B are great. lots of original ideas. it's more than anything philosophical. one might not agree with everything. but they are still interesting to explore. also they might not be that catchy at first.
Plot: 8.5/10: the plot is really good for the most part, everything is fairly balanced with great conflicts, great twists. and also some comedy. It's not too complicated, actually it's quite simple at times, I would say it explores complex ideas with simplicity(to some degree) 
however it's not always necessarily engaing.
first few
                  episodes are boring(for well known reasons) but even after that it might not keep you interested all the time.
(for the first few eps) the show fails to properly build up for some stuff early on. and you just don't feel the anticipation and thrill (=less interest). and when you get to some events, they might feel underwhelming because of that.
but as for the rest, I'm not really sure why it was not that interesting for me at times. I think it's because the show does not constantly present you with really catchy stuff for a good portion of the story. it's mostly build up with catchy stuff in between. for me it really got good at about the mid point when the build up was done and everything started unraveling. at which point I was fully invested. but others might not be that patient.
Visuals 8/10: Art and animation is fairly good for it's time. action is also good.
soundtracks 8/10
Characters 10/10: the characters in FMA are genuinely great. great protagonist(s), great antagonist(s). sometimes decent sometimes mind blowing motivations. exploration of each character done nicely. ironic fates. great main characters, fairly decent side characters. almost all important characters have some level of unique complexity and are really interesting and likeable. even the villains.
Enjoyment 8/10: it might or might not be personal taste, but I didn't enjoy it as much as I thought I would.
Overall 8.7/10: with that being said, I personally don't find it to be the best anime of all time it's certainly great. but just not on that level. for me it's a high 8, not above 9. besides it's concepts and ideas there is not really something about this show that will blow your mind. concept isnn't everything. great animation, action, music, complex plot, complex characters, almost every other aspect is done better by other shows, sometimes altogether sometimes individually.

10/10 Masterpiece do I even need to justify it? It's been #1 on this site forever, you all know it's good.
Is it perhaps, over-hyped a bit? Is there anything overrated about this show that maybe gives it a boost in popularity it doesn't deserve? Actually, that's probably true. I think that like Naruto, FMA as a franchise was a gateway anime for a lot of people, myself included. The 2003 series was always on on Adult Swim when I was in middle school and I remember when this series first dropped it was a bid deal.
I didn't watch it at the time it came out
                  because I didn't really understand how it would be different from the 2003 series, and the first episode is kind of a confusing one. They were trying to tell us this would be a brand new story starting from the beginning and following the manga more closely, but it seemed this first episode wouldn't make any sense to anyone who wasn't already familiar with the characters. It was like they were trying to say, yeah it's a new show but come on in look we've got all your favorite guys in it.
Lowart is a youtube channel that has a really long in depth video series talking about all the differences between the two shows, so if you've got like 5 hours to kill check it out. I think that regardless this show is one of those few great anime that manages to tell a complete story in just around 50-75 episodes. I think this is a level of storytelling that is rare in the medium. Most often you'll either get anime that run 12 episodes and never get an ending, go buy the manga please, or you get One Piece. 1000 episodes strong upon writing this and no signs of stopping anytime soon. It's okay to let a story progress quickly and end organically rather than milk it forever just because it keeps making money.
Just the story being complete would be enough to get this an 8 for being good. But the story is also still really good, even after seeing it so many times I choke up a bit near the end. I love the episode where Hohenheim reminisces on his past, especially since we aren't sure at that point in the story what the deal with Father is or whether Hohenheim is actually a bad guy. I love the prince of Xing and Mustang and Greed and Scar, to say nothing of our main protagonists. It's a good story with amazing character writing that manages to be complete and cohesive and not go on forever.
So yeah maybe it's a little overhyped because of it's position as the great gateway anime, but honestly you could do much worse for a gateway series. Imagine becoming an anime fan on stuff like Trigun or Cowboy Bebop. Frickin anime boomers.

It's been quite long since I watched my first anime ever, Cowboy Bebop, so I decided to watch another anime recently, Fullmetal Alchemist: Brotherhood.
As someone who has a twin brother, I found Fullmetal Alchemist: Brotherhood's story and main characters to be very relatable at times, and that made the experience all the more engaging and emotional. However, Fullmetal Alchemist: Brotherhood has incredible story and characters on its own anyway, filled with different metaphors, themes and ideas.
Surprisingly enough, Fullmetal Alchemist: Brotherhood is a fairly humorous series with a wonderful sense of humor and witty dialogue!
Also, the music - particularly the opening/ending themes - is beautiful, and
                  the pacing is consistent. I've heard that the first few episodes feel rushed if you watched the original Fullmetal Alchemist series but I didn't have a problem personally because I haven't watched the original Fullmetal Alchemist series.
Fortunately for Fullmetal Alchemist: Brotherhood, I actually can't think of any major flaws to be honest; I thought it was pretty much perfect overall.
Pros:
+ Engrossing story & characters
+ Charming humor & dialogue
+ Amazing music
+ Well-paced plot
Cons:
- None
Final Rating: 10/10
- Masterpiece -
Simply put, Fullmetal Alchemist: Brotherhood is a masterpiece; it's fascinating in every single way, it never gets boring and it does almost everything right.
Do I recommend it?:
Hell yes! It's really worth your time.
If you're a fan of Anime, you must watch Fullmetal Alchemist: Brotherhood.

In my opinion, no matter how good the Anime is, it will be very difficult to beat this Anime Remake from Fullmetal Alchemist and it is not wrong if there are people who OVERPROUD this anime, the main reason is of course the StoryLine which is very stunning and doesn't leave the slightest gap until to make me stand and applaud after seeing the sentence `` Fin '' on the last scene at LastEps.
If almost all anime only have a StoryLine 0-80 or a maximum of 0-98, this anime even has a StoryLine 0-101, especially with the 10 opening and ending songs which are so
                  nice to hear with lyrics that are so in accordance with the situation that is happening in The anime. In addition, each Chara also gets their own portion in the story plus the concept of science combined with the Fantasy genre that makes us so interested in exploring and understanding what Alchemy really is, (I plan to make a Thread about this Anime in the next post😊) . So of course it's not wrong if this Anime is no longer called Legend but Master Piece hehe. [Remember this is my opinion Loh: v]
   The only drawback of this Anime is that it brings the element of God and then it violates its Nature (Even though I know that the god referred to in this Anime is not the real God but a supreme fictional existence in FMAverse, after all the God that is meant here is not Omnipotence but only Omnisaince. ], Actually there are no shortcomings at all in FMAB Anime but because I am also a religious community so in my opinion those are the few drawbacks:)
    • Personal Rate: 11/10.

it's one of the best animes that i have ever seen the plot is very interesting and u can never guess what's going to happen next not to mention that all the opening songs are smply awsm and there'salso comedy in the anime for all anime lovers this is simply one anime that u can't miss out on

A masterpiece of an Anime and one I recommend to watch.
The story, art, characters, and action of this story are all on point, so you can never get bored watching.
The story starts off with two brothers just wanting to return their bodies to normal, yet as the story goes on they discover deeper and larger conspiracies that threaten the entire country if not the world.
The dynamic of Ed and Al shows as they are brothers who would do anything for the other. It sometimes feels like there is one main character, that being the Elric Brothers.  
There are so many interesting and meaningful characters
                  throughout the entire story you can't help but feel for them all.
So again, I recommend this anime be a must-see.

I really enjoyed wachting it. It  has one of the best the story lines I have ever seen. Detials in storyline and also in the art made love it. It has really good character development and also pretty good side characters. They did not neglect the side chacters and focus on the main characters. All characters are well writen. Soundtracks are pretty good as well. They are perfectly suited to the scenes. It made me feel the emotions in those scnes. Art in the fmab is good as well. They really tried their best for the art. Overall I recommend everyone to watch it.

Nice time pass anime, I enjoyed the story but sometimes after half 30episodes, it feels like it is being stretched. Animation and sound is good, the majority of the story focuses on character building. I can say that this anime is for people who like watching story-type anime, brotherhood and somewhat childish anime.
Nice plot twists at the end of a few episodes but it was so long to watch 50+ episodes of the story that I wanted it to just finish asap.
This is not the genre I usually watch and it is 64+ episodes so It was not worth watching for me.
